description: The Apple Certified Technical Coordinator certification is designed for anyone responsible for managing Apple computers and devices in a business environment. The exam is made up of content from the Support Essentials ACSP course, as well as content from the Server Essentials course which is covered in this show. Technologies covered include topics like network deployment, policy management, troubleshooting and using Open Directory for centralized user management.

We're gonna go ahead and

episodes.description: In this episode Don walks us through the various name-lookup configurations for Mac OS X Server. He shows how to set the hostname for your server, how to create DNS zones and host records, and demonstrates setting up redundant DNS servers.
episodes.title: Domain Name System

1

[MUSIC]

So if you watched

I just have to start somewhere so

17
00:00:52.720 --> 00:00:57.630
Now, DNS is the Domain Name System and
whether you know it or not,

18
00:00:57.630 --> 00:01:00.310
you use it every single day.

19
00:01:00.310 --> 00:01:04.510
When we browse to a web page or
access a network resource as human beings

20
00:01:04.510 --> 00:01:06.940
we don't think in terms of numbers,
we think in terms of names.

21
00:01:06.940 --> 00:01:10.620
If you wanna go to Apple's
website I go to www.apple.com.

22
00:01:10.620 --> 00:01:13.880
If I wanna access a file server
here in the building I might go to

23
00:01:13.880 --> 00:01:16.790
FileServer 01 or
something like that but they're names.

24
00:01:16.790 --> 00:01:18.380
Names are easy to remember.

25
00:01:18.380 --> 00:01:20.310
But your computer doesn't think that way.

26
00:01:20.310 --> 00:01:22.530
Your computer thinks in terms of numbers.

27
00:01:22.530 --> 00:01:27.360
Every computer, every server has a number
an IP address that we wanna access and

28
00:01:27.360 --> 00:01:30.270
we need to translate from name to number.

29
00:01:30.270 --> 00:01:33.400
DNS is what does that,
Domain Naming System.

30
00:01:33.400 --> 00:01:34.550
And it's happening all the time.

31
00:01:34.550 --> 00:01:35.950
When you fire up that web browser and

32
00:01:35.950 --> 00:01:38.740
you go to Apple's website, in the
background it's doing a look up, right?

33
00:01:38.740 --> 00:01:41.100

34
00:01:41.100 --> 00:01:45.070
So, if I take this client and

35
00:01:45.070 --> 00:01:48.944
And in Safari I can go to www.apple.com,

36
00:01:48.944 --> 00:01:51.126
So I'm going to browse their website,

37
00:01:51.126 --> 00:01:52.891
All I had to know was a name.

38
00:01:52.891 --> 00:01:56.465
But in the background it did
a name resolution look up, so

39

00:01:59.666 --> 00:02:04.740

41
00:02:04.740 --> 00:02:10.190
And here I can type in www.apple.com and

42
00:02:10.190 --> 00:02:11.469
And when it looks up, here it is.

43
00:02:11.469 --> 00:02:16.964
Apple.com was actually mapped
to 104.107.38.42, right?

44
00:02:16.964 --> 00:02:19.750
That's what the computer saw,
that's what the computer wanted.

45
00:02:19.750 --> 00:02:21.410
It didn't want a name.

46
00:02:21.410 --> 00:02:22.950
But I can't remember this.

47
00:02:22.950 --> 00:02:26.510
I can't remember 104.107.38.42,
I guess I could, over time.

48
00:02:26.510 --> 00:02:29.890
But I couldn't remember a bunch

49
00:02:29.890 --> 00:02:31.190
But I can remember a bunch of names.

50
00:02:31.190 --> 00:02:35.970
I can remember CNN.com or
ITPro.tv, Amazon.com, Apple.com.

51
00:02:35.970 --> 00:02:37.800
Those are easy to remember, all right?

52
00:02:37.800 --> 00:02:41.030
So the naming system is designed
to make life easy for us.

53
00:02:41.030 --> 00:02:45.830
And that's true on the internet and
it's true on your own private network.

54
00:02:45.830 --> 00:02:48.590
So if you're going to be setting up
a server, you probably want it to have

55
00:02:48.590 --> 00:02:51.400
a name and you probably want people
to be able to resolve that name.

56
00:02:51.400 --> 00:02:56.130
The problem is on your own network
your probably using private IP's.

57
00:02:56.130 --> 00:02:58.750
Right?
Not public IP's like out on the internet.

58
00:02:58.750 --> 00:03:03.580
So we can't rely on the internet
DNS servers to do our lookups.

59
00:03:03.580 --> 00:03:07.150
So we need to set up our own name
server to ba able to power this.

60
00:03:07.150 --> 00:03:07.820
All right.

61
00:03:07.820 --> 00:03:10.640
Setting up your own
nameserver is not hard.

62
00:03:10.640 --> 00:03:12.360
It's built right here into the server app,
and

63
00:03:12.360 --> 00:03:14.030
if you're gonna be doing Open Directory,

64
00:03:14.030 --> 00:03:16.370
you'll very likely want
to set this up anyway.

65
00:03:16.370 --> 00:03:19.140
A lot of services will use Bonjour,
and Bonjour's great.

66
00:03:19.140 --> 00:03:21.630
You can find other machines
on your network, but

67
00:03:21.630 --> 00:03:23.950
some services don't use Bonjour.

68
00:03:23.950 --> 00:03:26.300
And so for them, you need DNS.

69
00:03:26.300 --> 00:03:28.890
The other thing is,
Bonjour is not routable.

70
00:03:28.890 --> 00:03:32.800
Bonjour will find other clients right
there on the same network as you.

71
00:03:32.800 --> 00:03:34.820
But what if you have more
than one network, right?

72
00:03:34.820 --> 00:03:38.810
Maybe you work for a school board, and
you've got a central data center at your

73
00:03:38.810 --> 00:03:42.190
county office, and
then you've got 100 schools out there.

74
00:03:42.190 --> 00:03:44.050
That's 100 different networks.

75
00:03:44.050 --> 00:03:47.740
You can't run Bonjour in one school,
and find servers in another.

76
00:03:47.740 --> 00:03:51.090
You can't detect machines
on a different network.

77
00:03:51.090 --> 00:03:56.090
With DNS we can, with DNS everybody
registers their name with DNS.

78
00:03:56.090 --> 00:03:58.740
And once it's tied to DNS,
now when we do a lookup,

79
00:03:58.740 --> 00:04:00.170
we just look it up on the name server.

80
00:04:00.170 --> 00:04:03.160
And then we can reach out and connect that
person, it makes life a lot easier and

81
00:04:03.160 --> 00:04:04.540
much more scalable.

82
00:04:04.540 --> 00:04:07.410
>> Now Don, if we have a service maybe, or

83
00:04:07.410 --> 00:04:12.120
maybe an application there that starts
with let's say an IP address, and

84
00:04:12.120 --> 00:04:16.705
I don't have a name, is there a way that
we can connect if we have an IP address?

85
00:04:16.705 --> 00:04:18.465
But we don't have the name itself?

86
00:04:18.465 --> 00:04:22.545
>> Sometimes, yeah, what I'm showing
you here is a forward lookup, right?

87
00:04:22.545 --> 00:04:24.455
Forward lookup is a name to an IP.

88
00:04:24.455 --> 00:04:26.995
But you also have what's
called a reverse lookup.

89
00:04:26.995 --> 00:04:29.605
And a reverse lookup is where
you go from an IP to a name.

90
00:04:29.605 --> 00:04:32.555
Now when would we need that?

91
00:04:32.555 --> 00:04:34.225
For us, most of the time we don't need it.

92
00:04:34.225 --> 00:04:36.350
It is not something that we
really need to mess with.

93
00:04:36.350 --> 00:04:41.050
But if you're ever trying to troubleshoot
your network, troubleshoot a problem and

94
00:04:41.050 --> 00:04:42.050
find your way back, whatever.

95
00:04:42.050 --> 00:04:46.480
That reverse lookup is kind of handy, kind
of useful to see what you're connected.

96
00:04:46.480 --> 00:04:50.390
Let's see if I can give you
a quick example on the spot.

97
00:04:50.390 --> 00:04:53.399
When I fire this up and
I went to apple.com, right?

98
00:04:53.399 --> 00:04:56.500
I went to that website,
I know it's called apple.com.

99
00:04:56.500 --> 00:04:59.220
And I did a four look up to find that IP.

100
00:04:59.220 --> 00:05:01.780
Well if I took that IP.

101
00:05:01.780 --> 00:05:06.460
And I plugged it in here and did a lookup,
it's gonna do a reverse lookup.

102
00:05:06.460 --> 00:05:08.195
And look at the reverse
lookup that I got on that,

103
00:05:08.195 --> 00:05:12.560
deploy.static.akamaitechnologies.com.

104
00:05:12.560 --> 00:05:14.420
That's not Apple, right?

105
00:05:14.420 --> 00:05:17.980
Well, Akamai is a CDN,
a content distribution network.

106
00:05:17.980 --> 00:05:20.150
They have servers all over the world.

107
00:05:20.150 --> 00:05:23.860
If you want to have a website with
millions of visitors that are all over

108
00:05:23.860 --> 00:05:26.870
the planet you can contract it through
Akamai and you can use their network and

109
00:05:26.870 --> 00:05:28.520
that's exactly what Apple's doing.

110
00:05:28.520 --> 00:05:31.580
So I was able to use that
reverse lookup to figure out

111
00:05:31.580 --> 00:05:33.690
how Apple's hosting their server.

112
00:05:33.690 --> 00:05:36.950
Not the most useful information in the
world, but that's kind of one use for it.

113
00:05:36.950 --> 00:05:41.550
More importantly, though, there's some
utilities like If I go into terminal and

114
00:05:42.920 --> 00:05:47.750
I do a netstat -an, let's see,
was that the one I wanted?

115
00:05:47.750 --> 00:05:48.970
What a mess.

116
00:05:48.970 --> 00:05:51.085
Let's just do a straight up netstat.

117
00:05:51.085 --> 00:05:53.820
[LAUGH] There we go.

118
00:05:53.820 --> 00:05:57.120
If I do a netstat, it shows all the
different network connections that I've

119
00:05:57.120 --> 00:06:02.320
got open, and when you look at those
network connections Somewhere in here,

120
00:06:02.320 --> 00:06:05.050
I probably should have filled
through this, here we go.

121
00:06:05.050 --> 00:06:09.210
When you look at all your network
connections, some of them, it shows an IP.

122
00:06:09.210 --> 00:06:13.190
When you see an IP, I know that I've got
an open connection to this IP address.

123
00:06:13.190 --> 00:06:14.500
Who is it?

124
00:06:14.500 --> 00:06:16.910
I don't know,
it didn't figure it out right.

125
00:06:16.910 --> 00:06:22.090
But other ones, you'll see where it
actually has some kind of a name

126
00:06:22.090 --> 00:06:26.710
It was able to do a reversed lookup to
figure out who that was for me, and

127
00:06:26.710 --> 00:06:29.950
unfortunately its truncating some of
these where I can't truly see, but

128
00:06:29.950 --> 00:06:32.210
like here I've got appleglobal or
wherever.

129
00:06:32.210 --> 00:06:33.920
So the reversal lookups
can help me to figure

130
00:06:33.920 --> 00:06:36.050
out who it is I have a connection open to.

131
00:06:36.050 --> 00:06:37.910
This is a virtual machine and

132
00:06:37.910 --> 00:06:40.480
the only thing I've done is
fired up Apple's website.

133
00:06:40.480 --> 00:06:43.090
But look at all these connections.

134
00:06:43.090 --> 00:06:45.800
All of that from Apple's website.

135
00:06:45.800 --> 00:06:46.630
Who are all these servers?

136
00:06:46.630 --> 00:06:47.930
Can I trust them?

137
00:06:47.930 --> 00:06:49.530
Maybe, maybe not, right?

138
00:06:49.530 --> 00:06:53.210
Some of them are content discretion
networks like the cdn right here, right?

139
00:06:53.210 --> 00:06:57.090
Others, I don't know who they are,
and so I might need to go in and

140
00:06:57.090 --> 00:06:59.870
do over just like trying to
figure out who that is and.

141
00:06:59.870 --> 00:07:02.700
A lot of people don't register
their reverse lookups.

142
00:07:02.700 --> 00:07:05.220
So it might be that you can't
do a reverse lookup on one.

143
00:07:05.220 --> 00:07:07.060
Like if I take this guy and

144
00:07:07.060 --> 00:07:10.700
I run a lookup on it,
operation could not be completed, right.

145
00:07:10.700 --> 00:07:14.180
So reverse lookups are useful but
don't rely on them,

146
00:07:14.180 --> 00:07:16.600
don't count on them being there
because they aren't always there.

147
00:07:18.290 --> 00:07:22.360
All right so let's say that I want
to set myself up as a DNS server

148
00:07:22.360 --> 00:07:24.190
Well the process isn't that hard.

149
00:07:24.190 --> 00:07:25.920
First off, the thing we need to recognize,

150
00:07:25.920 --> 00:07:30.430
is that DNS names are made
up of more than one part.

151
00:07:30.430 --> 00:07:34.520
When you look at a name like this,
the first part here https,

152
00:07:34.520 --> 00:07:36.330
that's the protocol I'm going to use.

153
00:07:36.330 --> 00:07:40.470
The hyper text transfer
protocol with ssl or secure.

154
00:07:40.470 --> 00:07:44.020
Right?
So, this is a secure version of http.

155
00:07:44.020 --> 00:07:44.930
That's just a protocol.

156
00:07:44.930 --> 00:07:48.300
And I don't care,
DNS doesn't care about protocols.

157
00:07:48.300 --> 00:07:52.210
But then I got this name,
www.apple.com, all right?

158
00:07:52.210 --> 00:07:55.772
Every DNS name is made up of three parts.

159
00:07:55.772 --> 00:07:58.405
With the parts basically, I shouldn't say
every, I say it could be two parts really.

160
00:07:58.405 --> 00:08:00.494
But typically you have three parts.

161
00:08:00.494 --> 00:08:04.187
There is the Top Level Domain or the TLD.

162
00:08:04.187 --> 00:08:07.790
There is the Domain, and
then there's the Host Name.

163
00:08:07.790 --> 00:08:10.680
And there could be a few
other pieces kinda

164
00:08:10.680 --> 00:08:13.340
thrown in there just depending
on what it is that we're doing.

165
00:08:14.860 --> 00:08:22.200
So, let me get into text edit for
example and I will show you what I mean.

166
00:08:22.200 --> 00:08:26.075
When I look at something
like www.apple.com.

167
00:08:26.075 --> 00:08:30.210
Okay, what this is actually gonna break
down to is just a few different pieces.

168
00:08:30.210 --> 00:08:32.780
You know, we're all gonna have seizures if
I leave that page open in the background.

169
00:08:32.780 --> 00:08:34.280
Let me get rid of that.

170
00:08:34.280 --> 00:08:38.540
So what this is really made up
of is really three parts, right?

171
00:08:38.540 --> 00:08:40.290
www that's the host.

172
00:08:40.290 --> 00:08:40.830
Okay.

173
00:08:40.830 --> 00:08:43.920
So there's a server somewhere
in Apple's network or

174
00:08:43.920 --> 00:08:45.370
[INAUDIBLE] network, that's called www.

175
00:08:45.370 --> 00:08:47.860
Well, the name doesn't actually
have to match the server.

176
00:08:47.860 --> 00:08:50.360
The server can be called
any number of things.

177
00:08:50.360 --> 00:08:53.780
But www is like a nickname
that has been given.

178
00:08:53.780 --> 00:08:54.600
All right.

179
00:08:54.600 --> 00:08:57.280
Then you've got Apple, that's the domain.

180
00:08:58.370 --> 00:09:02.420
so apple went and registered Apple.com
with one of the registrars that are out

181
00:09:02.420 --> 00:09:05.070
there many many years ago and
Apple is their domain.

182
00:09:05.070 --> 00:09:09.470
And then in com,
that is the top level domain, okay?

183
00:09:09.470 --> 00:09:10.970
or the TLD.

184
00:09:10.970 --> 00:09:14.950
Now the host and the domain,
you get to pick those.

185
00:09:14.950 --> 00:09:18.490
You can use whatever you want as long as
somebody else doesn't already have it.

186
00:09:18.490 --> 00:09:20.840
But the top level domain,
you don't get to pick, right?

187
00:09:20.840 --> 00:09:22.860
Those are determined by
the internet registrars.

188
00:09:22.860 --> 00:09:24.450
They make those.

189
00:09:24.450 --> 00:09:27.300
The ARIN, INA, those guys.

190
00:09:27.300 --> 00:09:29.270
InterNick is a big part of that, and

191
00:09:29.270 --> 00:09:31.950
they determine what top level
domains are going to be available.

192
00:09:31.950 --> 00:09:38.380
So you usually see .com, .net, .edu, .org.

193
00:09:38.380 --> 00:09:39.460
There's country codes.

194
00:09:39.460 --> 00:09:42.334
Almost every country has them,

195
00:09:42.334 --> 00:09:47.260
.uk, .us, what is Germany, .de, so
those country codes are out there.

196
00:09:47.260 --> 00:09:50.740
And there's new ones like .info or
.museum.

197
00:09:50.740 --> 00:09:53.600
There's a bunch of different
ones that have come out lately.

198
00:09:53.600 --> 00:09:55.600
So you may see those too.

199
00:09:55.600 --> 00:09:59.200
That top level domain though, that's
where you basically have to register and

200
00:09:59.200 --> 00:10:01.625
you have to pick one domain and so

201
00:10:01.625 --> 00:10:07.590
Apple.com is their fully qualified
domain name, their FQDN so Apple.com.

202
00:10:07.590 --> 00:10:12.350
When you create a DNS server you have to
pick what domains you're gonna host and

203
00:10:12.350 --> 00:10:14.090
those are called zones.

204
00:10:14.090 --> 00:10:17.490
And zones, can be forward look
up zones where it's name IP, or

205
00:10:17.490 --> 00:10:20.060
it can be reverse look up
zones where it's IP to name.

206
00:10:20.060 --> 00:10:22.970
So a zone corresponds to a domain.

207
00:10:22.970 --> 00:10:25.410
So Apple.com that may ne one zone,

208
00:10:25.410 --> 00:10:27.451
and then I might have
Google.com that's a zone.

209
00:10:27.451 --> 00:10:30.320
Amazon.co that's a zone and

210
00:10:30.320 --> 00:10:33.160
if I'm doing name IP they will
be forward look up zones.

211
00:10:33.160 --> 00:10:37.920
Inside the zone well host,
that's what this www is.

212
00:10:37.920 --> 00:10:41.940
A host is a particular system and
the ip address is associated with it.

213
00:10:41.940 --> 00:10:43.780
So there will be an ip type www.

214
00:10:43.780 --> 00:10:47.530
Now it might be a real host or
might be an alias.

215
00:10:47.530 --> 00:10:49.100
You gonna have alias to
point somewhere else.

216
00:10:49.100 --> 00:10:51.710
So there is different forms of
host records we can have, but

217
00:10:51.710 --> 00:10:53.379
that's kind of the basic
components inside of it.

218
00:10:54.620 --> 00:10:56.400
You can have sub domains though.

219
00:10:56.400 --> 00:10:57.890
That does happen.

220
00:10:57.890 --> 00:11:03.500
So you'll see, what's a good example,
like store.apple.com.

221
00:11:03.500 --> 00:11:08.210
And they might have us.store or
eu.store or whatever.

222
00:11:08.210 --> 00:11:11.310
So what you have here is

but if I did dig www.apple.com.

680
00:32:43.070 --> 00:32:44.250
What do I get?

681
00:32:44.250 --> 00:32:46.950
Well I get the A record,
I get the NS record.

682
00:32:46.950 --> 00:32:48.250
I get a little more information.

683
00:32:48.250 --> 00:32:50.400
That's giving me more data, right?

684
00:32:50.400 --> 00:32:51.980
The dig utility is a little more hardcore.

685
00:32:51.980 --> 00:32:54.340
I don't use it very often cuz
it is the older utility and

686
00:32:54.340 --> 00:32:56.830
I don't normally need the other data.

687
00:32:56.830 --> 00:33:01.350
But an example of what your seeing here
is IN lets me know it's a forward lookup,

688
00:33:01.350 --> 00:33:02.690
a name to an IP.

689
00:33:02.690 --> 00:33:04.520
A, it's an A record.

690
00:33:04.520 --> 00:33:08.288
I can see the IP address here, that's
great, and I can see the time to live.

691
00:33:08.288 --> 00:33:12.835
If I cache this entry on my DNS server,
it can only stay there for

692
00:33:12.835 --> 00:33:16.800
10,800 seconds, which I think is,
is that 12 hours, what is that?

693
00:33:16.800 --> 00:33:19.260
It's something.
It's a good period of time, but after

694
00:33:19.260 --> 00:33:22.310
that period of time I've got to do the
look up again in case the IP changes so

695
00:33:22.310 --> 00:33:24.840
that's the limit of how
long I can cache that.

696
00:33:24.840 --> 00:33:27.360
We also see who's the authority,
who it is that controls it.

697
00:33:27.360 --> 00:33:30.930
So that's the kind of information you
find here, not terribly useful, but

698
00:33:30.930 --> 00:33:33.660
dig and
nslookup work great from the command line.

699
00:33:33.660 --> 00:33:37.060
Network utility works great from the GUI
it just does not give you many options,

700
00:33:37.060 --> 00:33:38.410
but after that you can get it set up.

701
00:33:38.410 --> 00:33:42.465
So between the server app itself for
configuration and

702
00:33:42.465 --> 00:33:45.475
the command line utilities you can kind of
troubleshoot it, configure it, and see.

703
00:33:45.475 --> 00:33:48.955
>> You know Don, something that's
been burning through my mind.

704
00:33:48.955 --> 00:33:52.145
You've showed us how to configure
a couple of the servers,

705
00:33:52.145 --> 00:33:57.840
and that it's definitely handy to have,
but what if I've got 500 machines?

706
00:33:57.840 --> 00:33:59.690
Now what is the client experience?

707
00:33:59.690 --> 00:34:03.450
Are you gonna have to go in and manually
administer to 500 individual records to be

708
00:34:03.450 --> 00:34:04.670
able to find them on your domain?

709
00:34:04.670 --> 00:34:06.280
Or is this something that's not so

710
00:34:06.280 --> 00:34:08.600
administratively challenging,
at least for me?

711
00:34:08.600 --> 00:34:12.340
>> Well you can certainly do it by hand,
and if you are paid an hourly wage,

712
00:34:12.340 --> 00:34:13.000
I recommend it.

713
00:34:13.000 --> 00:34:15.020
Cuz it'll keep you employed
the rest of your life, right?

714
00:34:15.020 --> 00:34:17.900
Maintaining DNS records is a super pain,
so

715
00:34:17.900 --> 00:34:22.200
it's better to have your clients register
themselves automatically, all right.

716
00:34:22.200 --> 00:34:24.400
If you have DACP,
it might be doing it already.

717
00:34:24.400 --> 00:34:26.900
A lot of DACP servers
are automatically update DNS.

718
00:34:26.900 --> 00:34:28.370
So they hand out an address and

719
00:34:28.370 --> 00:34:30.530
they add you to DNS, but
you can do it on the client too.

720
00:34:30.530 --> 00:34:32.130
Let me show you here.

721
00:34:32.130 --> 00:34:34.510
If I go back into my
System Preferences and

722
00:34:34.510 --> 00:34:39.230
I go into Network,
I assigned a static IP right here, right.

723
00:34:39.230 --> 00:34:41.540
But if you go on to Advanced and

724
00:34:41.540 --> 00:34:45.640
go to DNS, here's where you can have what
DNS servers you're going to use, right?

725
00:34:45.640 --> 00:34:49.190
So I want to register, I want to use
this DNS server for doing lookups,

726
00:34:49.190 --> 00:34:54.310
and so I can add my server, or Google,
or whoever it is I want to add.

727
00:34:54.310 --> 00:34:57.120
And over here you can start
to add search domains, and

728
00:34:57.120 --> 00:34:59.730
the search domains
are like little shortcuts.

729
00:34:59.730 --> 00:35:05.960
If I do a one name lookup, if I just look
up www, what domain is that a part of?

730
00:35:05.960 --> 00:35:06.530
It doesn't know.

731
00:35:06.530 --> 00:35:09.841
It expects me to do www.lab.itpro.tv.

732
00:35:09.841 --> 00:35:15.617
So I could come in here and I could add
a search domain of lab.itpro.tv and

733
00:35:15.617 --> 00:35:18.820
if I ever do a one name lookup.

734
00:35:18.820 --> 00:35:21.800
It'll automatically append this domain and
try that.

735
00:35:21.800 --> 00:35:23.100
And you can add more than one and

736
00:35:23.100 --> 00:35:25.480
it'll just try them all in order
until it finds who we're looking for.

737
00:35:25.480 --> 00:35:29.000
So a great way to have shortcut names for
your systems, right?

738
00:35:29.000 --> 00:35:33.640
It also has the added effect of this
client trying to register with DNS.

739
00:35:33.640 --> 00:35:37.170
It'll say, okay, if I got that
as my entry, I'm gonna try and

740
00:35:37.170 --> 00:35:40.540
reach out and update and
get that registered.

741
00:35:40.540 --> 00:35:42.430
It doesn't typically work.

742
00:35:42.430 --> 00:35:44.660
That's where it's better to have
a DHCP server that does it.

743
00:35:44.660 --> 00:35:50.150
And we'll see some of those options in a
DHCP episode when we go and film that one,

744
00:35:50.150 --> 00:35:53.990
but for right now we can set that,
shoot, I don't think I hit Apply there.

745
00:35:53.990 --> 00:35:57.190
But anyhow, you had to hit Apply,
that would then take effect and

746
00:35:57.190 --> 00:35:58.391
we'd start to look up those names.

747
00:35:58.391 --> 00:36:02.510
But otherwise, doing the manual
entry in here, you can do it, but

748
00:36:02.510 --> 00:36:05.000
anytime somebody's IP changes,
it becomes a problem.

749
00:36:05.000 --> 00:36:09.130
Because DHCP is so common, you really
can't keep up with this as a person.

750
00:36:09.130 --> 00:36:11.120
Like I said, if you're an hourly employee,
you've got a job for

751
00:36:11.120 --> 00:36:13.750
life because it's just so
hard to stay on top of that.

752
00:36:13.750 --> 00:36:16.100
You want dynamic registration to occur.

753
00:36:16.100 --> 00:36:17.100
>> DNS, what a great service.

754
00:36:17.100 --> 00:36:21.190
So I don't have to have this huge laundry
list of IP addresses in my pocket,

755
00:36:21.190 --> 00:36:23.960
every time I wanna browse that
anything across the Internet.

756
00:36:23.960 --> 00:36:25.793
All good information, thank you, Don.

757
00:36:25.793 --> 00:36:28.750
It does seem like we are coming
to the end of this episode.

758
00:36:28.750 --> 00:36:31.934
Got any parting words of
wisdom before we end this one?

759
00:36:31.934 --> 00:36:32.880
>> That's about it.

760
00:36:32.880 --> 00:36:35.570
We're gonna see more DNS especially
when we get to Open Directory.

761
00:36:35.570 --> 00:36:39.250
Cuz Open Directory is really important
to get that set properly and

762
00:36:39.250 --> 00:36:41.780
you will even see it,
if you just pull out real quick.

763
00:36:42.880 --> 00:36:46.180
I set a DNS search suffix a moment ago.

764
00:36:46.180 --> 00:36:49.210
But when you go to
the homepage of my server,

765
00:36:49.210 --> 00:36:51.870
see my hostname OSX-SERVER01.local.

766
00:36:51.870 --> 00:36:54.810
My server doesn't know
that it is lab.itpro.tv so

767
00:36:54.810 --> 00:36:57.330
when we go to do open directory
we gotta get that straight.

768
00:36:57.330 --> 00:37:00.317
We're gonna se that again,
there'll be a lot DNS as the shows go on.

769
00:37:00.317 --> 00:37:03.049
But in this episode what I wanna
do is introduce you to the basics,

770
00:37:03.049 --> 00:37:05.879
how we can get a server set up,
how we can get some records in there and

771
00:37:05.879 --> 00:37:08.130
get it working and that's what we've seen.

772
00:37:08.130 --> 00:37:10.150
Just be aware that is kind
of the tip of the iceberg,

773
00:37:10.150 --> 00:37:11.960
there's a lot more that
goes on behind the scene.

774
00:37:11.960 --> 00:37:14.680
>> Well look forward to seeing that, and
we certainly look forward to seeing you

775
00:37:14.680 --> 00:37:18.590
there as well, but signing out here at
ITPRO.TV, I've been your host, Wes Bryan.

776
00:37:18.590 --> 00:37:19.550
>> And I'm Don Pezet.

777
00:37:19.550 --> 00:37:23.152
>> And we'll see you next time.

778
00:37:23.152 --> 00:37:29.480
[SOUND]

episodes.description: In this episode Don demonstrates the various ways that you can remotely manage a machine running the OS X Server App. He demonstrates SSH, screen sharing and remotely executing the Server App itself.
episodes.title: Remote Management
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.000 --> 00:00:10.000
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:12.125 --> 00:00:14.987
Welcome back to another exciting
episode here at ITPro.TV.

3
00:00:14.987 --> 00:00:16.510
I'm your host, Wes Bryan.

4
00:00:16.510 --> 00:00:20.280
And in today's episode, we're going to be
moving through OS X Server Essentials.

5
00:00:20.280 --> 00:00:22.910
And to help us out today is
none other than Mr. Don Pezet.

6
00:00:22.910 --> 00:00:24.650
Don, welcome, and
how are you doing today, Sir?

7
00:00:24.650 --> 00:00:25.490
>> I'm doing great, Wes.

8
00:00:25.490 --> 00:00:28.500
Ready to dive right back into
the world of OS X Server Essentials.

9
00:00:28.500 --> 00:00:31.910
And in this episode we're gonna
taka a look at remote management.

10
00:00:31.910 --> 00:00:36.540
And by remote management, what I mean
is when you set up an OS X server,

11
00:00:36.540 --> 00:00:40.280
it's likely not a computer that
you sit at every single day.

12
00:00:40.280 --> 00:00:42.960
A very common scenario is where
people take Mac minis, and

13
00:00:42.960 --> 00:00:46.830
they get them set up with the Server app
installed, and it's full-blown setup, and

14
00:00:46.830 --> 00:00:48.840
they stick it in a server rack somewhere.

15
00:00:48.840 --> 00:00:51.140
No keyboard, no mouse, no monitor,

16
00:00:51.140 --> 00:00:53.640
just a little Mac mini sitting
in a closet somewhere.

17
00:00:53.640 --> 00:00:56.120
Or a Mac Pro, you got the big
cylinder stuck in a closet,

18
00:00:56.120 --> 00:00:58.180
obviously you gotta worry
about ventilation and cooling.

19
00:00:58.180 --> 00:01:02.840
But you get it put somewhere and you don't
necessarily have physical access to it, so

20
00:01:02.840 --> 00:01:06.590
you need a way to be able to remotely
connect to that server to work with it,

21
00:01:06.590 --> 00:01:11.020
and you can do that from your laptop,
from your desktop, from your iPad even.

22
00:01:11.020 --> 00:01:13.480
There's a lot of different ways to
be able to remote in and connect and

23
00:01:13.480 --> 00:01:15.510
start to manage a server.

24
00:01:15.510 --> 00:01:20.270
We have the built in ways that are a part
of just any regular OS X install, but

25
00:01:20.270 --> 00:01:23.790
then there's a few extra little
kinda bells and whistles I guess for

26
00:01:23.790 --> 00:01:26.960
the Server app that we'll see here
today with just getting connected and

27
00:01:26.960 --> 00:01:28.370
starting to work with that system.

28
00:01:28.370 --> 00:01:30.960
This also comes in really handy
if you have more than one server.

29
00:01:30.960 --> 00:01:33.800
If you just have one server,
yeah you can walk over, sit down,

30
00:01:33.800 --> 00:01:34.610
and start to work on it.

31
00:01:34.610 --> 00:01:36.640
But what if you have 100 servers?

32
00:01:36.640 --> 00:01:38.230
What if you had 1000 servers?

33
00:01:38.230 --> 00:01:42.610
You don't want to have to go and
sit at each one or have 1000 monitors,

34
00:01:42.610 --> 00:01:44.010
and 1000 keyboards, and 1000 mice.

35
00:01:44.010 --> 00:01:45.190
You don't want that, right?

36
00:01:45.190 --> 00:01:48.420
So you want that headless unit to
where it's just the computer and

37
00:01:48.420 --> 00:01:52.360
it's tucked away in a server room, and
then you remotely connect and manage it.

38
00:01:52.360 --> 00:01:54.120
So you've got a lot of
different ways to do that, and

39
00:01:54.120 --> 00:01:56.600
that's what we're going to take
a look at right here in this episode.

40
00:01:56.600 --> 00:01:59.270
Now, Don, with remote management,
one of the things that I've

41
00:01:59.270 --> 00:02:02.540
seen in some of the other systems is,
it could be on by default.

42
00:02:02.540 --> 00:02:04.470
Is this on by default?

43
00:02:04.470 --> 00:02:07.810
Or for security purposes maybe,
is it turned off by default and

44
00:02:07.810 --> 00:02:09.520
something that we have to enable?

45
00:02:09.520 --> 00:02:10.360
>> Yes and no.

46
00:02:10.360 --> 00:02:14.780
>> Okay.
>> [LAUGH] No easy answers today.

47
00:02:14.780 --> 00:02:17.060
There's several different
types of remote management.

48
00:02:17.060 --> 00:02:21.370
Some are on by default, some are not,
and so we may have to go in and

49
00:02:21.370 --> 00:02:22.470
kinda tweak those.

50
00:02:22.470 --> 00:02:25.660
And what you'll find is that,
it's actually changed over the years.

51
00:02:25.660 --> 00:02:30.341
And so if you're on a brand new El Capitan
system, and you just installed the Server

52
00:02:30.341 --> 00:02:33.610
app for the first time,
most of them are actually off by default.

53
00:02:33.610 --> 00:02:36.140
They're off and
you've got to turn them on.

54
00:02:36.140 --> 00:02:41.320
But if you've got a system that's been
upgraded from Mavericks, to Yosemite,

55
00:02:41.320 --> 00:02:46.170
to El Capitan from server version three,
to four, to five, that some of them may

56
00:02:46.170 --> 00:02:49.050
actually be on by default cuz they were on
by default back in the earlier version.

57
00:02:49.050 --> 00:02:50.590
So that's kinda changed a little bit.

58
00:02:50.590 --> 00:02:52.870
It's alway a good idea to go and check and

59
00:02:52.870 --> 00:02:55.800
make sure that everything is
set the way that you want it.

60
00:02:55.800 --> 00:02:59.270
Well, when you set up a brand new server,
whether you want to manage it remotely or

61
00:02:59.270 --> 00:03:02.490
not, you have to start
on the server itself.

62
00:03:02.490 --> 00:03:05.045
And you might remember from some of
the earlier episodes we set this up

63
00:03:05.045 --> 00:03:05.760
where I said that.

64
00:03:05.760 --> 00:03:11.265
I said, you've got to run the Server app
at least one time from the server itself.

65
00:03:11.265 --> 00:03:15.250
And the main reason is if you don't run it
at least once the services don't start,

66
00:03:15.250 --> 00:03:17.850
you can't remotely manage
something that's not even started.

67
00:03:17.850 --> 00:03:22.870
So we've gotta start the Server app
at least one time on the server.

68
00:03:22.870 --> 00:03:25.630
And once that's done,
now we can start to remote manage it.

69
00:03:25.630 --> 00:03:29.660
Well, technically you could remote manage
it even before you installed the Server

70
00:03:29.660 --> 00:03:33.550
app because we just have remote
management built right into OS X.

71
00:03:33.550 --> 00:03:35.620
Right?
Let's kind of recap that real quick before

72
00:03:35.620 --> 00:03:37.410
we dive into the server specific stuff.

73
00:03:37.410 --> 00:03:40.450
So I've got a server pulled up here,
and let me get out of the Server app.

74
00:03:40.450 --> 00:03:42.130
So we're going to put ourselves
into our regular world.

75
00:03:43.190 --> 00:03:47.230
This is a, for the most part,
a stock install of Yosemite.

76
00:03:48.400 --> 00:03:50.860
I'm sorry, not Yosemite, El Capitan,
whatever version this is.

77
00:03:50.860 --> 00:03:53.490
And actually, now that I've said it, let
me make sure that this is El Capitan and

78
00:03:53.490 --> 00:03:55.060
I'm not leading us down the wrong path.

79
00:03:55.060 --> 00:03:55.940
Yeah, it is.
Okay.

80
00:03:55.940 --> 00:03:58.910
So this is a fairly stock install,
and I know it doesn't look normal.

81
00:03:58.910 --> 00:04:00.960
This is something that I
like to do on my servers.

82
00:04:00.960 --> 00:04:04.890
So when I set up a new server, I know that
I'm going to be remotely managing it.

83
00:04:04.890 --> 00:04:08.380
And when you remotely do
something like screen sharing, and

84
00:04:08.380 --> 00:04:12.420
you have that big El Capitan,
this wallpaper, right?

85
00:04:12.420 --> 00:04:15.080
It takes forever for
that to render on the screen.

86
00:04:15.080 --> 00:04:18.640
And sometimes if you have a really poor
VNC connection, you'll see the line going

87
00:04:18.640 --> 00:04:22.280
down the screen super slow, because it's
having to draw this rich background.

88
00:04:22.280 --> 00:04:25.630
So when I set up servers, one of the first
things I do is turn the background off and

89
00:04:25.630 --> 00:04:27.660
just go to a solid color, solid blue.

90
00:04:27.660 --> 00:04:29.600
Solid blue renders super fast in VNC.

91
00:04:30.680 --> 00:04:32.060
And then from there,

92
00:04:32.060 --> 00:04:36.310
I go down to my Dock and the Dock
normally has all this stuff in it, right?

93
00:04:36.310 --> 00:04:38.880
Photos, and Mail, and Contacts.

94
00:04:38.880 --> 00:04:42.250
I'm never gonna use any of that stuff on
this server, and so I remove that and

95
00:04:42.250 --> 00:04:44.250
I put the server stuff down there, right?

96
00:04:44.250 --> 00:04:46.620
Things that I will use,
like Network Utility and

97
00:04:46.620 --> 00:04:51.290
the Server app, Remote Desktop,
if I've got that installed, The App Store.

98
00:04:51.290 --> 00:04:53.050
These are things that I know I'll use.

99
00:04:53.050 --> 00:04:55.020
And now I've got a much
more simplified interface.

100
00:04:55.020 --> 00:04:56.790
It's a little more server like.

101
00:04:56.790 --> 00:05:00.550
But all I've really done is
installed the Server app.

102
00:05:00.550 --> 00:05:02.550
Now, ever if I hadn't
installed the Server app,

103
00:05:02.550 --> 00:05:04.250
we can use the Mac's remote
management features.

104
00:05:04.250 --> 00:05:08.180
If you go into system preferences,
inside of system preferences,

105
00:05:08.180 --> 00:05:12.190
you've got the Sharing utility,
or control panel.

106
00:05:12.190 --> 00:05:14.810
And if I go into that Sharing utility,

107
00:05:14.810 --> 00:05:17.780
right from here I can see
different things that I can share.

108
00:05:17.780 --> 00:05:21.650
And for remote management, there's
just a handful of these that matter.

109
00:05:21.650 --> 00:05:24.330
DVD or CD sharing,
that really doesn't apply here.

110
00:05:24.330 --> 00:05:28.760
That's not gonna help me remote manage
this system, but screen sharing will.

111
00:05:28.760 --> 00:05:34.170
If I can do screen sharing, then via
VNC I can connect over the network and

112
00:05:34.170 --> 00:05:35.820
view the screen of this system.

113
00:05:35.820 --> 00:05:37.580
I don't need the Server app for that.

114
00:05:37.580 --> 00:05:40.010
So that's the first way that
we can remote manage this.

115
00:05:40.010 --> 00:05:44.860
I might be deploying 100 Macs, and
I want all of them to be servers, but

116
00:05:44.860 --> 00:05:46.310
I haven't put the Server app on them yet.

117
00:05:46.310 --> 00:05:50.220
So I can turn on screen sharing,
and now I can VNC into them, and

118
00:05:50.220 --> 00:05:51.000
start to see them work.

119
00:05:51.000 --> 00:05:52.900
If you haven't used that before,
the system's really easy.

120
00:05:52.900 --> 00:05:53.860
Let me just show you.

121
00:05:53.860 --> 00:05:54.490

00:04:36.806 --> 00:04:42.840

00:04:57.506 --> 00:05:00.557

00:05:00.557 --> 00:05:03.056
This is the key that deciphers that.

00:05:03.056 --> 00:05:05.331
So a private key works that same way.

00:05:05.331 --> 00:05:08.826
If I have the private key,

But it's not a one to one mapping,

00:05:12.626 --> 00:05:16.282
It's actually one piece of

00:05:16.282 --> 00:05:20.910
And I can take the data and run it

00:05:20.910 --> 00:05:23.186
the output will be the unencoded or

00:05:23.186 --> 00:05:27.455
the plain text data that was

00:05:27.455 --> 00:05:29.026
So the key is really important.

00:05:29.026 --> 00:05:33.102
This private key, if somebody were

00:05:33.102 --> 00:05:36.568

00:05:36.568 --> 00:05:37.889
It's the keys to the kingdom.

99
00:05:37.889 --> 00:05:40.900
So this is very very sensitive.

100
00:05:40.900 --> 00:05:43.560
I don't want somebody

00:05:43.560 --> 00:05:46.730
Well, if a client is gonna

Well, if I know I'm gonna be doing this,

00:28:35.530 --> 00:28:37.540
Believe it or not,
Apple said you should trust Apple.

580
00:28:37.540 --> 00:28:39.240
And that was not too far of a stretch,
right?

581
00:28:39.240 --> 00:28:42.850
But we also see AddTrust, AffirmTrust,

582
00:28:42.850 --> 00:28:46.830
ANF Global,
I've never heard of any of those, right?

583
00:28:46.830 --> 00:28:50.700
As we keep looking, Belgium Root,
I've never been to Belgium.

584
00:28:50.700 --> 00:28:52.040
Buypass.

585
00:28:52.040 --> 00:28:53.070
Never heard of them.

586
00:28:53.070 --> 00:28:54.020
Certum.

587
00:28:54.020 --> 00:28:54.980
Cisco.
All right,

588
00:28:54.980 --> 00:28:57.730
there's the first one I've seen so
far that I recognize, and

589
00:28:57.730 --> 00:29:00.800
Cisco doesn't even sell public certs,
so that's kind of an odd one.

590
00:29:00.800 --> 00:29:02.880
But if we keep looking, there's DigiCert.

591
00:29:02.880 --> 00:29:04.880
I think I said earlier I like DigiCert.

592
00:29:04.880 --> 00:29:07.610
And so, you've got DigiCert right here,
all these different ones.

593
00:29:07.610 --> 00:29:11.060
So if somebody out there is using
a certificate that's signed by DigiCert,

594
00:29:11.060 --> 00:29:13.310
your Mac is going to trust it by default.

595
00:29:13.310 --> 00:29:16.230
And you can add in your own root.

596
00:29:16.230 --> 00:29:17.860
If you create your own
root you can add it here.

597
00:29:17.860 --> 00:29:20.410
If you create an open directory
that happens automatically.

598
00:29:20.410 --> 00:29:24.703
Your open directory server becomes
a CA and when people buy into the open

599
00:29:24.703 --> 00:29:31.510
directory, they'll copy the public key
to your CA and drop it right in here.

600
00:29:31.510 --> 00:29:34.570
So they'll trust it, and they'll have
that functionality, it'll be available.

601
00:29:34.570 --> 00:29:38.840
>> Now, Don, is it safe to say with
your explanation here, that Apple has

602
00:29:38.840 --> 00:29:42.540
done the work beforehand, they've
communicated with these CAs out here,

603
00:29:42.540 --> 00:29:45.540
they said okay,
we've established that you are secure.

604
00:29:45.540 --> 00:29:49.410
So what they've done is they've taken
those private keys, or the public keys,

605
00:29:49.410 --> 00:29:52.640
excuse me, and they've basically
embedded them into a protective location

606
00:29:52.640 --> 00:29:54.800
within the operating system itself?

607
00:29:54.800 --> 00:29:56.400
>> Yeah, that's basically it.

608
00:29:56.400 --> 00:29:57.770
It's a protected spot.

609
00:29:57.770 --> 00:30:00.330
A virus can't go in and
just start ejecting certificates, right.

610
00:30:00.330 --> 00:30:02.410
The key chain itself gets locked.

611
00:30:02.410 --> 00:30:04.945
And so when you log in with your
username and your password,

612
00:30:04.945 --> 00:30:07.290
you're unlocking that key chain for
your access.

613
00:30:07.290 --> 00:30:09.590
And when you log out,
the key chain is being locked again.

614
00:30:09.590 --> 00:30:11.120
It's being locked with an encryption key.

615
00:30:11.120 --> 00:30:13.660
And the encryption key is your password.

616
00:30:13.660 --> 00:30:16.720
If you ever change your password for
your user account,

617
00:30:16.720 --> 00:30:20.540
the password on the keychain has to be
changed also because it's now different.

618
00:30:20.540 --> 00:30:22.980
So that process happens when
you do a password reset, and

619
00:30:22.980 --> 00:30:26.040
that stops third party software
from tampering with your roots.

620
00:30:26.040 --> 00:30:30.090
If somebody could add an unauthorized
root cert to your list,

621
00:30:30.090 --> 00:30:31.760
who knows what you would trust from there.

622
00:30:31.760 --> 00:30:36.030
I mean you'd really compromise
security on a pretty widespread basis.

623
00:30:36.030 --> 00:30:36.674
Not a good thing.

624
00:30:36.674 --> 00:30:39.330
[LAUGH] So, I think is that a trademark?

625
00:30:39.330 --> 00:30:39.900
Not a good thing.

626
00:30:39.900 --> 00:30:42.200
So, but yeah,
those are basically the certificates.

627
00:30:42.200 --> 00:30:45.470
This is all happening behind the scenes,
it's really important to understand what's

628
00:30:45.470 --> 00:30:48.700
going on, even though we don't
really have to interact with it.

629
00:30:48.700 --> 00:30:51.500
You might choose to buy a public cert,
in which case you'll run through

630
00:30:51.500 --> 00:30:54.900
that wizard that I showed you and then
go out and buy the cert and load it in.

631
00:30:54.900 --> 00:30:56.820
You might just stick with self sign certs.

632
00:30:56.820 --> 00:31:00.210
And if you stick with self sign certs, you
don't have to do much to administer them.

633
00:31:00.210 --> 00:31:02.380
Let me just show you the one
thing you'll have to do.

634
00:31:02.380 --> 00:31:06.320
That self sign cert that was generated
on my system, it does expire.

635
00:31:06.320 --> 00:31:09.710
It expires a while from now, right?

636
00:31:09.710 --> 00:31:13.860
Every time you upgrade the server app
from one major version to another,

637
00:31:13.860 --> 00:31:15.910
it will update that certificate.

638
00:31:15.910 --> 00:31:19.660
But if you don't update your server app,
you might have an older certificate.

639
00:31:19.660 --> 00:31:21.770
If I take a look at my self signed one,

640
00:31:21.770 --> 00:31:25.080
it shows an expiration date of April 26,
2018.

641
00:31:25.080 --> 00:31:26.920
Okay, that's two years from now.

642
00:31:26.920 --> 00:31:29.060
So it made a two year certificate.

643
00:31:29.060 --> 00:31:33.650
Well, if I update to server version 6, a
year from now it'll renew that for me and

644
00:31:33.650 --> 00:31:34.920
I won't have to worry about it.

645
00:31:34.920 --> 00:31:39.820
But if I don't, if I'm still running
server version 5, come April 26,

646
00:31:39.820 --> 00:31:42.640
2018, this certificate will expire, right?

647
00:31:42.640 --> 00:31:43.740
So I need to renew it.

648
00:31:43.740 --> 00:31:45.510
And renewing it is pretty easy.

649
00:31:45.510 --> 00:31:48.610
You just double click on it and this
screen will pop up and you've got a nice

650
00:31:48.610 --> 00:31:52.320
little Renew button right here at
the bottom, and so you can hit Renew, and

651
00:31:52.320 --> 00:31:55.630
because it's a self signed certificate,
it just renews it and that's it.

652
00:31:55.630 --> 00:31:59.310
If it's a public certificate, when you hit
Renew, It's gonna have to reach out to

653
00:31:59.310 --> 00:32:01.210
that provider and
go through that renew process.

654
00:32:01.210 --> 00:32:04.770
So, you need to go to the provider's
website, update the cert, they'll generate

655
00:32:04.770 --> 00:32:07.860
a new key for you, and when you hit
Renew down here, you'll have to drag and

656
00:32:07.860 --> 00:32:11.210
drop that key onto it and now it's
updated, so a little bit different.

657
00:32:11.210 --> 00:32:15.470
But, once I hit this,
it's gonna renew and apparently,

658
00:32:15.470 --> 00:32:17.700
it's going to take it's time or
is there a window in the background?

659
00:32:17.700 --> 00:32:19.130
Nope, it's just taking it's time.

660
00:32:19.130 --> 00:32:21.210
But eventually it will renew and
update itself and

661
00:32:21.210 --> 00:32:24.970
then we'll be ready to rock and now it
will be good for two more years, right?.

662
00:32:24.970 --> 00:32:27.520
Not two years on the end of it,
but two years from today,

663
00:32:27.520 --> 00:32:32.330
which I guess it was already generated
today so I can't even tell now.

664
00:32:32.330 --> 00:32:35.410
It just launched it this morning I guess.

665
00:32:35.410 --> 00:32:37.960
But now it's renewed and
it's ready to go for another two years.

666
00:32:37.960 --> 00:32:40.830
That's really about it from
the maintenance side on the certificates.

667
00:32:40.830 --> 00:32:42.880
>> Very good,
a lot of great information in this one.

668
00:32:42.880 --> 00:32:45.110
A lot of security centric information Don.

669
00:32:45.110 --> 00:32:47.410
I appreciate you explaining all that.

670
00:32:47.410 --> 00:32:50.690
It does look like we are coming to
the end of another great episode here.

671
00:32:50.690 --> 00:32:53.375
So Don before we do,
any parting words of wisdom,

672
00:32:53.375 --> 00:32:55.550
especially on the certificate side?

673
00:32:55.550 --> 00:32:56.660
>> That's about it.

674
00:32:56.660 --> 00:32:58.650
Big, big important lesson.

675
00:32:58.650 --> 00:33:00.110
If you buy public certificates or

676
00:33:00.110 --> 00:33:04.660
even using the private ones, put their
expiration date on your calendar, right?

677
00:33:04.660 --> 00:33:06.670
Even big companies have made mistakes.

678
00:33:06.670 --> 00:33:09.150
Apple made a mistake just,
it was like a month ago.

679
00:33:09.150 --> 00:33:12.170
They let one of their
certificates expire and a ton of

680
00:33:12.170 --> 00:33:16.100
apps from the iOS app store couldn't run
anymore until they fixed that certificate.

681
00:33:16.100 --> 00:33:18.400
So even big companies make that mistake.

682
00:33:18.400 --> 00:33:20.590
It's so easy to avoid it.

683
00:33:20.590 --> 00:33:23.990
Anytime you buy a certificate put
the expiration date on your calendar.

684
00:33:23.990 --> 00:33:26.980
And what I normally do is set
up reminder two months ahead.

685
00:33:26.980 --> 00:33:30.990
And that way, I might buy two certificates
and I'll forget about the certificate.

686
00:33:30.990 --> 00:33:34.380
But 16 months from now,
or 20 months from now,

687
00:33:34.380 --> 00:33:37.860
whenever it is that you set it, you get a
reminder hey, you need to renew this cert.

688
00:33:37.860 --> 00:33:40.430
And that way you can plan for
renewing it and go through that process.

689
00:33:40.430 --> 00:33:42.390
Cuz renewals are not
necessarily immediate.

690
00:33:42.390 --> 00:33:45.600
Sometimes they can take a few days or
even a week to go through that process.

691
00:33:45.600 --> 00:33:48.820
So you don't wanna wait till it's expired,
you wanna do it ahead of time.

692
00:33:48.820 --> 00:33:50.370
Put it on your calendar.

693
00:33:50.370 --> 00:33:51.710
>> Thank you for that information, Don.

694
00:33:51.710 --> 00:33:53.880
And thank you to our viewers out there for
watching.

695
00:33:53.880 --> 00:33:56.390
We're gonna go ahead and
sign out here with ITProTV.

696
00:33:56.390 --> 00:33:57.490
I've been your host, Wes Bryan.

697
00:33:57.490 --> 00:33:58.510
>> And I'm Don Pezet.

698
00:33:58.510 --> 00:34:00.416
>> And we'll see you next time.

699
00:34:00.416 --> 00:34:08.350
[SOUND]

episodes.description: In this episode, Don describes the three primary methods for monitoring an OS X Server to ensure it is online and healthy. He covers logging for past monitoring, statistics for real-time monitoring, and alerts for future monitoring.
episodes.title: Monitoring
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.043 --> 00:00:10.043
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:12.145 --> 00:00:14.982
Welcome back to another exciting
episode here at ITPROTV.

3
00:00:14.982 --> 00:00:16.310
I'm your host, Wes Bryan.

4
00:00:16.310 --> 00:00:20.550
And in today's episode we are moving
along in our OSX Server Essentials.

5
00:00:20.550 --> 00:00:23.490
And we've got, back in the studios,
none other than Mr.Don Pizet.

6
00:00:23.490 --> 00:00:24.810
Welcome and how you doing, Don.

7
00:00:24.810 --> 00:00:25.838
>> I'm doing great, Wes.

8
00:00:25.838 --> 00:00:28.530
We're gonna dive right back
into OSX server essentials.

9
00:00:28.530 --> 00:00:31.690
And in this episode, we're gonna take a
look at something that's pretty important.

10
00:00:31.690 --> 00:00:33.930
And that's monitoring our server.

11
00:00:33.930 --> 00:00:37.250
We've seen in the earlier episodes,
getting the server app set-up.

12
00:00:37.250 --> 00:00:38.170
Pretty easy, right.

13
00:00:38.170 --> 00:00:39.660
You go to the app store, you install it.

14
00:00:39.660 --> 00:00:40.780
Getting it running.

15
00:00:40.780 --> 00:00:42.860
Pretty easy,
you just click on the button, right.

16
00:00:42.860 --> 00:00:43.890
Certificates.

17
00:00:43.890 --> 00:00:45.230
They're already configured for you.

18
00:00:45.230 --> 00:00:47.820
Most of what we do in
the server app is super easy.

19
00:00:47.820 --> 00:00:50.130
That's kind of Apple's claim to fame.

20
00:00:50.130 --> 00:00:52.400
And when things are working right,
that's great.

21
00:00:52.400 --> 00:00:55.000
It's nice and it's easy,
we can get this stuff in place.

22
00:00:55.000 --> 00:00:56.860
But from time to time things go wrong.

23
00:00:56.860 --> 00:00:58.490
Especially after upgrades.

24
00:00:58.490 --> 00:01:00.940
And so
if something goes wrong what do you do.

25
00:01:00.940 --> 00:01:03.140
There's no easy button
that says fix the problem.

26
00:01:03.140 --> 00:01:05.280
So you've got to find the problem and

27
00:01:05.280 --> 00:01:09.410
resolve it and fortunately apple gives us
a lot of tools to be able to monitor and

28
00:01:09.410 --> 00:01:12.200
maintain our server right
from within the server app.

29
00:01:12.200 --> 00:01:15.170
And that's important because we've
got to ton of troubleshooting tools

30
00:01:15.170 --> 00:01:17.000
outside of the server app, right.

31
00:01:17.000 --> 00:01:20.650
But if you're managing a system remotely
you might not have access to all of that.

32
00:01:20.650 --> 00:01:25.110
So if I'm on a work station and
I'm SSHed into a system or

33
00:01:25.110 --> 00:01:29.380
if I'm VNC to see the screen that's
great I have access to that stuff.

34
00:01:29.380 --> 00:01:32.530
But if all I have is the server
app I need tools and

35
00:01:32.530 --> 00:01:35.820
resources in the server app
to be able to manage it.

36
00:01:35.820 --> 00:01:37.030
And we've actually got quite a few.

37
00:01:37.030 --> 00:01:39.580
So let's walk through what we've got here.

38
00:01:39.580 --> 00:01:42.750
So I'm on my server and I've just
kind of launched into my server app.

39
00:01:42.750 --> 00:01:45.480
And this is that main default screen
where it gives you some basic

40
00:01:45.480 --> 00:01:48.000
information about the system and so on.

41
00:01:48.000 --> 00:01:52.410
And you get a quick health check
right here on your main screen.

42
00:01:52.410 --> 00:01:53.720
See these three green dots.

43
00:01:53.720 --> 00:01:56.400
It doesn't matter that I really
don't have any services running.

44
00:01:56.400 --> 00:01:58.910
I have file sharing and DNS I guess.

45
00:01:58.910 --> 00:02:00.720
But, here's some quick dots.

46
00:02:00.720 --> 00:02:03.850
And what these are telling us is first,
do I have a valid host name.

47
00:02:03.850 --> 00:02:06.670
Well, you pretty much always have
a valid host name unless there's

48
00:02:06.670 --> 00:02:09.400
a duplicate on the network, so
you'll normally have a green dot there.

49
00:02:09.400 --> 00:02:10.750
Then, my computer name.

50
00:02:10.750 --> 00:02:13.250
Now notice how my host name and
my computer name are different.

51
00:02:13.250 --> 00:02:16.950
The host name It's a fully
qualified domain name and

52
00:02:16.950 --> 00:02:22.144
my is called OSX-SERVER01.local,
that's fine in a local network but

53
00:02:22.144 --> 00:02:25.320
if this one is gonna be exposed to
the internet, that might be a problem,

54
00:02:25.320 --> 00:02:28.630
might need to adjust that and change it,
that's gonna be an issue right.

55
00:02:28.630 --> 00:02:32.900
But I have my green dots which says at
least as it is right now, it works and

56
00:02:32.900 --> 00:02:34.580
the next one is internet.

57
00:02:34.580 --> 00:02:36.800
If this is a local server,
I don't care about this.

58
00:02:36.800 --> 00:02:38.840
But if I'm connected to the internet,
I do.

59
00:02:38.840 --> 00:02:41.840
This one is reachable at 209.251.159.179,
that's my public IP and

60
00:02:41.840 --> 00:02:46.320
I can get on the Internet so
I got a green light.

61
00:02:46.320 --> 00:02:48.705
But it tells me no services available.

62
00:02:48.705 --> 00:02:50.820
What the heck does that mean.

63
00:02:50.820 --> 00:02:54.570
No services,
well I have File Sharing turned on.

64
00:02:54.570 --> 00:02:56.620
And I have DNS turned on.

65
00:02:56.620 --> 00:02:58.910
Shouldn't this say those are available.

66
00:02:58.910 --> 00:03:02.070
Well, here at the ITProTV
studios we have a firewall.

67
00:03:02.070 --> 00:03:06.450
And the firewalls blocking outside
people from getting to this system.

68
00:03:06.450 --> 00:03:08.570
And so it's showing no services available.

69
00:03:08.570 --> 00:03:11.860
So even though I've got a green light,
my server can get to the internet.

70
00:03:11.860 --> 00:03:12.940
And I've got a public IP.

71
00:03:14.230 --> 00:03:16.670
I have no services available because
the firewall is blocking it.

72
00:03:16.670 --> 00:03:21.650
So I can use this to quickly tell whether
or not internet access is possible, right.

73
00:03:21.650 --> 00:03:23.910
If I'm not doing internet access,
I don't care about that.

74
00:03:23.910 --> 00:03:27.080
And so that's why the light's green even
though it says no services available.

75
00:03:27.080 --> 00:03:30.190
Apple knows that this is
a very common set up.

76
00:03:30.190 --> 00:03:32.390
But its one quick place
that you can look and

77
00:03:32.390 --> 00:03:36.420
you can go into reachability details
To get a quick breakdown on that.

78
00:03:36.420 --> 00:03:39.190
So I can see that my status is enabled.

79
00:03:39.190 --> 00:03:40.220
I've got that external IP.

80
00:03:40.220 --> 00:03:43.110
I don't have a public host
name cuz I didn't set it and

81
00:03:43.110 --> 00:03:44.870
none of my services are available.

82
00:03:44.870 --> 00:03:48.200
If I'm not gonna use internet access,
I'm just gonna hit disable.

83
00:03:48.200 --> 00:03:50.550
And we can turn off internet reachabilty,
right.

84
00:03:50.550 --> 00:03:54.530
When I do that,
now I'm just a local server, right.

85
00:03:54.530 --> 00:03:56.440
And reachability is unknown.

86
00:03:56.440 --> 00:03:59.650
Most of the time when you deploy a server,
you just wanted to be local.

87
00:03:59.650 --> 00:04:02.640
And unless you setting up a web server and
you want that to be public.

88
00:04:02.640 --> 00:04:04.630
So might want to disable this test,

89
00:04:04.630 --> 00:04:09.080
no sense in this thing testing it every
time if I'm not actually gonna use it.

90
00:04:09.080 --> 00:04:09.770
All right.
So

91
00:04:09.770 --> 00:04:12.950
that's one example of a quick thing that
we can monitor right here from the inside

92
00:04:12.950 --> 00:04:13.960
of the server App.

93
00:04:13.960 --> 00:04:17.170
Let's take a look and what I think
is probably the most important one.

94
00:04:17.170 --> 00:04:18.720
And that's our logs.

95
00:04:18.720 --> 00:04:24.390
If you went through our ACA shows, or even
the ACSP show, I talked about logs and

96
00:04:24.390 --> 00:04:27.780
how we can maintain them, and
in those shows we use the Console app.

97
00:04:27.780 --> 00:04:32.430
So if you launch Console, you can see
the system logs for your computer.

98
00:04:33.930 --> 00:04:35.940
Your server app is logging to this.

99
00:04:36.950 --> 00:04:40.450
The only problem is, your server app
isn't the only thing logging into this.

100
00:04:40.450 --> 00:04:42.460
You're going to have your
own operating system and

101
00:04:42.460 --> 00:04:45.030
all sorts of other applications
all logging in here too.

102
00:04:45.030 --> 00:04:47.320
So it gets really cluttered, right.

103
00:04:47.320 --> 00:04:50.260
There's just a lot of stuff in here
that doesn't necessarily pertain

104
00:04:50.260 --> 00:04:51.580
to the server app.

105
00:04:51.580 --> 00:04:53.290
And if I'm monitoring remotely.

106
00:04:53.290 --> 00:04:58.320
So for example if I'm over here on
some work station like this one, And

00:27:05.070 --> 00:27:09.490
So now I know that it crashed and
what I need to do to fix it, right?

561
00:27:10.490 --> 00:27:13.040
If I don't introduce more than 25 GB,
it's just gonna crash again.

562
00:27:13.040 --> 00:27:16.990
And I've got these two little
arrows down here where I can move

563
00:27:16.990 --> 00:27:20.920
forward to the next alert,
the next alert were the software updates.

564
00:27:20.920 --> 00:27:23.860
I've got two software updates available,
one for a digital camera,

565
00:27:23.860 --> 00:27:29.378
better rush on that one, but
the other one, OS 10 El Capitan 10.11.4.

566
00:27:29.378 --> 00:27:30.390
I'm running 10.11.3.

567
00:27:30.390 --> 00:27:32.480
I probably need to do an update.

568
00:27:32.480 --> 00:27:36.050
I bet there's some security updates rolled
into that one, I need to go find out.

569
00:27:36.050 --> 00:27:39.350
Research the update, find out if
you need it and then deploy it.

570
00:27:39.350 --> 00:27:43.060
But once you do the update,
you need to come in and clear these and so

571
00:27:43.060 --> 00:27:49.020
I'm gonna clear all the alerts and now the
little bubble goes away on my server icon.

572
00:27:49.020 --> 00:27:50.680
And now we're free and clear.

573
00:27:50.680 --> 00:27:54.300
But if I try and start that caching
service again, I'm gonna start it.

574
00:27:54.300 --> 00:27:55.140
It's just gonna crash again.

575
00:27:55.140 --> 00:27:56.110
Doesn't have enough space.

576
00:27:56.110 --> 00:27:57.390
There it goes.
Crashes, right?

577
00:27:57.390 --> 00:27:58.240
It's not really crashing.

578
00:27:58.240 --> 00:27:59.180
It's exiting cleanly.

579
00:27:59.180 --> 00:28:00.990
It just doesn't have enough space.

580
00:28:00.990 --> 00:28:05.070
And in a few moments,
the alert will come up.

581
00:28:05.070 --> 00:28:08.580
Now, it's kinda funny because I
just got the alert on my watch.

582
00:28:08.580 --> 00:28:12.180
I got the alert before it showed
up here in the server app.

583
00:28:12.180 --> 00:28:13.320
Why is that?

584
00:28:13.320 --> 00:28:19.015
Well, little unknown fact, but the server
app, it doesn't refresh itself, ever.

585
00:28:19.015 --> 00:28:22.440
[LAUGH] It's really up
to you to refresh it.

586
00:28:22.440 --> 00:28:26.280
Normally when you move between apps,
that causes a refresh.

587
00:28:26.280 --> 00:28:28.980
But if I just sitting here,
staring at the screen.

588
00:28:28.980 --> 00:28:30.140
It doesn't refresh.

589
00:28:30.140 --> 00:28:32.180
So you can refresh it manually.

590
00:28:32.180 --> 00:28:35.190
It's buried up here in the menu somewhere,
view I think?

591
00:28:35.190 --> 00:28:36.590
Yeah, you can do view and refresh.

592
00:28:36.590 --> 00:28:38.090
Or you can do Cmd+R.

593
00:28:38.090 --> 00:28:40.270
And if I do a Cmd+ R,
that'll cause a refresh, and

594
00:28:40.270 --> 00:28:41.310
normally it'll find the alert.

595
00:28:41.310 --> 00:28:42.200
It didn't.

596
00:28:42.200 --> 00:28:43.829
Is this ever gonna refresh?

597
00:28:45.290 --> 00:28:47.060
All right,
well apparently it's not gonna refresh.

598
00:28:47.060 --> 00:28:50.160
But I did get my letter via email and
I got my push notification,

599
00:28:50.160 --> 00:28:51.180
it's going off again.

600
00:28:51.180 --> 00:28:53.160
So I'm getting those alerts.

601
00:28:53.160 --> 00:28:56.660
Just be aware that the screen
doesn't refresh, or

602
00:28:56.660 --> 00:28:58.330
at least it doesn't refresh very well.

603
00:28:58.330 --> 00:29:01.670
You can force it if I just exit
the server app, and go back into it.

604
00:29:01.670 --> 00:29:04.970
Eventually it will get it, but
obviously that's not very timely, right?

605
00:29:04.970 --> 00:29:08.920
So that's another example of why we
would wanna set up those pushes so

606
00:29:08.920 --> 00:29:10.980
that we get those alert messages.

607
00:29:10.980 --> 00:29:14.910
Because I'm still not getting
that stinking alert in here.

608
00:29:14.910 --> 00:29:16.330
That's a problem, right?

609
00:29:16.330 --> 00:29:17.520
You don't wanna rely on this.

610
00:29:17.520 --> 00:29:20.280
It's too easy to overlook, and it's slow.

611
00:29:20.280 --> 00:29:22.680
Set up email, set up the push alerts,

612
00:29:22.680 --> 00:29:25.670
and when you're done with an alert,
make sure you clear it out.

613
00:29:25.670 --> 00:29:28.300
If it ever shows up on this dumb thing.

614
00:29:28.300 --> 00:29:31.120
Then make sure you clear it out,
otherwise the alert stays there.

615
00:29:31.120 --> 00:29:31.970
It stays there forever, and

616
00:29:31.970 --> 00:29:34.978
you can get more than one person working
on the problem, you've already handled it,

617
00:29:34.978 --> 00:29:36.190
wipe it out.

618
00:29:36.190 --> 00:29:40.110
>> Great information, and now we get
to go clear out notifications for

619
00:29:40.110 --> 00:29:44.540
about 50 of the different devices that
are scattered through the ITProTV studios.

620
00:29:44.540 --> 00:29:46.660
But until we get that done,

621
00:29:46.660 --> 00:29:48.830
it does look like we're coming
to the end of another episode.

622
00:29:48.830 --> 00:29:52.740
So we're gonna go ahead and we're gonna
take this time to sign out for ITProTV.

623
00:29:52.740 --> 00:29:54.040
I've been your host Wes Bryan.

624
00:29:54.040 --> 00:29:55.023
>> And I'm Don Pizzet.

625
00:29:55.023 --> 00:29:56.819
>> And we'll see you next time.

626
00:29:56.819 --> 00:29:58.957
[MUSIC]

episodes.description: In this episode Wes and Don take a look at how to keep Mac OS X Server up and running through common maintenance procedures. They demonstrate how to keep the base Mac OS X operating system up-to-date as well as the Server App. They will also explore the world of backups through Time Machine and how to ensure that service data on a separate drive can be included in the backup, and data that will be excluded during a backup operation
episodes.title: OS X Maintenance
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.000 --> 00:00:10.000
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:12.232 --> 00:00:15.126
Welcome back to another exciting
episode here at ITProTV.

3
00:00:15.126 --> 00:00:16.556
I'm your host Wes Bryan, and

4
00:00:16.556 --> 00:00:20.401
in today's episode we're gonna be moving
along in our OS X Server Essentials.

5
00:00:20.401 --> 00:00:23.210
And we got none other than Mr.
Don Pezet on hand to help us out.

6
00:00:23.210 --> 00:00:24.220
Don, how you doing sir?

7
00:00:24.220 --> 00:00:28.090
>> I am doing great Wes, ready to jump
right back into the world of OS X Server,

8
00:00:28.090 --> 00:00:31.510
and in this episode, we're gonna
take a look at server maintenance.

9
00:00:31.510 --> 00:00:34.520
Once you get your server up and running,
you guys have seen the earlier episodes,

10
00:00:34.520 --> 00:00:35.610
it's really not that hard.

11
00:00:35.610 --> 00:00:38.850
Get the server app in place,
and turn on a few services.

12
00:00:38.850 --> 00:00:40.590
Once that's done it starts to run.

13
00:00:40.590 --> 00:00:43.500
And hopefully things just run great,
and for

14
00:00:43.500 --> 00:00:45.350
the most part,
you can kind of forget about it.

15
00:00:45.350 --> 00:00:48.640
You just set the server up, and
you walk away, and now it does it's thing.

16
00:00:48.640 --> 00:00:52.520
But from time to time, we do need to step
in and take a few kind of maintenance

17
00:00:52.520 --> 00:00:58.220
activities, just to make sure that our
server stay safe, secure, and intact.

18
00:00:58.220 --> 00:01:02.190
If we ever had a hardware failure,
or a compromise,

19
00:01:02.190 --> 00:01:04.960
a virus, something like that, we need
to be able to recover from that, and

20
00:01:04.960 --> 00:01:06.630
make sure that our system stays intact.

21
00:01:06.630 --> 00:01:09.863
And so these are the maintenance
activities that we need to be performing.

22
00:01:09.863 --> 00:01:13.444
A lot of people don't do these, a lot of
people kind of shirk the maintenance side

23
00:01:13.444 --> 00:01:16.740
and say, well it's an Apple product,
you just turn it on and it'll run.

24
00:01:16.740 --> 00:01:20.190
And that's true, it'll run just fine,
right up until the part where it doesn't.

25
00:01:20.190 --> 00:01:22.480
And that's when you need to have
that maintenance in place and

26
00:01:22.480 --> 00:01:28.300
it doesn't matter how much effort Apple
puts into OS X, hard drives fail.

27
00:01:28.300 --> 00:01:30.060
Apple doesn't make hard drives, right.

28
00:01:30.060 --> 00:01:33.470
So you have hard drive failures,
you've got to be prepared for that.

29
00:01:33.470 --> 00:01:37.150
You have things like security exploits and
vulnerabilities that come out.

30
00:01:37.150 --> 00:01:40.237
Apple patches those,
they do a great job of patching them,

31
00:01:40.237 --> 00:01:43.898
but do you do a great job about
updating and installing those patches?

32
00:01:43.898 --> 00:01:44.965
A lot of people don't.

33
00:01:44.965 --> 00:01:48.777
So as a system's administrator, as
somebody who's administering OS X servers

34
00:01:48.777 --> 00:01:52.149
in the workplace, you need to be
making sure you update these systems.

35
00:01:52.149 --> 00:01:55.186
And so that's what we're gonna to
take a look here in this episode,

36
00:01:55.186 --> 00:01:56.212
updates and backups.

37
00:01:56.212 --> 00:01:58.952
All right,
well let's kick things off with updates.

38
00:01:58.952 --> 00:02:01.956
I wanna start with updates because
they are so important, and they're so

39
00:02:01.956 --> 00:02:03.360
easy to overlook.

40
00:02:03.360 --> 00:02:08.870
When you install Mac OS X, right,
when you get El Capitan fired up for

41
00:02:08.870 --> 00:02:15.148
the first time, automatic updates
are sort of enabled, sort of not enabled.

42
00:02:15.148 --> 00:02:16.913
All right,
now what the heck do I mean by that?

43
00:02:16.913 --> 00:02:17.771
Well, let me show you here.

44
00:02:17.771 --> 00:02:19.965
So, I've got this server.

45
00:02:19.965 --> 00:02:23.920
This is a stock install of El Capitan.

46
00:02:23.920 --> 00:02:26.900
And all I've done is change my wallpaper
and removed some stuff from the dock down

47
00:02:26.900 --> 00:02:31.350
here, and I installed the server app,
and that's about it, okay.

48
00:02:31.350 --> 00:02:37.233
Well, when I installed this,
it's running El Capitan 10.11.3.

49
00:02:37.233 --> 00:02:41.613
I know 10.11.4 is out okay, I know
it's out, it's been out for weeks now,

50
00:02:41.613 --> 00:02:44.190
this system doesn't have it.

51
00:02:44.190 --> 00:02:47.240
Well, doesn't the system
automatically upgrade?

52
00:02:47.240 --> 00:02:48.630
No, no it doesn't.

53
00:02:48.630 --> 00:02:52.890
It's prompted me a few times, but
because of the show I just ignored it.

54
00:02:52.890 --> 00:02:54.160
Not now, or maybe later.

55
00:02:54.160 --> 00:02:56.760
Right, a lot of people do that,
like I'll come back and I'll do it later.

56
00:02:56.760 --> 00:02:57.970
And then what do we do?

57
00:02:57.970 --> 00:02:58.894
We don't come back and do it later right?

58
00:02:58.894 --> 00:03:01.750
[LAUGH] It just kind of gets forgotten and
put by the wayside.

59
00:03:01.750 --> 00:03:06.649
So at this stage, the only even hint
that there's an update out there

60
00:03:06.649 --> 00:03:11.640
is right in the server app under Alerts,
I've got an alert.

61
00:03:11.640 --> 00:03:13.230
And if I look at that alert,

62
00:03:13.230 --> 00:03:17.320
it's altering me that there's two
software updates available, okay.

63
00:03:17.320 --> 00:03:21.258
One of those is gonna be the 10.11.4
update, cuz I know that's out there.

64
00:03:21.258 --> 00:03:23.522
Actually don't know what the other one is,
let's find out.

65
00:03:23.522 --> 00:03:26.131
So if I double-click on that
it'll tell me what we've got and

66
00:03:26.131 --> 00:03:29.178
you know we saw this in the show the other
day, I should have remembered that.

67
00:03:29.178 --> 00:03:33.351
That there is the 10.11.4, but there's
also some kind of digital camera update,,

68
00:03:33.351 --> 00:03:35.770
because I'm a laptop and
I've got a digital camera.

69
00:03:35.770 --> 00:03:37.580
So, it's got an update for that.

70
00:03:37.580 --> 00:03:42.155
I don't necessarily care about the camera
update, that's probably not gonna help me,

71
00:03:42.155 --> 00:03:44.907
but 10.11.4,
I probably do care about that.

72
00:03:44.907 --> 00:03:46.939
I probably wanna learn a little
more about that update.

73
00:03:46.939 --> 00:03:48.738
I can get it rolled out my environment.

74
00:03:48.738 --> 00:03:53.093
>> Don, you had showed us in a previous
episode that sometimes when we do updates,

75
00:03:53.093 --> 00:03:56.996
we've got our base operating system and
we have the server app itself.

76
00:03:56.996 --> 00:03:58.611
So are we looking at a single update,

77
00:03:58.611 --> 00:04:01.384
are we looking at maybe a couple
of different types of updates?

78
00:04:01.384 --> 00:04:05.218
>> It's really a couple of different ones,
and that base OS part is important because

79
00:04:05.218 --> 00:04:09.075
these updates that it's showing here,
those weren't updates to the server app.

80
00:04:09.075 --> 00:04:12.380
Those are updates to the OS,
not the server app, right.

81
00:04:12.380 --> 00:04:14.770
And so they're showing up in the server
app because I've got it installed, but

82
00:04:14.770 --> 00:04:17.180
even if I didn't have
the server app installed,

83
00:04:17.180 --> 00:04:20.090
those updates would still be available and
needed for my system.

84
00:04:20.090 --> 00:04:24.180
If you go into your System Preferences and
in your System Preferences,

85
00:04:24.180 --> 00:04:28.780
you can go into
the App Store System Panel, right?

86
00:04:28.780 --> 00:04:30.699
So this Preference panel right here.

87
00:04:30.699 --> 00:04:32.933
And I know this seems weird
to go to App Store, but

88
00:04:32.933 --> 00:04:35.560
all the Apple updates roll out
through the App Store now.

89
00:04:35.560 --> 00:04:36.640
That's the way they handle that.

90
00:04:36.640 --> 00:04:38.050
And when you go into the App Store,

91
00:04:38.050 --> 00:04:40.710
you'll see how your automatic
settings are configured.

92
00:04:40.710 --> 00:04:44.220
And this is kinda the default, that we're
set to automatically check for updates.

93
00:04:44.220 --> 00:04:46.780
It will look to see if
an update is out there.

94
00:04:46.780 --> 00:04:49.560
It'll download the update
in the background.

95
00:04:49.560 --> 00:04:52.650
So when an update comes out, it's
actually gonna download it from Apple and

96
00:04:52.650 --> 00:04:54.170
put it on your hard drive.

97
00:04:54.170 --> 00:04:59.606
It will install app updates, so if you
have Safari, it needs an update, or if

98
00:04:59.606 --> 00:05:05.732
Pages, one of those other programs needs
an update, it'll go ahead and update that.

99
00:05:05.732 --> 00:05:06.939
But look at this guy.

100
00:05:06.939 --> 00:05:09.780
Install OS X updates, it's not checked.

101
00:05:09.780 --> 00:05:14.558
It will download the OS X updates,
but it won't install it automatically.

102
00:05:14.558 --> 00:05:16.510
That means that if I don't come here and

103
00:05:16.510 --> 00:05:19.850
do the updates myself,
the server is never gonna get updated.

104
00:05:19.850 --> 00:05:23.436
And a year from now,
it will still be running 10.11.3.

105
00:05:23.436 --> 00:05:25.906
Even though 10.11.4 has
been downloaded and

106
00:05:25.906 --> 00:05:29.060
sitting right there onto the hard drive,
it doesn't install it.

107
00:05:29.060 --> 00:05:31.810
Now, you might be tempted to go ahead and
check that.

108
00:05:31.810 --> 00:05:35.450
And I'll tell you be careful with that,
because you don't necessarily want

109
00:05:35.450 --> 00:05:37.890
to automatically roll
out updates to a server.

110
00:05:37.890 --> 00:05:39.750
To a workstation is one thing, right?

111
00:05:39.750 --> 00:05:44.110
If my laptop takes an update and
has to reboot, it bothers me.

112
00:05:44.110 --> 00:05:46.053
What about everybody else in the company?

113
00:05:46.053 --> 00:05:46.797
It doesn't bother them.

114
00:05:46.797 --> 00:05:48.240
Right, it's my laptop, it's my problem.

115
00:05:48.240 --> 00:05:51.490
So it doesn't affect them,
it's just my system.

116
00:05:51.490 --> 00:05:55.870
But on a server, let's say it's an open
directory server, it goes to reboot and

117
00:05:55.870 --> 00:05:57.720
now nobody can log in on the network.

118
00:05:57.720 --> 00:06:01.380
Now my entire company is inconvenienced
while that server reboots.

119
00:06:01.380 --> 00:06:03.630
And what if the update breaks something?

120
00:06:03.630 --> 00:06:06.170
What if I've got educational
software running on that server and

121
00:06:06.170 --> 00:06:08.130
the update applies,
now the software doesn't run.

122
00:06:08.130 --> 00:06:10.940
Now all the students can't
get into that software.

123
00:06:10.940 --> 00:06:12.318
That's a problem.

124
00:06:12.318 --> 00:06:15.750
Servers, we wanna get much more involved
in the update process than we do on

125
00:06:15.750 --> 00:06:16.960
workstations.

126
00:06:16.960 --> 00:06:22.400
And so the recommendation is to
not use Apple's update service.

127
00:06:22.400 --> 00:06:25.550
With Apple's update service, they wanna
roll you updates as fast as they can.

128
00:06:25.550 --> 00:06:28.132
As soon as they come out, they wanna
get it to you and get it installed.

129
00:06:28.132 --> 00:06:31.965
Right, but instead,
you should setup your own update server.

130
00:06:31.965 --> 00:06:34.299
And setting up your own update
server's really pretty easy.

131
00:06:34.299 --> 00:06:35.366
Let me walk you through the process.

132
00:06:35.366 --> 00:06:38.480
I know at this point you guys
should have completed ACA Shows and

133
00:06:38.480 --> 00:06:40.960
we covered it in there
in integrator depth.

134
00:06:40.960 --> 00:06:42.860
But just to run through it quickly here.

135
00:06:42.860 --> 00:06:44.630
You can set up your own
software update server.

136
00:06:44.630 --> 00:06:48.185
And what will happen is you'll
download the updates from Apple and

137
00:06:48.185 --> 00:06:49.526
then you'll hold them.

138
00:06:49.526 --> 00:06:54.426
And then you can choose what updates to
approve and what updates not to approve.

139
00:06:54.426 --> 00:06:58.271
And so, you might roll some updates out to
a couple of test servers to make sure that

140
00:06:58.271 --> 00:06:59.510
things work.

141
00:06:59.510 --> 00:07:02.316
And then roll it out to the rest of
your servers, but you need that control.

142
00:07:02.316 --> 00:07:05.057
You don't get that control when
you're using Apple's update servers.

143
00:07:05.057 --> 00:07:06.682
They just roll everything out to you.

144
00:07:06.682 --> 00:07:09.140
If you want control, you've got
to set up your own update server.

145
00:07:09.140 --> 00:07:12.684
>> Now Don, you said don't
automatically install these updates.

146
00:07:12.684 --> 00:07:14.965
I'd forget my head if it wasn't attached,
so

147
00:07:14.965 --> 00:07:18.941
would you advise maybe having some sort
of patch management system or solution,

148
00:07:18.941 --> 00:07:22.880
where these things can be reviewed,
they can be submitted and approved?

149
00:07:22.880 --> 00:07:23.655
>> Yeah, absolutely.

150
00:07:23.655 --> 00:07:26.830
You've gotta take an active hand in this,
so you need a group of people,

151
00:07:26.830 --> 00:07:30.410
you need a group of test computers that
you can roll these updates out to.

152
00:07:30.410 --> 00:07:33.800
Different people can test it out and make
sure all the functionality is still valid,

153
00:07:33.800 --> 00:07:36.440
and if it is,
then roll it out to the masses, right?

154
00:07:36.440 --> 00:07:39.360
And you can do that with the software
update that were built right into

155
00:07:39.360 --> 00:07:41.060
