608
00:29:34.150 --> 00:29:37.420
And not only will it type it out, it will
put those slashes in the file name for

609
00:29:37.420 --> 00:29:38.660
me so that I don't have to worry about it.

610
00:29:38.660 --> 00:29:40.530
So I'm going to use that
a lot here on the show.

611
00:29:40.530 --> 00:29:43.880
And in real life, I use it too so
I don't forget those slashes, right?

612
00:29:43.880 --> 00:29:48.341
So as I go through here, I'm gonna
change into /Volumes/Time\ Machine and

613
00:29:48.341 --> 00:29:53.142
on the Time Machine drive, there's really
only one folder, Backups.backupdb,

614
00:29:53.142 --> 00:29:57.219
and I know that sounds like a database,
but it's really just a folder.

615
00:29:57.219 --> 00:30:00.180
So, if I change into that folder,
I can see my backups.

616
00:30:00.180 --> 00:30:02.650
Well, I get permission denied.

617
00:30:02.650 --> 00:30:04.360
Okay, why is that?

618
00:30:04.360 --> 00:30:07.510
Well, only administrators can get
into the backup on this drive.

619
00:30:07.510 --> 00:30:10.800
If it were a removable drive,
it would have that, ignore ownership, and

620
00:30:10.800 --> 00:30:15.130
it wouldn't care but on my local drive,
I'm not ignoring ownership.

621
00:30:15.130 --> 00:30:18.030
It's got an owner, and the owner's
the administrator of the system.

622
00:30:18.030 --> 00:30:19.100
And so, I need to be an administrator.

623
00:30:19.100 --> 00:30:22.310
So I'm gonna have to use the sudo
command to kind of manipulate it, and

624
00:30:22.310 --> 00:30:25.980
work with this stuff, or I'm gonna
have to go and change the permissions,

625
00:30:25.980 --> 00:30:29.070
to be able to break into it,
which we don't want to have to do.

626
00:30:29.070 --> 00:30:33.970
But the data is in there,
we just can't necessarily see it, right?

627
00:30:33.970 --> 00:30:40.480
So if I do a sudo of that list command and

628
00:30:40.480 --> 00:30:44.700
go to look in there, you'll see
that I'm able to see in there and

629
00:30:44.700 --> 00:30:48.790
in there is my server name OSX-SERVER01,
right?

630
00:30:48.790 --> 00:30:50.540
And so I can see that.

631
00:30:50.540 --> 00:30:52.784
And then if I wanna look inside of that,

632
00:30:52.784 --> 00:30:59.260
then I can see there's a backup and
the backup is in progress, right.

633
00:30:59.260 --> 00:31:02.930
So until the backup is done,
I can't really restore it.

634
00:31:02.930 --> 00:31:09.520
But let me show you the command as
it would be and let me change this

635
00:31:11.880 --> 00:31:16.680
prompt a little bit so
I have just a little more room.

636
00:31:16.680 --> 00:31:18.340
Shoot, that's not right.

637
00:31:18.340 --> 00:31:21.960
I need to do something like this.

638
00:31:21.960 --> 00:31:26.160
I just tried to get a little
more screen real estate.

639
00:31:26.160 --> 00:31:27.560
Shoot, that's not working either.

640
00:31:27.560 --> 00:31:28.450
Well let's see.

641
00:31:28.450 --> 00:31:28.990
You know what?

642
00:31:28.990 --> 00:31:30.660
I'd better use V, all capital.

643
00:31:30.660 --> 00:31:31.810
Let me just bump that up.

644
00:31:31.810 --> 00:31:32.760
And there we are.

645
00:31:32.760 --> 00:31:35.450
I just needed a smaller prompt to get
this whole command on the screen.

646
00:31:35.450 --> 00:31:38.460
So the command that you're
gonna run is tmutil, right?

647
00:31:38.460 --> 00:31:40.770
That's the time machine utility and

648
00:31:40.770 --> 00:31:44.540
I need the sudo this thing to make
sure it's gonna run properly right.

649
00:31:44.540 --> 00:31:48.462
I need to run it as administrator and
so it's gonna be tmutil and

650
00:31:48.462 --> 00:31:51.423
then I need to tell that I'm restoring,
okay.

651
00:31:51.423 --> 00:31:55.022
And I almost always use the -v option
on this one so I get verbose output,

652
00:31:55.022 --> 00:31:56.803
if I can see if there's any errors.

653
00:31:56.803 --> 00:31:59.455
And then I need to tell it where
the data's coming from And

654
00:31:59.455 --> 00:32:00.789
where the data's going to.

655
00:32:00.789 --> 00:32:04.913
And the front part is the hard part,
I normally change directories into where

656
00:32:04.913 --> 00:32:08.030
the backup is so
I don't have to specify a giant path here.

657
00:32:08.030 --> 00:32:12.940
I can actually just say ./* which says,
the source is everything in this

658
00:32:12.940 --> 00:32:15.700
directory, but if I'm running it
from outside of the directory,

659
00:32:15.700 --> 00:32:19.530
like I am here,
then what I can do is I can just specify.

660
00:32:19.530 --> 00:32:25.728
It'd be /Volumes/Time/
Machine/Backups.backupdb/ and

661
00:32:25.728 --> 00:32:28.660
then you have the server name.

662
00:32:28.660 --> 00:32:31.835
And I'm gonna screen
wrap a bit on this one.

663
00:32:31.835 --> 00:32:35.140
/Latest is what we normally want, right,

664
00:32:35.140 --> 00:32:37.670
that would be the last
backup that it took.

665
00:32:37.670 --> 00:32:40.940
And I don't have a latest right now
because my backup is currently running.

666
00:32:40.940 --> 00:32:42.899
So I'll just say, /Latest.

667
00:32:42.899 --> 00:32:46.201
And then from there, we need,

668
00:32:46.201 --> 00:32:51.470
let's see, /Latest and then, the volume.

669
00:32:51.470 --> 00:32:53.500
So here's where it gets
a little bit weird,

670
00:32:53.500 --> 00:32:55.190
because we have to specify
the start up volume.

671
00:32:55.190 --> 00:33:02.195
And the start up volume,
in my case is Macintosh HD, right?

672
00:33:02.195 --> 00:33:05.810
So Macintosh/HD is the startup volume and
that's where we would

673
00:33:05.810 --> 00:33:09.500
normally be restoring, because that's
what we want right, is our main OS.

674
00:33:09.500 --> 00:33:10.980
And so that's fine.

675
00:33:10.980 --> 00:33:14.840
But I also need to get the other volume,
right?

676
00:33:14.840 --> 00:33:17.970
So I can leave that out because
technically I've already restored that and

677
00:33:17.970 --> 00:33:23.400
so now I can specify the other volume,
in my case it would be /Storage, right.

678
00:33:23.400 --> 00:33:25.960
So I'm saying, restore the other drive.

679
00:33:25.960 --> 00:33:28.800
Not Macintosh HD but storage.

680
00:33:28.800 --> 00:33:33.120
And from there, we can then point
it to the other location which

681
00:33:33.120 --> 00:33:38.060
my new location is just /Volumes/Storage
so it's gonna know what to restore.

682
00:33:38.060 --> 00:33:40.430
I'm actually leaving something
kind of important out,

683
00:33:40.430 --> 00:33:43.370
which is I need to say /Storage/*.

684
00:33:43.370 --> 00:33:48.088
So it knows to get everything from inside
of that and put it in /Volume/Storage.

685
00:33:48.088 --> 00:33:53.250
And that's gonna make it bring that data
back and put it on the storage drive.

686
00:33:53.250 --> 00:33:55.160
>> And that storage drive,
if I remember right, Don,

687
00:33:55.160 --> 00:33:59.040
that has all of the service data
that you pointed over there, right?

688
00:33:59.040 --> 00:34:03.480
>> Yeah,
that's where I moved that service data in.

689
00:34:03.480 --> 00:34:06.400
Be careful because it
should be all of it but

690
00:34:06.400 --> 00:34:08.210
let me give you an example
where it might not be.

691
00:34:08.210 --> 00:34:11.980
So when I go into OS 10 server here,
my server app.

692
00:34:11.980 --> 00:34:15.220
I set my service data location
to that storage drive but

693
00:34:15.220 --> 00:34:17.650
some services can be
located somewhere else.

694
00:34:17.650 --> 00:34:21.380
For example, like the caching service,
see how it's got it's own setting for

695
00:34:21.380 --> 00:34:22.030
cache location?

696
00:34:22.030 --> 00:34:24.100
It's still set to Macintosh HD.

697
00:34:24.100 --> 00:34:27.000
It can be set to a third or
a fourth hard drive, some other drive.

698
00:34:27.000 --> 00:34:28.540
And I might need to go and get that.

699
00:34:28.540 --> 00:34:31.590
So I did the one that the global
setting was provided with.

700
00:34:31.590 --> 00:34:34.780
But check your individual services
because they might have their own

701
00:34:34.780 --> 00:34:35.580
storage somewhere else.

702
00:34:35.580 --> 00:34:38.850
Most of them don't so
like if I look at the mail server, right?

703
00:34:38.850 --> 00:34:42.600
The mail server doesn't have a setting
in here for where that storage is.

704
00:34:42.600 --> 00:34:45.960
I mean, you can set the mailbox size but
you cant' set where it resides.

705
00:34:45.960 --> 00:34:49.110
It uses the global setting so
mailbox is covered.

706
00:34:49.110 --> 00:34:54.660
Messages, calendar, context,
they're all covered, cache isn't.

707
00:34:54.660 --> 00:34:55.450
Now to be honest with you guys,

708
00:34:55.450 --> 00:34:58.550
I don't normally backup the cache
because it's just a cache.

709
00:34:58.550 --> 00:35:00.282
And the next time somebody
goes to download a file,

710
00:35:00.282 --> 00:35:02.135
it pulls it from the internet and
you cache it again, so

711
00:35:02.135 --> 00:35:03.830
you don't really need to back that up.

712
00:35:03.830 --> 00:35:05.400
Same thing with
the software update server.

713
00:35:05.400 --> 00:35:07.610
I don't normally back that up because,
again,

714
00:35:07.610 --> 00:35:09.330
I can just redownload those from Apple.

715
00:35:09.330 --> 00:35:13.740
I'm more concerned about data that
I can't recreate, like emails.

716
00:35:13.740 --> 00:35:15.600
If emails came into that mail server and

717
00:35:15.600 --> 00:35:18.920
I lose the mail database,
I can't just recreate those emails.

718
00:35:18.920 --> 00:35:19.660
I guess you could,

719
00:35:19.660 --> 00:35:23.320
you could reach out to every person who
could've conceivably emailed you and

720
00:35:23.320 --> 00:35:26.730
have them resend you the email, that would
be a fun set of phone calls to make.

721
00:35:26.730 --> 00:35:31.420
So, you want to make sure you focus on
that data that you can't recreate, right?

722
00:35:31.420 --> 00:35:36.190
Key thing to remember here is that
Time Machine on a server works the same as

723
00:35:36.190 --> 00:35:41.490
Time Machine on a workstation,
unless you have more than one hard drive.

724
00:35:41.490 --> 00:35:44.070
If you have more than one hard drive,
when you set up your Time Machine backup,

725
00:35:44.070 --> 00:35:46.760
make sure your external or
extra hard drives are not excluded.

726
00:35:46.760 --> 00:35:49.290
You need to make sure they're
included in the backup.

727
00:35:49.290 --> 00:35:54.380
And then secondly, make sure you remember
after you restore from Time Machine that

728
00:35:54.380 --> 00:35:57.820
you may need to go back and
restore your hard drive, your external or

729
00:35:57.820 --> 00:36:00.440
additional hard drives also,
as a separate step.

730
00:36:00.440 --> 00:36:04.420
Those are kinda key differences
between a server and a work station.

731
00:36:04.420 --> 00:36:05.290
>> Great information.

732
00:36:05.290 --> 00:36:08.330
In this episode, we've been looking
at proactive maintenance and

733
00:36:08.330 --> 00:36:09.570
not reactive maintenance.

734
00:36:09.570 --> 00:36:10.540
Remember what Don said,

735
00:36:10.540 --> 00:36:14.130
don't wait until you need backups to
find out if you actually have backups.

736
00:36:14.130 --> 00:36:16.150
But it does look like we're
coming to the end of the episode.

737
00:36:16.150 --> 00:36:19.550
Don, before we part ways here,
got anything else for us?

738
00:36:19.550 --> 00:36:23.810
>> That's about it, the key, I think I've
kind of already covered the key points,

739
00:36:23.810 --> 00:36:27.550
but I guess just one word of advice which
is don't just turn on your backups and

740
00:36:27.550 --> 00:36:29.380
forget about them, check them.

741
00:36:29.380 --> 00:36:30.600
You've got to check your backups.

742
00:36:30.600 --> 00:36:32.180
Check to make sure their occurring,

743
00:36:32.180 --> 00:36:35.360
I mentioned how I like to stick
the Time Machine icon up in the menu bar,

744
00:36:35.360 --> 00:36:38.480
because I can quickly see whether
my backups have run or not, right?

745
00:36:38.480 --> 00:36:39.830
So definitely set that up.

746
00:36:39.830 --> 00:36:42.730
But the other thing is, do test restores.

747
00:36:42.730 --> 00:36:46.690
Every now and then take your Time Machine
backup and go to a virtual machine, or

748
00:36:46.690 --> 00:36:49.770
a go to a MAC mini on your network,
something, and just test the restore.

749
00:36:49.770 --> 00:36:52.790
And go to restore it and
see if everything comes back and online.

750
00:36:52.790 --> 00:36:55.860
If it doesn't,
you know there's problem with your backup.

751
00:36:55.860 --> 00:36:58.500
Hey look, my external hard drive
is not a part of this backup,

752
00:36:58.500 --> 00:36:59.710
I can't restore services.

753
00:36:59.710 --> 00:37:02.270
It's better to spot that
on your own schedule

754
00:37:02.270 --> 00:37:03.820
than to spot it when a failure occurs.

755
00:37:03.820 --> 00:37:05.370
You definitely wanna see that earlier.

756
00:37:05.370 --> 00:37:07.030
And on software updates,

757
00:37:07.030 --> 00:37:10.430
make sure that you don't just
blanket roll out updates on servers.

758
00:37:10.430 --> 00:37:11.920
On workstations,
you can get away with it but

759
00:37:11.920 --> 00:37:16.210
on servers you need to make sure
they're online as much as possible.

760
00:37:16.210 --> 00:37:19.140
So test the updates first and

761
00:37:19.140 --> 00:37:23.540
then manually control the rollout
by using a software update server.

762
00:37:23.540 --> 00:37:26.760
If you know you're not gonna maintain it
though, be honest with yourself and say,

763
00:37:26.760 --> 00:37:28.390
hey, I'm not gonna maintain this.

764
00:37:28.390 --> 00:37:29.560
And if that's the case,

765
00:37:29.560 --> 00:37:33.260
just stick with the automatic updates from
Apple because then at least they get done.

766
00:37:33.260 --> 00:37:34.260
That's my advice.

767
00:37:34.260 --> 00:37:36.550
>> All right, well Don, thank you for
that wealth of information.

768
00:37:36.550 --> 00:37:38.520
And thank for
our viewers out there for watching.

769
00:37:38.520 --> 00:37:39.650
We're gonna go ahead and sign out.

770
00:37:39.650 --> 00:37:42.360
For ITProTV,
I've been your host, Wes Bryan.

771
00:37:42.360 --> 00:37:43.138
>> And I'm Don Pezet.

772
00:37:43.138 --> 00:37:45.350
>> And we'll see you next time.

773
00:37:45.350 --> 00:37:52.750
[MUSIC]

topics.title: Configuring and Monitoring OS X Server

episodes.description: In this episode Wes and Don discuss user authentication and the different types of authentication. They explain topics like hashes, crypt passwords, password servers, Kerberos and the Lightweight Directory Access Protocol. They explore the different storage mechanisms like Crypt, Shadow and Open Directory.
episodes.title: User Authentication
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.008 --> 00:00:10.008
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:12.355 --> 00:00:14.943
Welcome back.
Another exciting episode here at ITProTV.

3
00:00:14.943 --> 00:00:16.799
I'm your host Wes Bryan, and

4
00:00:16.799 --> 00:00:22.155
in today's episode we're continuing along
in our series on OS X server essentials.

5
00:00:22.155 --> 00:00:24.225
We've got none other than mister
Don Pezet in the house with us.

6
00:00:24.225 --> 00:00:25.665
Don how you doing today sir.

7
00:00:25.665 --> 00:00:28.595
>> I'm doing swell Wes ready
to dive right back in and

8
00:00:28.595 --> 00:00:31.075
in this episode we're gonna be
tackling some different topics.

9
00:00:31.075 --> 00:00:34.190
I know we've been focusing on server
administration up until now but

10
00:00:34.190 --> 00:00:37.060
on this one we're gonna take a look at,
well,

11
00:00:37.060 --> 00:00:42.320
user authentication and
user accounts are kind of a special thing

12
00:00:42.320 --> 00:00:45.920
in the OS 10 environment because
you've got that nice little GUI.

13
00:00:45.920 --> 00:00:48.590
You got the Apple world
sitting on the surface, and

14
00:00:48.590 --> 00:00:51.250
underneath you've got the BSD Unix world.

15
00:00:51.250 --> 00:00:54.540
And the two,
mostly kind of mask each other.

16
00:00:54.540 --> 00:00:56.930
So if you're in the terminal
you just see the Unix side, and

17
00:00:56.930 --> 00:00:59.420
if you're in the GUI you
just see the Apple side.

18
00:00:59.420 --> 00:01:02.150
But they really both work in concert,
they work together.

19
00:01:02.150 --> 00:01:03.840
Where things get even more complex though,

20
00:01:03.840 --> 00:01:07.290
is Apple doesn't just support
its own native authentication.

21
00:01:07.290 --> 00:01:11.179
It supports third part systems too because
it's rare that you just have an all Mac

22
00:01:11.179 --> 00:01:11.933
environment.

23
00:01:11.933 --> 00:01:14.186
You typically have some
windows machines out there or

24
00:01:14.186 --> 00:01:16.820
other things you might have
authenticated against.

25
00:01:16.820 --> 00:01:21.300
And so Apple has multiple different
ways that users can authenticate

26
00:01:21.300 --> 00:01:22.320
when they work with the system.

27
00:01:22.320 --> 00:01:25.260
So in this episode i wanna walk you
through each of the different ones

28
00:01:25.260 --> 00:01:26.440
that might turn up on the exam.

29
00:01:26.440 --> 00:01:29.740
They expect you to know the different
ones that are available and

30
00:01:29.740 --> 00:01:33.340
you probably need to know them in real
life too because you might find where

31
00:01:33.340 --> 00:01:37.740
a user is able to log in on a computer
even though they don't have a user account

32
00:01:37.740 --> 00:01:39.920
in that computer they're like where
the heck is this coming from.

33
00:01:39.920 --> 00:01:41.210
You need to understand the different

34
00:01:41.210 --> 00:01:43.880
places where that account
might be coming from.

35
00:01:43.880 --> 00:01:45.610
All right well let's kick things off and

36
00:01:45.610 --> 00:01:50.400
just talk about what is authentication
because there's a little bit of confusion

37
00:01:50.400 --> 00:01:52.950
amongst two security terms
you hear a lot about.

38
00:01:52.950 --> 00:01:56.060
Authentication and authorization, right?

39
00:01:56.060 --> 00:01:59.696
Authentication is the act of proving
that you are who you say you are.

40
00:01:59.696 --> 00:02:01.400
All right?

41
00:02:01.400 --> 00:02:06.880
On a Mac OS 10 machine, there's only
one way that you can prove who you are,

42
00:02:06.880 --> 00:02:10.260
and that's through a username and
password combination, right?

43
00:02:10.260 --> 00:02:13.710
If I tell it that my
username is Don Puszet, and

44
00:02:13.710 --> 00:02:15.500
if I tell it my password is password123,
ooh,

45
00:02:15.500 --> 00:02:18.670
we'll have to edit that out,
I don't want people to know my password.

46
00:02:18.670 --> 00:02:20.290
If I say my password, password123,

47
00:02:20.290 --> 00:02:24.610
then the computer says, you must be Don,
because you knew your own name.

48
00:02:24.610 --> 00:02:28.740
That's the mark of my intelligence,
and then you knew your password.

49
00:02:28.740 --> 00:02:31.210
But the reality is, Wes,
you know my password now.

50
00:02:31.210 --> 00:02:35.350
Wes could log in on this computer, and
the computer would assume that he is me.

51
00:02:35.350 --> 00:02:37.250
Because he knows all
the necessary information.

52
00:02:37.250 --> 00:02:39.080
He knows my name and
now he knows my password.

53
00:02:39.080 --> 00:02:41.820
So it's not the greatest method available.

54
00:02:41.820 --> 00:02:43.940
And I think everybody acknowledges that,

55
00:02:43.940 --> 00:02:45.970
that passwords are just
not the most reliable.

56
00:02:45.970 --> 00:02:48.820
So you're starting to see people
make pushes into other areas.

57
00:02:48.820 --> 00:02:51.990
Apple has done it,
not in Mac OS, but in IOS.

58
00:02:51.990 --> 00:02:56.490
In IOS they've enable the fingerprint,
right, you can do touch ID to log in now.

59
00:02:56.490 --> 00:03:01.430
Or you can do a pin number to log in, but

I don't wanna do that here because what's
important is really just one piece of it.

514
00:26:49.050 --> 00:26:52.580
When you log in on a Mac, there's
some interesting stuff that happens.

515
00:26:52.580 --> 00:26:53.900
Let me show you.

516
00:26:53.900 --> 00:26:55.930
So, If I log out,
let me just log out of this system.

517
00:26:57.420 --> 00:27:02.250
When the system boots up the Mac OS kernel
starts and the kernel is called Darwin.

518
00:27:02.250 --> 00:27:07.210
So Darwin starts and then Darwin launches
a few processes and those processes start.

519
00:27:07.210 --> 00:27:10.710
And then it launches a very special
process called login window and

520
00:27:10.710 --> 00:27:12.120
that's what I'm looking at right here.

521
00:27:12.120 --> 00:27:14.590
I'm looking at the login window process.

522
00:27:14.590 --> 00:27:19.820
And when I pick a user account like
Don Pezet, and I provide a password, I'm

523
00:27:19.820 --> 00:27:26.800
logging in and the login window service
becomes me, it takes over my identity.

524
00:27:26.800 --> 00:27:32.180
I authenticate and I'm given what's called
a ticket granting ticket, or a TGT, right?

525
00:27:32.180 --> 00:27:34.170
This is a key part of Kerberos.

526
00:27:34.170 --> 00:27:40.030
The TGT lets me run other
processes as myself.

527
00:27:40.030 --> 00:27:45.430
I can grant other processes a ticket,
or it's usually called a token but

528
00:27:45.430 --> 00:27:48.670
in the official terminology it's a ticket,
on the exam you'll see ticket.

529
00:27:48.670 --> 00:27:51.010
On the Internet you'll
see token more often.

530
00:27:51.010 --> 00:27:55.720
But, I can give a ticket to any process
and I can say, now you can run as me.

531
00:27:55.720 --> 00:28:01.840
So, anytime I run Safari or Pages or
Finder they're running as me.

532
00:28:01.840 --> 00:28:04.680
So that Safari has the same
permissions as I do.

533
00:28:04.680 --> 00:28:06.380
And Finder has the same permissions I do.

534
00:28:06.380 --> 00:28:08.560
Or Disc Utility has the same
permissions that I do.

535
00:28:08.560 --> 00:28:11.780
If I am an administrator, that means
these are running as administrators.

536
00:28:11.780 --> 00:28:15.300
If I'm a standard user,
they're running as a standard user.

537
00:28:15.300 --> 00:28:16.620
Everything's running as me.

538
00:28:16.620 --> 00:28:19.820
So, if I come in here and
I launch Safari, all right?

539
00:28:19.820 --> 00:28:24.580
So here I am, I'm running Safari and
I go to www.apple.com.

540
00:28:24.580 --> 00:28:26.850
Okay, so I'm running Safari.

541
00:28:26.850 --> 00:28:28.330
It's running right there.

542
00:28:28.330 --> 00:28:29.780
I go to Apple's website.

543
00:28:29.780 --> 00:28:31.360
If I switch to Wes.

544
00:28:31.360 --> 00:28:33.140
So I'm gonna jump over,
I'm gonna log in as Wes.

545
00:28:33.140 --> 00:28:36.110
Now this is my first
time logging in as Wes so

546
00:28:36.110 --> 00:28:38.300
it's going to take a moment as it
creates his profile and stuff.

547
00:28:39.440 --> 00:28:42.640
He has a log in window just like I did.

548
00:28:42.640 --> 00:28:46.380
And he has a TGT,
a Ticket Granting Ticket,

549
00:28:46.380 --> 00:28:50.210
that's letting him run programs as himself
and the operating system is able to

550
00:28:50.210 --> 00:28:54.000
keep these programs separate because
the ticket's attached to them.

551
00:28:54.000 --> 00:28:57.870
It sees the ticket and it says this
copy of Safari is running from Wes.

552
00:28:57.870 --> 00:28:59.900
This other copy of Safari is running for
Don and

553
00:28:59.900 --> 00:29:02.550
it knows that based on the tickets.

554
00:29:02.550 --> 00:29:05.100
So, as I soon as I manage
to get logged in as him,

555
00:29:05.100 --> 00:29:10.070
I have to resist the Apple ID kind of push
there, but as soon as I get logged in

556
00:29:10.070 --> 00:29:13.260
as him I can launch Safari
there'll two separate things.

557
00:29:13.260 --> 00:29:18.020
Now, where we see this
is kinda interesting.

558
00:29:18.020 --> 00:29:21.570
You can go in the activity monitor and if
you're an admin you can see your stuff in

559
00:29:21.570 --> 00:29:24.000
the system but
you don't normally see other users.

560
00:29:24.000 --> 00:29:28.510
So now that I'm logged in as Wes here,
I'm just gonna go to www.apple.com.

561
00:29:28.510 --> 00:29:31.528
All right, so he launched Safari and
went to Apple, I launched Safari and

562
00:29:31.528 --> 00:29:32.170
went to Apple.

563
00:29:33.830 --> 00:29:35.005
Let me switch back to myself.

564
00:29:35.005 --> 00:29:38.040
I'm gonna have an identity
crisis here in a minute.

565
00:29:38.040 --> 00:29:41.850
So, let me gt back here logged
in as myself, there we go, and

566
00:29:41.850 --> 00:29:43.430
I'm gonna launch the activity monitor.

567
00:29:45.060 --> 00:29:47.735
All right, in the activity monitor,
under CPU,

568
00:29:47.735 --> 00:29:50.830
you can see every process
running on your computer.

569
00:29:50.830 --> 00:29:53.560
You see the process and
you see who ran it and

570
00:29:53.560 --> 00:29:56.530
see how all of these over here say dpezet.

571
00:29:56.530 --> 00:29:58.030
I ran them, right?

572
00:29:58.030 --> 00:30:00.660
And the very first one,
if I sort it by process ID,

573
00:30:00.660 --> 00:30:05.610
the one with the lowest process ID
is the first one that ran as me.

574
00:30:05.610 --> 00:30:11.050
And if I come over here and
look, well it's distnoted,

575
00:30:11.050 --> 00:30:12.760
which is one of the launch processes.

576
00:30:12.760 --> 00:30:17.780
But the first one that is really important
is this guy right here, loginwindow, okay.

577
00:30:17.780 --> 00:30:20.610
These other ones are running as
me because I'm an administrator.

578
00:30:20.610 --> 00:30:23.260
A regular user wouldn't see those,
loginwindow would be their first one.

579
00:30:23.260 --> 00:30:30.200
So loginwindow, I provided my username and
password to it, and it ran as me, right?

580
00:30:30.200 --> 00:30:34.440
And so it kicked in and now everything
after that is being run as me.

581
00:30:34.440 --> 00:30:39.890
So when we start running other processes,
we'll see those kick in as me.

582
00:30:39.890 --> 00:30:44.870
So, these guys here have a lower process
number cuz I must have started them,

583
00:30:44.870 --> 00:30:46.480
it's the server app
that's doing that right?

584
00:30:46.480 --> 00:30:49.160
Cuz I started the services as me before.

585
00:30:49.160 --> 00:30:54.580
This one, 6580, anything with a process ID
higher than 6580 is from this session and

586
00:30:54.580 --> 00:30:57.130
so that's the first one
with that session number.

587
00:30:57.130 --> 00:30:58.910
And then each of the programs
that I run since then.

588
00:30:58.910 --> 00:31:01.890
So, I should be able to find
Safari in this list, right?

589
00:31:01.890 --> 00:31:04.740
It would be one of the later
things that I ran.

590
00:31:04.740 --> 00:31:05.810
There it is.

591
00:31:05.810 --> 00:31:07.910
There's Safari and it's running as me.

592
00:31:07.910 --> 00:31:10.290
My ticket is attached to it.

593
00:31:10.290 --> 00:31:13.200
Now, I know Wes is running Safari also,
right?

594
00:31:13.200 --> 00:31:15.020
But if I sort it, I don't see Wes here.

595
00:31:15.020 --> 00:31:20.360
And that's because the activity monitor
only shows you, your stuff, by default.

596
00:31:20.360 --> 00:31:24.910
But, if I were to drop down to a terminal,
In the terminal

597
00:31:24.910 --> 00:31:30.470
there's a BSD command we can run, called,
PS, that shows you all your processes.

598
00:31:30.470 --> 00:31:33.860
And PS will show you,
not just yours, but everybody's,

599
00:31:33.860 --> 00:31:35.440
if you give it the right modifier.

600
00:31:35.440 --> 00:31:40.270
So, if I do, sudo ps aux, right?

601
00:31:40.270 --> 00:31:41.710
Show me all the users.

602
00:31:41.710 --> 00:31:43.090
Show me what they're doing.

603
00:31:43.090 --> 00:31:46.200
When I run that,
I'm gonna see processes for everybody.

604
00:31:46.200 --> 00:31:50.220
And it's a lot of stuff so let me filter
that cuz I just want to find Safari,

605
00:31:50.220 --> 00:31:52.740
all right.

606
00:31:52.740 --> 00:31:56.780
And when I do that, let's see Safari,

607
00:31:56.780 --> 00:31:59.610
it must have a capital S,
it returned by grep command,

608
00:31:59.610 --> 00:32:02.890
my search, that's the only command that
it found, so let me try a capital S.

609
00:32:02.890 --> 00:32:04.680
There we go, that's a little better.

610
00:32:04.680 --> 00:32:09.720
And so looking at this,
I can see dpezet, process 7067.

611
00:32:09.720 --> 00:32:13.900
And I can see wbryan,
process 7023, and actually

612
00:32:13.900 --> 00:32:18.960
it looks like I've got more than one
Safari open right now for whatever reason.

613
00:32:18.960 --> 00:32:20.880
Tabs or updates or whatever.

614
00:32:20.880 --> 00:32:24.290
So, each of these are running
as our identities.

615
00:32:24.290 --> 00:32:27.810
So when you log in, when you authenticate,
that's the first part.

616
00:32:27.810 --> 00:32:31.000
But then it's gotta authorize you,
what are you authorized to do?

617
00:32:31.000 --> 00:32:34.740
And every program you run is
authorized the same way you are.

618
00:32:34.740 --> 00:32:37.760
And it's done by attaching
that ticket right there,

619
00:32:37.760 --> 00:32:39.120
that's how that process works.

620
00:32:39.120 --> 00:32:42.010
So I wanted to show you guys
that to be aware of it.

621
00:32:42.010 --> 00:32:44.910
On the exam,
there's two key terms to remember.

622
00:32:44.910 --> 00:32:48.010
Ticket granting ticket, I said it
more than once, that was important.

623
00:32:48.010 --> 00:32:51.410
And then, KDC, key distribution center.

624
00:32:51.410 --> 00:32:55.210
If you have a Kerbero server,
so an Open Directory,

625
00:32:55.210 --> 00:33:00.630
a Microsoft Active Directory, or even
the local directory service on your Mac,

626
00:33:00.630 --> 00:33:03.330
it's what gives you
the ticket granting ticket.

627
00:33:03.330 --> 00:33:05.040
It's what gives you that key.

628
00:33:05.040 --> 00:33:08.600
And so it's called
a Key Distribution Center, a KDC.

629
00:33:08.600 --> 00:33:10.680
So you're open directory,
your active directory,

630
00:33:10.680 --> 00:33:15.540
and even your local user database
are Key Distribution Centers, KDCs.

631
00:33:15.540 --> 00:33:17.730
And they give you that ticket
granting ticket so you can go and

632
00:33:17.730 --> 00:33:19.090
run those applications.

633
00:33:19.090 --> 00:33:21.560
In real life,
you probably don't care about this at all.

634
00:33:21.560 --> 00:33:23.570
But it's kinda neat to understand
the process in the background and

635
00:33:23.570 --> 00:33:25.690
how that works and
it's kinda neat to pass an exam,

636
00:33:25.690 --> 00:33:27.370
because these questions
are definitely gonna be on there,

637
00:33:27.370 --> 00:33:29.320
so definitely something
that you wanna remember.

638
00:33:29.320 --> 00:33:33.520
>> Lot of components, a lot of pieces
to authentication and authorization.

639
00:33:33.520 --> 00:33:35.360
Don, appreciate you opening the hood and

640
00:33:35.360 --> 00:33:37.400
letting us take a look at
the engine behind the scene.

641
00:33:37.400 --> 00:33:39.750
So it does look like we're coming
to the end of another episode.

642
00:33:39.750 --> 00:33:42.570
But before we leave,
got any words of wisdom?

643
00:33:42.570 --> 00:33:44.320
Study, [LAUGH].

644
00:33:44.320 --> 00:33:46.010
All of this stuff is hidden
behind the scenes, right.

645
00:33:46.010 --> 00:33:48.420
So do exactly what I just did,
poke around.

646
00:33:48.420 --> 00:33:51.342
It's hard to hurt anything, just don't
delete any files, you can poke around and

647
00:33:51.342 --> 00:33:52.060
try to look at them.

648
00:33:52.060 --> 00:33:55.456
Remember that you will probably need to
use the Sudo command to get into a lot of

649
00:33:55.456 --> 00:33:57.296
the directives cuz they're protected.

650
00:33:57.296 --> 00:34:00.603
And if you cheat like I did and do
Sudo.sh you can launch a route shell and

651
00:34:00.603 --> 00:34:03.821
then you can browse around and
you don't have to do the Sudo command.

652
00:34:03.821 --> 00:34:05.449
Don't do that in regular practice,

653
00:34:05.449 --> 00:34:09.030
though cuz you can accidentally do some
damage when you are in that type of shell.

654
00:34:09.030 --> 00:34:10.660
So you always want to be careful there.

655
00:34:10.660 --> 00:34:12.190
>> All right Don,
thank you for joining us.

656
00:34:12.190 --> 00:34:14.350
And thank you to our viewers for
joining us out there.

657
00:34:14.350 --> 00:34:16.070
We're gonna go ahead and
sign off here at ITProTV.

658
00:34:16.070 --> 00:34:17.960
I've been your host Wes Bryan.

659
00:34:17.960 --> 00:34:18.660
>> And I'm Don Pezet.

660
00:34:18.660 --> 00:34:20.853
>> And we'll see you next time.

661
00:34:20.853 --> 00:34:28.500

episodes.description: In this episode Wes and Don introduce Open Directory for centralized identity and password management. They look at the basics  like the main components that make up the Open Directory and the initial setup. They talk about the roles that a server can play when setting up Open Directory.
episodes.title: Open Directory
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.000 --> 00:00:10.000
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:11.936 --> 00:00:15.002
Welcome back to another exciting
episode here at ITProTV.

3
00:00:15.002 --> 00:00:19.231
I'm your host Wes Bryan, and in today's
episode, we're going to be moving along in

4
00:00:19.231 --> 00:00:23.071
our OSX server essentials and we got Mr.
Don Pezet in the house to help us out.

5
00:00:23.071 --> 00:00:24.280
Don, how are you doing today, sir?

6
00:00:24.280 --> 00:00:25.100
>> I'm doing great, Wes.

7
00:00:25.100 --> 00:00:28.850
Ready to jump back into OSX and we're
gonna be picking up this episode with

8
00:00:28.850 --> 00:00:31.220
a topic I mentioned a few
times in the last episode.

9
00:00:31.220 --> 00:00:32.680
If you haven't watched it,
our last episode,

10
00:00:32.680 --> 00:00:35.920
we talked about user authentication and
the ways that we can provide a username

11
00:00:35.920 --> 00:00:39.860
and a password to Mac OS and
get authenticated and get in the system.

12
00:00:39.860 --> 00:00:43.116
Well, I mentioned
Apple's Open Directory more than once,

13
00:00:43.116 --> 00:00:45.530
and didn't show it a single time,
and you might be wondering why?

14
00:00:45.530 --> 00:00:48.330
Well, the reason why is,
we got this whole episode, right here,

15
00:00:48.330 --> 00:00:49.610
on Apple's Open Directory.

16
00:00:49.610 --> 00:00:52.050
We're gonna see how to get it installed,
up and running,

17
00:00:52.050 --> 00:00:54.600
get some Macs joined to it, and using it.

18
00:00:54.600 --> 00:00:56.560
It's, actually, a pretty simple system.

19
00:00:56.560 --> 00:01:00.040
The set up, it does have some advanced
features that we need to be aware of,

20
00:01:00.040 --> 00:01:02.650
that can seem a little complex at first.

21
00:01:02.650 --> 00:01:04.670
But you'll see once we get into it,
it's not that bad, and

22
00:01:04.670 --> 00:01:06.030
it is a very reliable system.

23
00:01:06.030 --> 00:01:10.390
So that's what we're tackling right here,
Apple's Open Directory.

24
00:01:10.390 --> 00:01:12.070
Now, the thing about Open Directory,

25
00:01:12.070 --> 00:01:16.170
before I dive too deep into it, is that
Apple did not create it from scratch.

26
00:01:16.170 --> 00:01:19.630
This is actually built on an open
source product called OpenLDAP.

27
00:01:19.630 --> 00:01:21.840
And Apple forked OpenLDAP.

28
00:01:21.840 --> 00:01:26.120
And what forking means is, they basically
took all the code as it was written and

29
00:01:26.120 --> 00:01:28.230
then they made their own kinda branch,

30
00:01:28.230 --> 00:01:31.430
their own set of changes to
it that are Apple specific.

31
00:01:31.430 --> 00:01:35.880
So it's not a line for
line clone of OpenLDAP.

32
00:01:35.880 --> 00:01:36.610
It's been modified.

33
00:01:36.610 --> 00:01:38.990
It's been modified to suit Apple's needs.

34
00:01:38.990 --> 00:01:41.200
And on a negative side,

35
00:01:41.200 --> 00:01:44.170
that does mess with compatibility
a little bit with OpenLDAP, but

36
00:01:44.170 --> 00:01:48.890
on a positive side it means that we get a
nice GUI that makes it easy to manage it,

37
00:01:48.890 --> 00:01:53.590
as opposed to a bunch of text based config
files you normally have with OpenLDAP.

38
00:01:53.590 --> 00:01:55.310
OpenLDAP is not the easiest to configure,

39
00:01:55.310 --> 00:01:59.890
you will see here in this show that Open
Directory is, pretty easy to configure and

40
00:01:59.890 --> 00:02:01.680
get up and running, all right.

41
00:02:01.680 --> 00:02:04.530
The other thing to remember is
why we even need Open Directory,

42
00:02:04.530 --> 00:02:08.390
because I'm saying hey, we've got
usernames and passwords in Open Directory.

43
00:02:08.390 --> 00:02:10.310
I've got usernames and
passwords right here on my own computer.

44
00:02:10.310 --> 00:02:13.630
Why do I need some other server
to provide that function.

45
00:02:13.630 --> 00:02:17.440
If you're an individual user
with your own laptop, or

46
00:02:17.440 --> 00:02:20.370
if you're a small office, a home, right?

47
00:02:20.370 --> 00:02:22.940
You probably don't need Open Directory,
most people don't.

48
00:02:22.940 --> 00:02:28.994
But if you've got ten users,
100 users, 1,000, 5,000, 50,000 users.

49
00:02:28.994 --> 00:02:30.980
You really need Open Directory.

50
00:02:30.980 --> 00:02:33.760
And let me explain the main
problem that it solves.

51
00:02:34.820 --> 00:02:38.950
By default, user accounts
are present on a single computer.

52
00:02:38.950 --> 00:02:41.530
So, if I sit down at my computer,
and I go into my System Preferences,

53
00:02:41.530 --> 00:02:43.530
I go to users and groups,
and I add a user.

54
00:02:43.530 --> 00:02:45.070
That's just on my computer.

55
00:02:45.070 --> 00:02:46.650
On my laptop.

56
00:02:46.650 --> 00:02:48.070
Wes has his laptop.

57
00:02:48.070 --> 00:02:52.110
If he creates user accounts right there on
his laptop, and then if I have some kind

58
00:02:52.110 --> 00:02:56.730
of network device sharing a folder
user accounts are on that device.

59
00:02:56.730 --> 00:02:59.310
The user account on my computer
won't work on that other computer.

60
00:02:59.310 --> 00:02:59.970
Doesn't exist there.

61
00:02:59.970 --> 00:03:01.340
I would have to create it again.

62
00:03:01.340 --> 00:03:04.050
I would have to create
my user account over and

63
00:03:04.050 --> 00:03:07.710
over again on every computer that
I wanted access via the network.

64
00:03:07.710 --> 00:03:09.270
You can do that, it's a lot of work,
but you can do it.

65
00:03:09.270 --> 00:03:12.870
And then if I ever wanted to change my
password, I have to go to every one of

66
00:03:12.870 --> 00:03:16.920
those computers and change the password,
because they are separate accounts.

67
00:03:16.920 --> 00:03:20.110
If your a home user with two
computers that's not a big deal.

68
00:03:20.110 --> 00:03:22.830
If it's just you and
your own laptop it's not a big deal.

69
00:03:22.830 --> 00:03:24.731
But if you have a 1,000 computers or

70
00:03:24.731 --> 00:03:28.230
50,000 computers,
you don't want to do that, right?

71
00:03:28.230 --> 00:03:32.580
Every year, maybe you work at a school and
every year you get 20,000 new students.

72
00:03:32.580 --> 00:03:36.300
And so you've got to go to all
the computers in your entire school and

73
00:03:36.300 --> 00:03:37.570
add 20,000 new accounts.

74
00:03:37.570 --> 00:03:39.250
You don't want to do that.

00:37:13.779 --> 00:37:15.375
I've been your host, Wes Bryan.

763
00:37:15.375 --> 00:37:16.129
>> And I'm Don Pezet.

764
00:37:16.129 --> 00:37:18.402
>> And we'll see you next time.

765
00:37:18.402 --> 00:37:25.830
[MUSIC]

episodes.description: In this episode, Wes and Don take a look at user accounts and explore different user types, their characteristics and privileges inside of Mac OS X Server. They demonstrate how to create, manage and maintain a user accounts. They will guide the viewer through password policy creation as well as the effects of the policy on the end user experience.
episodes.title: User Accounts
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.000 --> 00:00:10.000
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:11.819 --> 00:00:14.716
Welcome back to another exciting
episode here at ITProTV.

3
00:00:14.716 --> 00:00:19.129
I'm your host, Wes Bryan, and in today's
episode, we're moving through our OS X

4
00:00:19.129 --> 00:00:22.691
server essentials and we got none
other than Mr. Don Pezet on hand.

5
00:00:22.691 --> 00:00:23.800
Don, how you doing sir?

6
00:00:23.800 --> 00:00:27.320
>> I'm doing great, Wes, ready to dive
right back into our OS X material.

7
00:00:27.320 --> 00:00:31.030
And in this episode, we're gonna
be taking a look at user accounts.

8
00:00:31.030 --> 00:00:32.830
And I know what you're thinking,
wait a minute, Don,

9
00:00:32.830 --> 00:00:40.160
we had a whole episode on user accounts
a couple of episodes ago, and yes, we did.

10
00:00:40.160 --> 00:00:42.940
But, in this episode I want
to take that same concept and

11
00:00:42.940 --> 00:00:44.430
go a little more in depth,

12
00:00:44.430 --> 00:00:48.140
and cover some of the behind the scenes
things that deal with user accounts.

13
00:00:48.140 --> 00:00:52.590
When we tackled it last time, we saw local
accounts and we saw network accounts and

14
00:00:52.590 --> 00:00:55.780
we went through the authentication
process, how authentication works.

15
00:00:55.780 --> 00:00:58.640
But beyond that there's a lot
more that's just dealing

16
00:00:58.640 --> 00:01:00.780
with managing those user accounts.

17
00:01:00.780 --> 00:01:01.830
So we're gonna tackle that.

18
00:01:01.830 --> 00:01:04.940
We'll talk a little bit about groups,
too, and troubleshooting,

19
00:01:04.940 --> 00:01:07.920
a few other different things that
we can kind of mess around with and

20
00:01:07.920 --> 00:01:10.240
figure out how everything's going.

21
00:01:10.240 --> 00:01:14.180
So that's what we're gonna be taking
a look at and it should be a good time.

22
00:01:14.180 --> 00:01:16.740
>> Yeah, when it comes down to it
we've got a few different types, or

23
00:01:16.740 --> 00:01:18.170
a couple different types of accounts, Don.

24
00:01:18.170 --> 00:01:20.800
Can you tells us a little bit about the
different types that we can expect to see?

25
00:01:20.800 --> 00:01:24.350
>> All right, so the two main types that
we need to worry about are the local and

26
00:01:24.350 --> 00:01:25.530
network accounts, right?

27
00:01:25.530 --> 00:01:28.510
And the terminology's a little bit weird
because we talk about local accounts,

28
00:01:28.510 --> 00:01:32.470
those are user accounts that exist
right on your individual Mac.

29
00:01:32.470 --> 00:01:36.390
They're managed individually on each
independent system, they're not combined.

30
00:01:36.390 --> 00:01:40.540
So those type of accounts, some people
refer to the as work group account, but

31
00:01:40.540 --> 00:01:43.740
they're really just local to your
own machine, so local accounts.

32
00:01:43.740 --> 00:01:45.620
Where it gets tricky
are the network accounts

33
00:01:45.620 --> 00:01:46.880
because we call them network accounts.

34
00:01:46.880 --> 00:01:49.230
They're stored on an open
directory somewhere, but

35
00:01:49.230 --> 00:01:51.820
Apple calls them local network accounts.

36
00:01:51.820 --> 00:01:55.180
And the reason they call them local
network accounts is because they exist on

37
00:01:55.180 --> 00:01:59.570
an open directory server somewhere and
so they're local to that server but

38
00:01:59.570 --> 00:02:02.330
they are available on the network also,
all right.

39
00:02:02.330 --> 00:02:07.420
Now when you create a user account you
really have this limited window of where

40
00:02:07.420 --> 00:02:11.500
you can set that, during creation, because
you can't change it after the fact.

41
00:02:11.500 --> 00:02:12.460
Let me show you what I mean.

42
00:02:12.460 --> 00:02:17.014
So I've got this server here, and this
server is an Open Directory server, so

43
00:02:17.014 --> 00:02:21.637
it's got Open Directory on it, and that
means I can have both local accounts and

44
00:02:21.637 --> 00:02:22.826
network accounts.

45
00:02:22.826 --> 00:02:27.179
Now, if I go into my System Preferences,
and I go into the Users and Groups,

46
00:02:27.179 --> 00:02:30.180
I'm only going to see local accounts here,
right?

47
00:02:30.180 --> 00:02:34.560
I see Don Pezet, I'm an admin and I see
guest user, which is disabled by default.

48
00:02:34.560 --> 00:02:36.590
Those are local accounts.

49
00:02:36.590 --> 00:02:42.210
If I were to add a new account, well,
I can only add local accounts here.

50
00:02:42.210 --> 00:02:44.110
So, if I go to Add, here it is.

51
00:02:44.110 --> 00:02:45.210
I can create a new account.

52
00:02:45.210 --> 00:02:47.820
And you have variations of local accounts,
right?

53
00:02:47.820 --> 00:02:50.570
Administrator, they can do
whatever they want to the system.

54
00:02:50.570 --> 00:02:53.930
Standard, it's a regular user,
they can't install software,

55
00:02:53.930 --> 00:02:55.302
they're kind of limited
on what they can do.

56
00:02:55.302 --> 00:02:57.620
Managed with Parental Controls,

57
00:02:57.620 --> 00:03:00.680
this is a standard user that has the
parental controls options turned on, so

58
00:03:00.680 --> 00:03:03.950
we can restrict what web pages they
can get to and programs they can run.

59
00:03:03.950 --> 00:03:05.200
Sharing Only.

60
00:03:05.200 --> 00:03:07.810
Sharing Only means they
can't log in on this machine

61
00:03:07.810 --> 00:03:10.160
they can only access it via the network.

62
00:03:10.160 --> 00:03:12.230
Now that starts to sound
like Open Directory.

63
00:03:13.490 --> 00:03:16.230
They can log into this
machine from the network.

64
00:03:16.230 --> 00:03:19.210
Whatever machine they're at they still
have to have a valid account over there.

65
00:03:19.210 --> 00:03:20.660
That's the difference with Open Directory,

66
00:03:20.660 --> 00:03:23.225
with Open Directory you can use
the same account everywhere.

67
00:03:23.225 --> 00:03:26.550
With Sharing Only the account only applies
when they're accessing this machine via

68
00:03:26.550 --> 00:03:27.060
the network.

69
00:03:27.060 --> 00:03:29.530
So these are the kinda four variations.

70
00:03:29.530 --> 00:03:33.690
Well if I go to my server app instead,

71
00:03:33.690 --> 00:03:36.460
in the server app I can create
user accounts too, right.

72
00:03:36.460 --> 00:03:40.140
So if I go over here under Accounts and
Users I'll see my user accounts and

73
00:03:40.140 --> 00:03:44.230
there's that Don Pezet account, and you'll
see over here it's in the Local Directory,

74
00:03:44.230 --> 00:03:46.170
it's a local account.

75
00:03:46.170 --> 00:03:50.670
But, I can add more users and
I can add those network account right.

76
00:03:50.670 --> 00:03:53.108
So, when I go to Add,
I have to choose that right here,

77
00:03:53.108 --> 00:03:55.300
I wanna make it a local network account.

78
00:03:55.300 --> 00:03:57.680
You cannot change this after the fact.

79
00:03:57.680 --> 00:04:01.540
So, for example my account, when I look at
my account here's that Don Pezet account,

80
00:04:01.540 --> 00:04:02.960
it's a local directory account.

81
00:04:02.960 --> 00:04:06.310
Maybe I wanna convert that to
an Open Directory account, I can't.

82
00:04:06.310 --> 00:04:09.050
If I edit that, so
if I just pull up that user,

83
00:04:09.050 --> 00:04:12.650
there's no option in here that change
it to make it a network account.

84
00:04:12.650 --> 00:04:16.680
It's just, it's stuck,
it's local only, that's it.

85
00:04:16.680 --> 00:04:18.080
Well, you got the Home Folder option but

86
00:04:18.080 --> 00:04:20.620
that doesn't actually apply
to where the account resides.

87
00:04:20.620 --> 00:04:22.340
It just whether or
not it has a home directory, right?

88
00:04:22.340 --> 00:04:25.110
So there's no way to
change it after the fact.

89
00:04:25.110 --> 00:04:27.190
So you got to get it
right the first time and

90
00:04:27.190 --> 00:04:31.040
the place I find people make most
mistakes are when it comes to groups.

91
00:04:31.040 --> 00:04:33.550
When you go and create a group
because you can mess it up there and

92
00:04:33.550 --> 00:04:35.510
you don't even notice right away, but

93
00:04:35.510 --> 00:04:38.300
for a user account if I wanna
create an account for Wes, right?

94
00:04:38.300 --> 00:04:42.050
I can come in here and
create an account for Wes Bryan, and

95
00:04:42.050 --> 00:04:47.040
I can give him account name, and
email address, password, all the other

96
00:04:47.040 --> 00:04:52.330
various things I think he needs to have
for his account, and then I can create it.

97
00:04:52.330 --> 00:04:54.960
Well let's talk about all
these various things.

98
00:04:54.960 --> 00:04:57.330
I've been talking about this first
option here, the directory, right?

99
00:04:57.330 --> 00:05:00.260
Local, or local network, right?

100
00:05:00.260 --> 00:05:02.090
So that's choosing where it gets stored.

101
00:05:02.090 --> 00:05:05.740
Does it get stored on the local machine or
in the Open Directory?

102
00:05:05.740 --> 00:05:08.410
Then the Full Name,
the Full Name is what Mac OS uses.

103
00:05:08.410 --> 00:05:10.220
We see this on the login screens.

104
00:05:10.220 --> 00:05:14.460
You can log in with it,
it's what we normally see, ourselves.

105
00:05:14.460 --> 00:05:18.930
The Account Name, that's for
the BSD Unix subsystem, right?

106
00:05:18.930 --> 00:05:21.200
That's the name behind the scenes.

107
00:05:21.200 --> 00:05:24.140
Now it's funny because I
say it's behind the scenes.

108
00:05:24.140 --> 00:05:26.120
It's actually not even
what the system uses.

109
00:05:26.120 --> 00:05:29.490
Because attached to this user is a UID,
a user ID.

110
00:05:29.490 --> 00:05:34.230
And it's a number, it's usually three
digits, they typically start at 500 so

111
00:05:34.230 --> 00:05:37.270
if Wes is the second account I've created,
he's probably 502.

112
00:05:37.270 --> 00:05:40.860
Then that number is what the system
actually pays attention to.

113
00:05:40.860 --> 00:05:44.560
The system doesn't care what his full
name is or what his account name is, but

114
00:05:44.560 --> 00:05:46.360
that is for us to be human readable.

115
00:05:46.360 --> 00:05:49.130
And in the UNIX world,
you can't have spaces, and so

116
00:05:49.130 --> 00:05:51.980
that's why we have two different names.

117
00:05:51.980 --> 00:05:55.090
The full name, they can be all pretty,
we can make it whatever we want.

118
00:05:55.090 --> 00:05:57.180
Well, I guess we have limits there, right?

119
00:05:57.180 --> 00:05:58.620
On the exam this might come up.

120
00:05:58.620 --> 00:06:05.460
It's really letters, numbers, and spaces,
and so I can do capital and lower case.

121
00:06:05.460 --> 00:06:10.800
It will let you do I think it's underscore
and period I think is the limit.

122
00:06:10.800 --> 00:06:13.550
It's easy to find out if you
type an unsupported character.

123
00:06:13.550 --> 00:06:19.263
So if you look here, I've got Wes Bryan,
I've got a capital W and a lower case e.

124
00:06:19.263 --> 00:06:24.127
I've got a space between Wes and Bryan,
I did an underscore and a period after it,

125
00:06:24.127 --> 00:06:27.370
but if I start doing things
like exclamation points and

126
00:06:27.370 --> 00:06:30.776
@s and symbols like that,
it starts to get angry at you.

127
00:06:30.776 --> 00:06:33.530
It doesn't want you doing
those other characters, okay.

128
00:06:33.530 --> 00:06:37.040
So there are limitations to
what we can jam in there,

129
00:06:37.040 --> 00:06:40.940
so you really need to try and
hold it to letters, numbers, and

130
00:06:40.940 --> 00:06:45.096
spaces underscores if you need them and
hyphens and periods.

131
00:06:45.096 --> 00:06:48.770
The account name is a lot more strict,
because it needs to be letters or

132
00:06:48.770 --> 00:06:52.480
numbers and underscored or
hyphens and that's about it.

133
00:06:52.480 --> 00:06:55.000
You're kind of limited on what you
want to do there cuz it's what

134
00:06:55.000 --> 00:06:57.780
falls into that BSD
subsystem under the hood.

135
00:06:57.780 --> 00:07:00.260
So this one gets really picky.

136
00:07:00.260 --> 00:07:04.170
If I try and type exclamation points
it's not even letting me type them.

137
00:07:04.170 --> 00:07:06.699
I can't type an @ symbol or whatever.

138
00:07:06.699 --> 00:07:08.630
I can type numbers.

139
00:07:09.750 --> 00:07:11.110
I can't do spaces.

140
00:07:11.110 --> 00:07:12.970
I'm hitting the space bar and
nothing's happening.

141
00:07:12.970 --> 00:07:14.100
I can do underscores and

142
00:07:14.100 --> 00:07:18.000
hyphens, periods, right, but
none of the other special characters.

143
00:07:18.000 --> 00:07:22.533
So it's much more limited
in what you can do.

144
00:07:22.533 --> 00:07:25.050
After that we've got our email address.

145
00:07:25.050 --> 00:07:27.090
This is just, an email,
this really in use for

146
00:07:27.090 --> 00:07:29.980
the contact system in OS X,
it has no true bearing.

147
00:07:29.980 --> 00:07:32.873
The system doesn't even verify
that email address even exists,

148
00:07:32.873 --> 00:07:34.195
doesn't necessarily know.

149
00:07:34.195 --> 00:07:36.916
But if I wanna put in an email address for
Wes, so

150
00:07:36.916 --> 00:07:39.512
I might say that he is wes@lab.itpro.tv.

151
00:07:39.512 --> 00:07:42.042
I can punch that in, shoot, I hit Enter.

152
00:07:42.042 --> 00:07:43.599
Well, it's gonna create his account.

153
00:07:43.599 --> 00:07:47.149
I can punch that in, and
it's gonna make it and now,

154
00:07:47.149 --> 00:07:50.230
it just has that email address on file.

155
00:07:50.230 --> 00:07:53.354
So if I go into my contacts,
I can see that email address, and

156
00:07:53.354 --> 00:07:55.883
if I've got mail set up,
I can try and email him.

157
00:07:55.883 --> 00:07:57.137
Let me add another user.

158
00:07:57.137 --> 00:08:01.672
Let's see, let's create an account for
good old Dave Mustaine, right.

159
00:08:01.672 --> 00:08:06.145
So we're gonna give Dave Mustaine
an account, we'll make him dmustaine.

160
00:08:06.145 --> 00:08:08.392
And the format you use for
the Account Name,

161
00:08:08.392 --> 00:08:12.100
I'm kinda in the habit of using
first initial, last name.

162
00:08:12.100 --> 00:08:15.804
You can use whatever you want,
you can use full names written out.

163
00:08:15.804 --> 00:08:20.520
I could say davemustaine,
I could say davem, or whatever.

164
00:08:20.520 --> 00:08:22.140
It's whatever works for you.

165
00:08:22.140 --> 00:08:24.890
Just know that in your organization
you might have duplicates.

166
00:08:24.890 --> 00:08:30.170
I might have two John Smiths, or I might
have a John Smith and a James Smith.

167
00:08:30.170 --> 00:08:31.730
Well, if I am doing
first initial last name,

168
00:08:31.730 --> 00:08:33.350
those two are gonna have
the same account name,

169
00:08:33.350 --> 00:08:36.070
so I've gotta have some system in
place for dealing with duplicates.

170
00:08:36.070 --> 00:08:37.650
That's the only thing
I have to worry about.

171
00:08:37.650 --> 00:08:39.720
You don't wanna have two
accounts with the same name.

172
00:08:41.370 --> 00:08:43.300
All right,
after that we've got the password.

173
00:08:43.300 --> 00:08:47.500
On the password, ideally you should use
a strong password but I've actually been

174
00:08:47.500 --> 00:08:50.530
using the word password, all lowercase,
which is about as weak as you can get.

175
00:08:50.530 --> 00:08:54.510
I might as well be leaving the password
fields blank at this point, right, but

176
00:08:54.510 --> 00:08:59.200
you can use the password assistant right
here to come up with a secure password.

177
00:08:59.200 --> 00:09:03.050
If you click on that little key,
you'll get a pop up that will appear,

178
00:09:03.050 --> 00:09:05.809
apparently way over here on the other
side of my screen, there we go.

179
00:09:05.809 --> 00:09:08.720
And it'll help you generate
an automatic password and

180
00:09:08.720 --> 00:09:10.600
it's got a few different ways
that it can do it, right?

181
00:09:10.600 --> 00:09:12.810
Memorable passwords, letters and numbers,

182
00:09:12.810 --> 00:09:16.530
numbers only, FIPS-181 compliant or
truly random.

183
00:09:16.530 --> 00:09:20.870
So you can pick it like this and
it'll gauge how strong that password is.

184
00:09:20.870 --> 00:09:24.850
And you'll see if I come in here and tell
it that I'm gonna do a manual entry and

185
00:09:24.850 --> 00:09:27.450
I'm doing password all lower case.

186
00:09:27.450 --> 00:09:29.320
I didn't get a very good rating, right?

187
00:09:29.320 --> 00:09:31.906
So maybe if I add 123.

188
00:09:31.906 --> 00:09:33.510
There we go, now we're safe, right?

189
00:09:33.510 --> 00:09:34.600
It's still a terrible password.

190
00:09:34.600 --> 00:09:37.760
So the little meter there is only so good.

191
00:09:37.760 --> 00:09:41.140
You need to find a good
combination of things and

192
00:09:41.140 --> 00:09:45.830
usually you wanna mix capital and
lowercase, and things like that.

193
00:09:45.830 --> 00:09:50.300
And then the longer the password gets,
the more secure it gets, right?

194
00:09:50.300 --> 00:09:54.550
Even though I just entered 1 through 0,
that wasn't terribly secure.

195
00:09:54.550 --> 00:09:57.740
It's just trying to help you,
give you some basic coaching advice.

196
00:09:57.740 --> 00:09:58.635
Not the greatest thing.

197
00:09:58.635 --> 00:10:01.176
All right, it is warning me,
this is too repetitive.

198
00:10:01.176 --> 00:10:02.620
In other words, it picked up that pattern.

199
00:10:02.620 --> 00:10:06.930
So it gave me a good quality but it still
warned me about that little problem.

200
00:10:06.930 --> 00:10:09.130
I didn't have that warning before, right?

201
00:10:09.130 --> 00:10:13.551
So if I start doing repeating patterns or
whatever, it will pick up on that and

202
00:10:13.551 --> 00:10:14.579
warn me about it.

203
00:10:14.579 --> 00:10:17.760
All right, so that's kind of the password
field, not too terribly exciting.

204
00:10:18.820 --> 00:10:20.499
Then as you keep scrolling down here,

205
00:10:20.499 --> 00:10:23.300
you'll see allow user to
administer this server.

206
00:10:23.300 --> 00:10:23.810
What does that mean?

207
00:10:25.120 --> 00:10:28.320
Are they allowed to run the server app and
connect to the system and

208
00:10:28.320 --> 00:10:29.420
start to manage it?

209
00:10:29.420 --> 00:10:31.290
Are regular users not allowed to do that?

210
00:10:31.290 --> 00:10:34.900
So am I gonna let them be an administrator
on the system, can they use the server

211
00:10:34.900 --> 00:10:38.990
app, can they go into system preferences,
can they be an admin on the server?

212
00:10:38.990 --> 00:10:41.290
Well, maybe I want them to be,
maybe I don't.

213
00:10:41.290 --> 00:10:42.950
This is one we can change after the fact.

214
00:10:42.950 --> 00:10:45.460
You can make somebody an administrator or
take it away.

215
00:10:45.460 --> 00:10:49.030
It's actually manged by a group and
so you can kinda move people in and

216
00:10:49.030 --> 00:10:49.950
out of the group if you need to.

217
00:10:49.950 --> 00:10:53.240
But just checking this little
box here takes care of that and

218
00:10:53.240 --> 00:10:54.350
now this user will be an administrator.

219
00:10:55.790 --> 00:10:59.860
The home folder I talked about before,
on every Mac there's a /users folder,

I jump into terminal and I run klist,
no credential cache found, right?

481
00:23:22.870 --> 00:23:24.480
Cuz I'm not logged in
with a Kerberos account.

482
00:23:24.480 --> 00:23:25.850
I'm not logged in to the open directory.

483
00:23:25.850 --> 00:23:29.390
I'm just a local administrator,
a local account on the system, right?

484
00:23:29.390 --> 00:23:31.120
So, a great way to test and

485
00:23:31.120 --> 00:23:35.315
check, am I logged in with a network
account or am I logged in locally?

486
00:23:35.315 --> 00:23:39.370
Cuz other commands like whoami,
whoami just says what your user name is,

487
00:23:39.370 --> 00:23:42.360
doesn't really tell you if you're
logged into the network or not.

488
00:23:42.360 --> 00:23:45.890
But klist, you'll see that ticket and
you'll see more information in there.

489
00:23:45.890 --> 00:23:49.148
You'll see things like when
that ticket was issued.

490
00:23:49.148 --> 00:23:52.588
So remember how I mentioned my
credentials were expired earlier?

491
00:23:52.588 --> 00:23:55.828
You can see how long ago
that ticket was issued.

492
00:23:55.828 --> 00:23:57.388
And when it expires.

493
00:23:57.388 --> 00:24:00.610
So my ticket was issued at 11:13.

494
00:24:00.610 --> 00:24:03.632
It expires at 21:13, right?

495
00:24:03.632 --> 00:24:05.930
So it was a ten hour ticket.

496
00:24:05.930 --> 00:24:08.700
In ten hours I need to
renew that ticket or

497
00:24:08.700 --> 00:24:10.680
I'm not gonna be able to run applications.

498
00:24:10.680 --> 00:24:12.630
And so
that's what happens when it expires.

499
00:24:12.630 --> 00:24:16.170
And if I lose communication with
the server, that ticket will expire and

500
00:24:16.170 --> 00:24:18.720
then I won't be able to
access network resources.

501
00:24:18.720 --> 00:24:21.839
Those are all different things that
kind of get in between you and

502
00:24:21.839 --> 00:24:23.410
accessing a network resource.

503
00:24:23.410 --> 00:24:27.401
>> Don, you've shown us, told us
that you can check the time clocks,

504
00:24:27.401 --> 00:24:30.202
is there any way that if I've got for
instance,

505
00:24:30.202 --> 00:24:34.896
maybe a few machines that their time
synchronization, I wouldn't want to have

506
00:24:34.896 --> 00:24:39.052
to go to every individual machine and
set the time or re-set the time.

507
00:24:39.052 --> 00:24:42.850
Is there a way that we could maybe
apply this to a bulk set of machines?

508
00:24:42.850 --> 00:24:46.820
>> Yeah, ideally, what you wanna do is
not set your clocks yourself, right.

509
00:24:46.820 --> 00:24:50.420
You wanna use something like NTP,
the Network Time Protocol, right.

510
00:24:50.420 --> 00:24:52.850
NTP servers, your Mac should be set for
it by default.

511
00:24:52.850 --> 00:24:55.570
So by default, out of the box,
it should be set for NTP.

512
00:24:55.570 --> 00:24:59.640
So like if I jump into my
System Preferences, and we go in here, and

513
00:24:59.640 --> 00:25:04.902
we jump into our clock settings, which are
way down here at the bottom, Date & Time.

514
00:25:04.902 --> 00:25:09.162
If I go into Date & Time, what you
should see is that it set date and

515
00:25:09.162 --> 00:25:10.890
time automatically.

516
00:25:10.890 --> 00:25:14.640
Right, that it's gonna pull
it from time.apple.com.

517
00:25:14.640 --> 00:25:17.610
So you shouldn't adjust
your clock yourself.

518
00:25:17.610 --> 00:25:19.750
If you adjust your clock in
an Open Directory environment,

519
00:25:19.750 --> 00:25:21.820
it's gonna break authentication, right.

520
00:25:21.820 --> 00:25:25.710
The only thing that you can
safely adjust is your time zone.

521
00:25:25.710 --> 00:25:27.948
Because in the background,
it's using UTC, right.

522
00:25:27.948 --> 00:25:29.500
It's using Zulu time.

523
00:25:29.500 --> 00:25:33.550
But everywhere else, you just see
it rendered in your own time zone.

524
00:25:33.550 --> 00:25:37.890
So if I'm accidentally in the Pacific
Time Zone, I can move into Eastern.

525
00:25:39.120 --> 00:25:40.850
Technically my clock is still the same but

526
00:25:40.850 --> 00:25:44.070
it's rendering correct,
versus is I subtract or add 3 hours.

527
00:25:44.070 --> 00:25:46.522
Now I'm breaking it right, so
that's kind of the same thing.

528
00:25:46.522 --> 00:25:49.090
And using NTP is the best way to do that.

529
00:25:49.090 --> 00:25:53.170
Now it's grayed out online, because you
have to be an administer to change it.

530
00:25:53.170 --> 00:25:58.792
And I'm logged in with a directory account
that is an administrator but, there we go.

531
00:25:58.792 --> 00:26:01.210
Yep, so now, I can go in and change that.

532
00:26:01.210 --> 00:26:04.360
I can turn that off and
set my clock manually, if I wanted to.

533
00:26:04.360 --> 00:26:06.650
A lot of users are administrators
on their own machine,

534
00:26:06.650 --> 00:26:09.070
because you wanna allow them
to install their own software.

535
00:26:09.070 --> 00:26:11.060
But that means they can
break their clock too.

536
00:26:11.060 --> 00:26:15.070
So if you're gonna go that route,
I recommend using the Profile Manager to

537
00:26:15.070 --> 00:26:18.590
push out a hard profile that prevents
users from changing the setting.

538
00:26:18.590 --> 00:26:21.750
So you can hard set it, and
you don't have to use Apple's time server.

539
00:26:21.750 --> 00:26:23.920
You can come in and
specify one of your own.

540
00:26:23.920 --> 00:26:27.790
So I know lot of people like pool.ntp.org,
or

541
00:26:27.790 --> 00:26:30.490
you might even set up
your own time server.

542
00:26:30.490 --> 00:26:35.400
But if you do, make sure that all of your
machines are using the same time server,

543
00:26:35.400 --> 00:26:40.060
cuz if their clocks get off, you'll start
getting authentication issues, right.

544
00:26:40.060 --> 00:26:42.580
In additional authentication,
remember your access control list.

545
00:26:42.580 --> 00:26:45.430
That's another thing that can
cause you to get blocked, and

546
00:26:45.430 --> 00:26:48.950
I showed it the last episode,
back when I was in the Server Manager.

547
00:26:48.950 --> 00:26:51.030
Let me switch back to me.

548
00:26:51.030 --> 00:26:55.791
That when we create user accounts, you
can create an ACL on each individual user

549
00:26:55.791 --> 00:27:00.356
account, and that can restrict what
services they're allowed to access.

550
00:27:00.356 --> 00:27:03.278
So, if they're trying to access something,
and they're getting blocked,

551
00:27:03.278 --> 00:27:04.530
it could be that they have an ACL.

552
00:27:04.530 --> 00:27:09.661
So if I take an account, like,
old Dave Mustang, and I hit the gear,

553
00:27:09.661 --> 00:27:14.096
down here, we can go in and
Edit Access to Service, right?

554
00:27:14.096 --> 00:27:17.249
I showed this, where, you can pick and
choose what they access.

555
00:27:17.249 --> 00:27:20.428
Doesn't matter if their password is right
or wrong, or if their clock is right or

556
00:27:20.428 --> 00:27:23.450
wrong, if it's not checked here,
they won't be able to access it.

557
00:27:23.450 --> 00:27:25.190
That's one thing that can block it.

558
00:27:25.190 --> 00:27:28.050
But those ACLs show up in
more than one place right?

559
00:27:28.050 --> 00:27:33.010
So if I have file sharing for example,
every shared folder has permissions.

560
00:27:33.010 --> 00:27:35.620
But you'll also see where
most of your services,

561
00:27:35.620 --> 00:27:39.560
even simple services like the calendar,
will have entries in here where you can

562
00:27:39.560 --> 00:27:42.360
create ACLs based on what
computers can get to it.

563
00:27:42.360 --> 00:27:45.620
So now it doesn't matter what user
account it is, it's just the,

564
00:27:45.620 --> 00:27:48.140
why is it taking a long time to
load a service that's turned off?

565
00:27:48.140 --> 00:27:48.980
There we go [LAUGH].

566
00:27:48.980 --> 00:27:53.533
But it doesn't matter if it's a user
account that has a bad password or

567
00:27:53.533 --> 00:27:54.392
a bad clock.

568
00:27:54.392 --> 00:27:54.904
If their IP,

569
00:27:54.904 --> 00:27:58.180
if their workstation is not allowed to get
to it then they're gonna have a problem.

570
00:27:58.180 --> 00:28:00.730
So right here,
see the permissions for the calendar?

571
00:28:00.730 --> 00:28:02.720
All users, All Networks?

572
00:28:02.720 --> 00:28:07.950
I can edit those permissions and
I can specify only some users.

573
00:28:07.950 --> 00:28:13.690
And now I can pick, and so
maybe I want Nick to be able to get to it.

574
00:28:13.690 --> 00:28:14.976
Well that worked really well.

575
00:28:14.976 --> 00:28:19.220
I want Nick to be able to get to it,
but I don't want anybody else, right?

576
00:28:19.220 --> 00:28:21.870
So I'll just come in here and
put him in the list.

577
00:28:21.870 --> 00:28:24.220
It's not an ACL on Nick's account.

578
00:28:24.220 --> 00:28:26.520
It's an ACL on the calendar.

579
00:28:26.520 --> 00:28:30.870
So access control lists can go either way,
on the user or on the calendar.

580
00:28:30.870 --> 00:28:33.520
And once that's done,
now he's the only one that can get to it.

581
00:28:33.520 --> 00:28:37.340
When connecting from, here's where I
can limit it to certain networks, and

582
00:28:37.340 --> 00:28:40.930
so I can say private networks or
only some networks.

583
00:28:40.930 --> 00:28:43.880
And now I can come in and
get really specific, and

584
00:28:43.880 --> 00:28:47.860
I can create a network like, you know,
maybe it's the Gainesville office.

585
00:28:49.130 --> 00:28:56.850
And I'll say that it's 192.168.0.1
all the way through 192.168.0.245.

586
00:28:56.850 --> 00:29:03.022
And specify that, and once that's in
place, now if I can click, there we go.

587
00:29:03.022 --> 00:29:06.163
Now I have limits on the user and
the network, and this is gonna stop people

588
00:29:06.163 --> 00:29:09.659
from being able to access those services,
even if their account is completely and

589
00:29:09.659 --> 00:29:13.030
perfectly valid, those are other
things you wanna troubleshoot.

590
00:29:13.030 --> 00:29:15.933
>> Don, what if somebody makes a mistake,
the admin makes a mistake and

591
00:29:15.933 --> 00:29:18.639
they create the user account from
the System Preferences rather

592
00:29:18.639 --> 00:29:19.706
than on the service app.

593
00:29:19.706 --> 00:29:21.735
What's gonna be the end
result of their access?

594
00:29:21.735 --> 00:29:23.310
>> They're gonna have no network access,
right?

595
00:29:23.310 --> 00:29:26.031
I mean, they might be able to access
shared folders if those exist,

596
00:29:26.031 --> 00:29:27.840
cuz you can authenticate that way.

597
00:29:27.840 --> 00:29:31.070
But they won't be able to log into
their own machine with that account.

598
00:29:31.070 --> 00:29:32.393
Now that might not be a problem, right.

599
00:29:32.393 --> 00:29:36.286
If they're just accessing the calendar and
chat, they can authenticate each of those

600
00:29:36.286 --> 00:29:40.235
individual applications, and they can put
their account, which would be effectively

601
00:29:40.235 --> 00:29:44.160
a local account, but they wouldn't be able
to log into their machine as that account.

602
00:29:44.160 --> 00:29:46.723
So that means they're gonna have to
authenticate in every single app

603
00:29:46.723 --> 00:29:49.230
individually and that's super annoying.

604
00:29:49.230 --> 00:29:53.250
If it's network account, now they can log
into their machine with the network and

605
00:29:53.250 --> 00:29:56.347
all the apps will automatically
see that and get it connected.

606
00:29:56.347 --> 00:29:59.309
You saw with the messages where you can
make them message buddies appear in

607
00:29:59.309 --> 00:30:00.200
the same group.

608
00:30:00.200 --> 00:30:02.260
You start getting features like that
where it all becomes automatic.

609
00:30:02.260 --> 00:30:05.200
That's really what you want,
you don't wanna mix and match local and

610
00:30:05.200 --> 00:30:05.889
network if you can avoid it.

611
00:30:07.530 --> 00:30:09.320
All right, well,
I know it's been a little while.

612
00:30:09.320 --> 00:30:12.765
Let's take a look back at that group and
see if it ever showed up for us and if

613
00:30:12.765 --> 00:30:16.891
not, we're gonna do a little more digging
on the logs, and we'll see what we've got.

614
00:30:16.891 --> 00:30:20.647
So we'll just jump right over
here to groups and there we go,

615
00:30:20.647 --> 00:30:22.792
we've got the band is showing up.

616
00:30:22.792 --> 00:30:23.948
There's that imported group.

617
00:30:23.948 --> 00:30:26.890
I guess it just needed a little
time to sort itself out there.

618
00:30:26.890 --> 00:30:30.240
And once I pull that up I can see
not only did it make the group,

619
00:30:30.240 --> 00:30:33.010
but it's got members added to it, right?

620
00:30:33.010 --> 00:30:34.578
All imported from that file.

621
00:30:34.578 --> 00:30:38.030
So if I need to bring in a bunch of
these guys all at once, I can do that,

622
00:30:38.030 --> 00:30:40.964
get them created and
even add people to it at the same time.

623
00:30:40.964 --> 00:30:43.341
So just like we saw
with the user accounts,

624
00:30:43.341 --> 00:30:47.322
not anything too crazy different there,
same basic process, right?

625
00:30:47.322 --> 00:30:48.890
Just all about some fine things.

626
00:30:48.890 --> 00:30:51.760
You'll find that a lot of
people don't make use of this

627
00:30:51.760 --> 00:30:54.750
quite the same way because, well,
everybody's got different needs, right,

628
00:30:54.750 --> 00:30:56.820
different groups or whatever.

629
00:30:56.820 --> 00:30:59.563
Microsoft's Active Directory is a little
more common out there in the real world

630
00:30:59.563 --> 00:31:01.676
for this stuff and it has
a different way of importing things.

631
00:31:01.676 --> 00:31:03.580
So you'll see a lot of
documentation on that.

632
00:31:03.580 --> 00:31:07.940
But for the Apple exam, obviously,
they want you to know the Apple stuff and

633
00:31:07.940 --> 00:31:09.100
that's basically it.

634
00:31:09.100 --> 00:31:10.600
>> A lot of good information in this one.

635
00:31:10.600 --> 00:31:11.822
And remember, this was a two parter.

636
00:31:11.822 --> 00:31:15.092
So if you're catching the second part and
it sounds a little foreign to you,

637
00:31:15.092 --> 00:31:17.060
remember to go back and
see the first part.

638
00:31:17.060 --> 00:31:19.930
Don, thanks for that information, but
looks like we're gonna wrap this up.

639
00:31:19.930 --> 00:31:21.730
Got any parting words of wisdom?

640
00:31:21.730 --> 00:31:25.180
You know, one last thing that I
forgot to mention that might turn up,

641
00:31:25.180 --> 00:31:27.280
is that you can actually nest groups.

642
00:31:27.280 --> 00:31:30.820
So you can have one group
inside of another group.

643
00:31:30.820 --> 00:31:34.170
You may have absolutely no need for this,
but let me just give you an example.

644
00:31:34.170 --> 00:31:36.790
Let's say that I have sales
people in my company.

645
00:31:36.790 --> 00:31:40.440
And some sales people are in Europe and
some sales people are in North America.

646
00:31:40.440 --> 00:31:43.920
I might want salespeople in Europe
to have access to one printer and

647
00:31:43.920 --> 00:31:46.810
salespeople in North America to
have access to another printer.

648
00:31:46.810 --> 00:31:49.880
And then I might want all of the
salespeople to have access to a certain

649
00:31:49.880 --> 00:31:51.100
shared folder.

650
00:31:51.100 --> 00:31:54.459
So I can create nested
groups that meet that need.

651
00:31:54.459 --> 00:31:56.524
Right, let me just show you that real
quick and then we'll wrap it up,

652
00:31:56.524 --> 00:31:57.750
I know Wes is giving me the evil eye now.

653
00:31:57.750 --> 00:32:02.473
So I'm gonna create a group
real quick called Sales People.

654
00:32:02.473 --> 00:32:06.773
So we'll whip that simple group up and
get that in place.

655
00:32:06.773 --> 00:32:13.242
And then I'm gonna create another group
called, maybe like NA Sales People,

656
00:32:13.242 --> 00:32:17.458
so this'll be my North American
sales people, and

657
00:32:17.458 --> 00:32:22.872
then we'll create a EU Sales People for
that other side, right.

658
00:32:22.872 --> 00:32:27.296
So now I've got North America, I've got
EU, I've got everything that I need, and

659
00:32:27.296 --> 00:32:29.059
I can go back under Sales People.

660
00:32:29.059 --> 00:32:32.471
And in the Members,
when we go to add members,

661
00:32:32.471 --> 00:32:37.293
you're normally adding users right,
but I can also add Groups.

662
00:32:37.293 --> 00:32:41.986
And so right there I've added
North America Sales People, and

663
00:32:41.986 --> 00:32:46.420
I can add EU Sales People, and
now I've got nested groups.

664
00:32:46.420 --> 00:32:49.780
I've got the, oops,
if I can click OK, there we go.

665
00:32:49.780 --> 00:32:52.200
So if I get permissions to sales people,

666
00:32:52.200 --> 00:32:55.260
every sales person in the entire
company will get that permission.

667
00:32:55.260 --> 00:32:59.010
If I assign it to EU,
just people in the EU get permissions.

668
00:32:59.010 --> 00:33:02.010
If I assign it to NA, just people in
North America get the permissions.

669
00:33:02.010 --> 00:33:05.890
And when I hire a new sales person I
don't put them in the Sales People group,

670
00:33:05.890 --> 00:33:08.370
I put them in their regional group.

671
00:33:08.370 --> 00:33:10.834
And their regional group is
a part of the parent group and

672
00:33:10.834 --> 00:33:13.412
still get those permissions
cuz they kinda trickle down.

673
00:33:13.412 --> 00:33:17.270
So you can nest groups to create
the hierarchy that you need.

674
00:33:17.270 --> 00:33:20.542
Just remember to make sure they're network
directory accounts and not local directory

675
00:33:20.542 --> 00:33:23.166
accounts, so that you can use them
all throughout your environment.

676
00:33:23.166 --> 00:33:25.823
>> Don, thanks for all that great
information, and we do thank you,

677
00:33:25.823 --> 00:33:27.400
the viewers, out there for watching.

678
00:33:27.400 --> 00:33:29.760
But we're gonna go ahead and
sign out here at ITProTV.

679
00:33:29.760 --> 00:33:31.069
I've been your host, Wes Bryan.

680
00:33:31.069 --> 00:33:32.160
>> And I'm Don Pezet.

681
00:33:32.160 --> 00:33:34.258
>> And we'll see you next time.

682

00:24:24.230 --> 00:24:27.970

00:24:28.970 --> 00:24:33.100

00:25:48.710 --> 00:25:53.040

00:25:58.831 --> 00:26:00.090

00:26:00.090 --> 00:26:01.260

00:26:01.260 --> 00:26:03.970
So that Teacher Laptops

00:26:03.970 --> 00:26:05.460

00:26:05.460 --> 00:26:12.320

00:26:12.320 --> 00:26:17.089

00:26:21.430 --> 00:26:27.080

00:26:27.080 --> 00:26:32.500

00:26:32.500 --> 00:26:38.510

00:26:38.510 --> 00:26:41.810

00:26:43.770 --> 00:26:47.070
So again, you're building that

00:26:47.070 --> 00:26:48.630
organization, all right?

00:26:48.630 --> 00:26:49.690
That's important.

00:26:49.690 --> 00:26:51.590

00:26:59.510 --> 00:27:02.490

00:27:10.642 --> 00:27:12.370

one member as soon as I hit Save.

00:27:20.730 --> 00:27:21.570

00:27:21.570 --> 00:27:24.410
So Student Machines now has one member,

00:27:24.410 --> 00:27:27.950
Teacher Machines has two members, those

00:27:27.950 --> 00:27:31.640
