00:27:31.640 --> 00:27:34.230
So under Teacher Laptops maybe
I wanna add my machine there,

00:27:34.230 --> 00:27:36.130
because you can have a device

00:27:36.130 --> 00:27:37.930
There's no reason you couldn't.

560
00:27:37.930 --> 00:27:40.364
And so I can add that one in, right?

561
00:27:40.364 --> 00:27:44.080
And so now I'll show up under that also,
right?

562
00:27:44.080 --> 00:27:48.190
Notice how Teacher Machines,
its member count didn't increase, but

563
00:27:48.190 --> 00:27:50.280
because I'm in Teacher Laptops, and

00:27:50.280 --> 00:27:53.950
Teacher Laptops is in Teacher Machines,
I'm now effectively in Teacher Machines.

565
00:27:53.950 --> 00:27:55.770
It's an easier way to manage that,
all right.

566
00:27:55.770 --> 00:27:58.580
But you've got to arrange and depending on
your devices, depending on your groups,

00:27:58.580 --> 00:27:59.960
it's gonna be different for you.

00:27:59.960 --> 00:28:03.398
Create the hierarchy based on
the policies you're going to apply.

00:28:03.398 --> 00:28:06.632
And just remember, it's easy enough to
move people around after the fact, so

00:28:06.632 --> 00:28:09.425

be a little bit more pointing and

00:28:09.425 --> 00:28:12.270

device groups and

00:28:53.060 --> 00:28:56.580
So if I have a user account,

00:28:56.580 --> 00:28:58.390
This is going to apply.

00:28:58.390 --> 00:29:01.040
When we start to create our settings,
you've gotta figure out,

00:29:01.040 --> 00:29:06.860

00:29:06.860 --> 00:29:12.510
I might want something that's
a laptop power saving setting.

588
00:29:12.510 --> 00:29:14.620
I want that to apply to laptop

589
00:29:14.620 --> 00:29:16.390
I don't care if you're a teacher or
a student,

590
00:29:16.390 --> 00:29:17.750
I want it to apply to that laptop.

591
00:29:18.890 --> 00:29:23.550

592
00:29:23.550 --> 00:29:25.720
Now I don't care if the student
logs in on a desktop or

593
00:29:25.720 --> 00:29:28.200
a laptop,
I just care that they're a student.

594
00:29:28.200 --> 00:29:33.290
So some profiles will apply to users,
some profiles will apply to devices,

595
00:29:33.290 --> 00:29:38.220
and then we make the decision, but
I always apply the profiles to a group.

596
00:29:38.220 --> 00:29:40.760
I rarely apply a profile
to an individual user,

597
00:29:40.760 --> 00:29:43.370
because there's no easy way to copy that.

598
00:29:43.370 --> 00:29:46.960
If I create a profile and I just apply it
to Wes, and then I hire a new user and I'm

00:29:46.960 --> 00:29:50.940

00:29:50.940 --> 00:29:55.490

00:29:55.490 --> 00:29:57.840
put Wes in that and
created the profile there.

00:29:57.840 --> 00:29:59.850
And now I want somebody else

00:29:59.850 --> 00:30:03.130
I just stick them in
the ITProTV show host group and

00:30:03.130 --> 00:30:04.430

00:30:04.430 --> 00:30:10.290

deviate, but as a rule of thumb,

606
00:30:10.290 --> 00:30:14.070

607
00:30:14.070 --> 00:30:16.420
You can move people in and
take people out of the group.

00:30:16.420 --> 00:30:19.900
You can move devices in,

1

[MUSIC]

2

3
00:00:15.126 --> 00:00:16.764
I'm your host, Wes Bryan, and

4
00:00:16.764 --> 00:00:20.543
in today's episode we're moving
through our OS X Server fundamentals.

5
00:00:20.543 --> 00:00:23.696
And joining me back in the studio again
is none other than Mr Don Pezet, Don,

6
00:00:23.696 --> 00:00:25.050
how you doing today, sir?

7
00:00:25.050 --> 00:00:26.241
>> I'm doing great, Wes,

8
00:00:26.241 --> 00:00:30.550
I'm ready to tax everyone's mind with
the most complex topic imaginable.

9
00:00:30.550 --> 00:00:31.390
Sharing files.

10
00:00:31.390 --> 00:00:32.126
That's right,

11
00:00:32.126 --> 00:00:35.125
[LAUGH] we're gonna take a look at
sharing files in OS X Server today.

12
00:00:35.125 --> 00:00:37.530
And I know, it sounds kind of ridiculous.

13
00:00:37.530 --> 00:00:40.010

14
00:00:40.010 --> 00:00:41.170

15

00:00:49.050 --> 00:00:52.320

understand the difference between

18
00:00:52.320 --> 00:00:55.450
the sharing service in the server
versus the sharing service

00:00:55.450 --> 00:00:57.658
on your own desktop and what that is.

20
00:00:57.658 --> 00:01:00.496
So we're gonna take a look at that today,
what the difference is, how we get it

00:01:00.496 --> 00:01:03.042
configured, and why we'd even use

22
00:01:03.042 --> 00:01:05.690

00:01:05.690 --> 00:01:08.171
>> Don, one of the things we

00:01:08.171 --> 00:01:10.756
when it comes to file sharing,
we got a host of protocols for

00:01:10.756 --> 00:01:14.458
different operating systems out there and

26
00:01:14.458 --> 00:01:18.160

00:01:18.160 --> 00:01:21.490
>> All right, now in your just

36

37
00:01:49.520 --> 00:01:52.100

00:01:52.100 --> 00:01:55.167

00:01:55.167 --> 00:01:58.130

00:02:01.900 --> 00:02:04.730

00:02:14.197 --> 00:02:17.708

47
00:02:17.708 --> 00:02:22.918

48
00:02:22.918 --> 00:02:26.985

00:02:26.985 --> 00:02:28.410

00:02:28.410 --> 00:02:31.880

00:02:31.880 --> 00:02:32.630
years.

52
00:02:32.630 --> 00:02:35.750
And there's parts of it
that they've open sourced,

53
00:02:35.750 --> 00:02:38.520
they've made available to other
vendors that are out there.

54
00:02:38.520 --> 00:02:43.360
And so SMB, Server Message Block, it was
originally a Microsoft-only protocol, but

55
00:02:43.360 --> 00:02:46.690
now, Linux and Mac support it.

56
00:02:46.690 --> 00:02:49.820
So that means that you can have all of

00:02:49.820 --> 00:02:51.190

58

59
00:02:53.108 --> 00:02:58.190

60

61

right, between Linux, Windows, and

62
00:03:07.250 --> 00:03:09.670
There's multiple versions

which I might call Research, all right.

740
00:37:07.330 --> 00:37:11.999
And so this is gonna be my Research folder
and let me just unlock my permissions.

741
00:37:13.340 --> 00:37:18.027
And see how it's me, staff,
everyone, right, and that's it,

742
00:37:18.027 --> 00:37:20.636
that's the default for my desktop.

743
00:37:20.636 --> 00:37:23.987
And I'm gonna take staff and I'll make
staff, actually I'll leave staff read

744
00:37:23.987 --> 00:37:27.080
only, and I'm gonna take everyone and
give them no access.

745
00:37:27.080 --> 00:37:30.920
Okay, so everyone no access, staff read
only, me, I can do whatever I want.

746
00:37:30.920 --> 00:37:34.390
That's how this folder is, all right,
sitting right on my desktop.

747
00:37:34.390 --> 00:37:39.955
When I take that folder and I move it,
so I'm gonna move it into Work Files.

748
00:37:39.955 --> 00:37:41.325
Work Files,

749
00:37:41.325 --> 00:37:46.165
we saw just a moment ago that Work Files
have a lot of permissions on it.

750
00:37:46.165 --> 00:37:49.955
It's got, Wes has read and write,
teachers read and write, me read and

751
00:37:49.955 --> 00:37:53.285
write, staff has read only,
everyone has read only.

752
00:37:53.285 --> 00:37:57.315
If I take a look at the new folder,
Research, and

753
00:37:57.315 --> 00:38:00.120
I pull it up, look at what it has.

754
00:38:00.120 --> 00:38:03.430
It did not inherit
the permissions of the parent.

755
00:38:03.430 --> 00:38:07.510
It kept me with read and write,
staff read only, everyone else no access.

756
00:38:07.510 --> 00:38:10.260
So, if you make a new folder or

757
00:38:10.260 --> 00:38:14.570
you make a new file, it'll inherit the
permissions of the folder you put it in.

758
00:38:14.570 --> 00:38:17.210
So those are gonna stay the same.

759
00:38:17.210 --> 00:38:21.571
But if you move a file into there,
then it's gonna change.

760
00:38:21.571 --> 00:38:24.372
Then it's gonna change and,
well it doesn't change,

761
00:38:24.372 --> 00:38:26.610
the folder permission kinda change.

762
00:38:26.610 --> 00:38:30.200
The source file will retain
the permissions that it had

763
00:38:30.200 --> 00:38:31.630
from where it came from, right?

764
00:38:31.630 --> 00:38:32.690
So that doesn't change.

765
00:38:32.690 --> 00:38:35.530
The exception is if you're coming
from like removable media or

766
00:38:35.530 --> 00:38:38.070
a separate hard drive,
cuz then when you move,

767
00:38:38.070 --> 00:38:42.400
you're technically creating a new file
on this drive, and then it will inherit.

768
00:38:42.400 --> 00:38:43.935
And that's where it really gets weird,
right,

769
00:38:43.935 --> 00:38:45.404
now permissions are going
all over the place.

770
00:38:45.404 --> 00:38:48.296
So it's a good idea that if
you're creating something new,

771
00:38:48.296 --> 00:38:51.811
you don't worry about it, but
any time you move something into a folder,

772
00:38:51.811 --> 00:38:53.700
double check the permissions.

773
00:38:53.700 --> 00:38:56.420
Double check to make sure it ended up
with the permissions that you expected it

774
00:38:56.420 --> 00:38:57.210
to have.

775
00:38:57.210 --> 00:39:00.510
Cuz if I leave it like this,
I might know, hey Wes has read and

776
00:39:00.510 --> 00:39:01.640
write to the Work Files folder.

777
00:39:01.640 --> 00:39:04.320
I'm gonna put this in here and
he'll have access, right?

778
00:39:04.320 --> 00:39:09.280
Well no, he doesn't have access because
only me and, well a staff has read only,

779
00:39:09.280 --> 00:39:11.350
I guess Wes would be in staff so
you'd have read only, but

780
00:39:11.350 --> 00:39:12.510
you wouldn't have read write.

781
00:39:12.510 --> 00:39:15.030
Wes wouldn't have the permissions I
expected him to because of the way

782
00:39:15.030 --> 00:39:15.770
inheritance was handled.

783
00:39:15.770 --> 00:39:19.190
So just be aware that's a little bit of a
pitfall that you can kinda step into when

784
00:39:19.190 --> 00:39:20.889
you're dealing with shared folders.

785
00:39:20.889 --> 00:39:22.943
>> Well Don, thank you for
all that great information.

786
00:39:22.943 --> 00:39:26.042
And hopefully you know a little
bit more about file sharing,

787
00:39:26.042 --> 00:39:27.700
the wonderful topic that it is.

788
00:39:27.700 --> 00:39:28.810
But we're gonna go ahead and

789
00:39:28.810 --> 00:39:31.060
it does look like we're coming
to the end another episode.

790
00:39:31.060 --> 00:39:33.063
So we're gonna take this time
to sign out for ITProTV.

791
00:39:33.063 --> 00:39:34.364
I've been your host Wes Bryan.

792
00:39:34.364 --> 00:39:35.420
>> And I'm Don Pezet.

793
00:39:35.420 --> 00:39:37.867
>> And we'll see you next time.

794
00:39:37.867 --> 00:39:43.708
[MUSIC]

episodes.description: In this episode, Wes and Don demonstrate setting up a Caching Server inside of Mac OS X. They cover the basic considerations to be aware of when setting up a Caching Server. They discuss the type of content that can be cached including storage and supporting multiple subnet environments.
episodes.title: Caching Server
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.000 --> 00:00:10.000
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:12.061 --> 00:00:15.051
Welcome back to another exciting
episode here at ITProTV.

3
00:00:15.051 --> 00:00:17.080
I'm your host Wes Bryan and

4
00:00:17.080 --> 00:00:21.610
in today's episode we're moving
through our OS X server essentials.

5
00:00:21.610 --> 00:00:24.870
And we're getting into implementing
deployment solutions, and

6
00:00:24.870 --> 00:00:27.610
more specifically,
a topic known as the caching server.

7
00:00:27.610 --> 00:00:30.550
Helping us out with the caching server
is none other than Mr. Don Pezet.

8
00:00:30.550 --> 00:00:31.940
Don, how you doing today, sir?

9
00:00:31.940 --> 00:00:32.800
>> I'm doing great, Wes.

10
00:00:32.800 --> 00:00:34.710
Ready to dive right into
the caching service.

11
00:00:34.710 --> 00:00:36.380
And for
those of you that aren't familiar with it,

12
00:00:36.380 --> 00:00:39.430
the caching service actually a neat little
system that's a part of the server app.

13
00:00:39.430 --> 00:00:42.870
Is designed to make it where you can
more quickly distribute files and

14
00:00:42.870 --> 00:00:47.480
updates across your Mac while using
the minimal amount of bandwidth possible.

15
00:00:47.480 --> 00:00:51.730
This is great in areas where you
don't have a giant WAN link or

16
00:00:51.730 --> 00:00:54.470
you just have a ton of Macs and you want
things to be a little more efficient.

17
00:00:54.470 --> 00:00:56.380
The caching service works really well for
that.

18
00:00:56.380 --> 00:00:58.630
So that's what we're gonna be diving
into right here in this episode.

19
00:00:58.630 --> 00:01:03.270
>> So Don, when we look at the caching
server, I've got my server app it's open,

20
00:01:03.270 --> 00:01:04.170
it's ready to go.

21
00:01:04.170 --> 00:01:06.760
I need to do some configuring,
you're gonna help us out with that.

22
00:01:06.760 --> 00:01:07.790
How do we configure it?

23
00:01:07.790 --> 00:01:09.180
>> All right, this is my favorite one.

24
00:01:09.180 --> 00:01:12.521
Out of all the stuff in this show,
the caching server literally,

25
00:01:12.521 --> 00:01:14.486
there's an on switch and that's it.

26
00:01:14.486 --> 00:01:17.806
Like everything else that we've seen in
this series, you gotta do configurations,

27
00:01:17.806 --> 00:01:19.526
you got all these options to turn on and
off.

28
00:01:19.526 --> 00:01:22.250
The caching server,
we just flip an on switch.

29
00:01:22.250 --> 00:01:24.310
So it's super simple to configure.

30
00:01:24.310 --> 00:01:27.550
Apple wanted to make this one
as easy to deploy as possible.

31
00:01:27.550 --> 00:01:30.300
In fact,
there really just isn't much to it.

32
00:01:30.300 --> 00:01:32.200
But let's talk a little
bit about how it works and

33
00:01:32.200 --> 00:01:34.780
what it does to make sure
your deploying it correctly.

34
00:01:34.780 --> 00:01:37.440
And you might be asking what do I need?

35
00:01:37.440 --> 00:01:39.430
If it's just on switch,
how can you deploy it incorrectly?

36
00:01:39.430 --> 00:01:42.820
Well, we have a slight thing
that we need to be aware of,

37
00:01:42.820 --> 00:01:45.120
a big gotcha that kind of sits out there.

38
00:01:45.120 --> 00:01:49.690
Which is that the caching
server is not compatible

39
00:01:49.690 --> 00:01:51.110
with the software update server.

40
00:01:51.110 --> 00:01:54.070
Now, we're going to talk about the
software update server in our next episode

41
00:01:54.070 --> 00:01:55.900
and get a look at in how it works.

42
00:01:55.900 --> 00:01:58.200
But the two of them
are mutually exclusive.

43
00:01:58.200 --> 00:02:02.030
You can have one or
the other you can't have both.

44
00:02:02.030 --> 00:02:06.150
Because both of them provide
the ability to distribute updates.

45
00:02:06.150 --> 00:02:07.400
The caching server.

46
00:02:07.400 --> 00:02:10.920
What happens with the caching server
is when there's an update available,

47
00:02:10.920 --> 00:02:13.560
one of the Macs on your network
is gonna find that update.

48
00:02:13.560 --> 00:02:14.610
It's gonna reach out to Apple,

49
00:02:14.610 --> 00:02:16.510
Apple's gonna say hey look I've
got a new update for you, and

50
00:02:16.510 --> 00:02:18.240
the Mac's gonna download it.

51
00:02:18.240 --> 00:02:22.120
When that Mac downloads it,
if it's connected to a caching server,

52
00:02:22.120 --> 00:02:25.660
a copy of the update will be
stored on the caching server.

53
00:02:25.660 --> 00:02:30.340
From then on, if any other Mac
goes to download that update,

54
00:02:30.340 --> 00:02:31.830
it'll just get it from the caching server.

55
00:02:31.830 --> 00:02:34.060
Instead of going out to the Internet.

56
00:02:34.060 --> 00:02:35.720
Now, if you just have five Macs.

57
00:02:35.720 --> 00:02:37.030
Is that a big deal?

58
00:02:37.030 --> 00:02:38.160
It really isn't.

59
00:02:38.160 --> 00:02:38.720
Here in the studio.

60
00:02:38.720 --> 00:02:40.840
How many Macs do we even have around here,
Wes?

61
00:02:40.840 --> 00:02:42.400
We probably have-
>> 10, 15.

62
00:02:42.400 --> 00:02:43.440
>> Yeah, 10 or 15 of them, right?

63
00:02:43.440 --> 00:02:44.470
So, not a ton.

64
00:02:44.470 --> 00:02:46.940
But we've probably got 10 or
15 Macs here in the studios.

65
00:02:46.940 --> 00:02:48.650
And so, for us,
we don't have a caching server.

66
00:02:48.650 --> 00:02:49.700
We've got 10 or 15 Macs.

67
00:02:49.700 --> 00:02:52.625
If we need to download an update,
we download it 10 or 15 times and

68
00:02:52.625 --> 00:02:53.765
then that's it.

69
00:02:53.765 --> 00:02:58.825
But imagine if you had 2,000 Macs and
you're about to download

70
00:02:58.825 --> 00:03:02.885
the El Capitan installer or
any of the El Capitan updates.

71
00:03:02.885 --> 00:03:05.950
The El Capitan updates
are a good 800 to 900 megs each.

72
00:03:05.950 --> 00:03:10.790
If you have 1,000 Macs that's a lot of
bandwidth you're gonna eat up downloading

73
00:03:10.790 --> 00:03:13.630
the same update over and
over and over and over again.

74
00:03:13.630 --> 00:03:17.050
So, it makes sense to deploy
a caching server on the network.

75
00:03:17.050 --> 00:03:20.920
If you have a caching server,
one person will download the update and

76
00:03:20.920 --> 00:03:24.420
once they've downloaded, it everybody
else just gets the update right from that

77
00:03:24.420 --> 00:03:26.890
local server instead of
reaching all the way to Apple.

78
00:03:26.890 --> 00:03:28.720
So, two things happen.

79
00:03:28.720 --> 00:03:30.820
One you use less Internet bandwidth,
right.

80
00:03:30.820 --> 00:03:32.870
So if you have a data cap or
whatever it helps.

81
00:03:32.870 --> 00:03:34.090
Most of us don't have data caps though.

82
00:03:34.090 --> 00:03:36.155
So it's just kinda
minimizing that bandwidth.

83
00:03:36.155 --> 00:03:40.075
And the second thing is you're
gonna get the update faster.

84
00:03:40.075 --> 00:03:40.935
What do I mean by that?

85
00:03:40.935 --> 00:03:43.205
Well, what's your Internet bandwidth?

86
00:03:43.205 --> 00:03:47.765
Here in our building, we have fiber
optic Internet, and it's 80 megabit.

87
00:03:47.765 --> 00:03:50.435
So we have 80 megs of Internet bandwidth,
and that's pretty good.

88
00:03:50.435 --> 00:03:53.145
A lot of people have far,
far worse connections than that.

89
00:03:53.145 --> 00:03:53.915
We have 80 megabits.

90
00:03:53.915 --> 00:03:56.235
So if we go and download it,
that's what we're gonna download it at.

91
00:03:56.235 --> 00:03:57.495
That sounds great.

92
00:03:57.495 --> 00:04:01.625
But, if the update is sitting on
a server here on my local network,

93
00:04:01.625 --> 00:04:04.710
our local network is gigabit, right.

94
00:04:04.710 --> 00:04:08.620
Gigabit, it's over ten times the bandwidth
of that 80 meg Internet connection.

95
00:04:08.620 --> 00:04:10.910
It's a significant speed improvement.

96
00:04:10.910 --> 00:04:14.190
So we can download the update
from a caching server way faster

97
00:04:14.190 --> 00:04:16.470
than we can download it
from Apple servers itself,

98
00:04:16.470 --> 00:04:18.430
even though we've got a great
Internet connection, all right.

99
00:04:18.430 --> 00:04:21.640
So, that's another advantage of the
caching servers that it can push updates

100
00:04:21.640 --> 00:04:23.370
far, far faster.

101
00:04:23.370 --> 00:04:28.060
Now, why is it not compatible
with the software update server?

102
00:04:28.060 --> 00:04:29.280
Well the reason is,

103
00:04:29.280 --> 00:04:33.350
on the software update server,
you can download updates from Apple.

104
00:04:33.350 --> 00:04:36.520
And you can distribute the updates
out to your own clients right from

105
00:04:36.520 --> 00:04:37.830
a central machine.

106
00:04:37.830 --> 00:04:42.240
The big difference is on the software
update server, you can approve and

107
00:04:42.240 --> 00:04:43.490
deny updates.

108
00:04:43.490 --> 00:04:45.240
You can enable and disable updates.

109
00:04:45.240 --> 00:04:48.890
So let's say that a new
version of Safari comes out.

110
00:04:48.890 --> 00:04:53.150
And you have an application that doesn't
work in the newest version of Safari.

111
00:04:53.150 --> 00:04:56.810
You can go in the software update server
and you can say disable that update.

112
00:04:56.810 --> 00:05:00.250
And now the Safari update won't
push out to your work stations or

113
00:05:00.250 --> 00:05:03.180
new iTunes or something like
that you can block things or

114
00:05:03.180 --> 00:05:05.860
you can approve things you can do
that often software update server.

115
00:05:05.860 --> 00:05:07.710
On a caching server you can't.

116
00:05:07.710 --> 00:05:11.040
On a caching server it's just caching.

117
00:05:11.040 --> 00:05:12.680
People can do whatever
update they want and

118
00:05:12.680 --> 00:05:14.670
it's gonna get cached and
it's gonna be distributed.

119
00:05:14.670 --> 00:05:17.650
You have no control over saying yes or
no to an update.

120
00:05:17.650 --> 00:05:20.890
So if you want control,
you gotta go software update.

121
00:05:20.890 --> 00:05:22.920
If you don't want control,
you can go caching.

122
00:05:22.920 --> 00:05:26.110
Well, in my world that's a no-brainer.

123
00:05:26.110 --> 00:05:27.770
I'm just gonna go software update then.

124
00:05:27.770 --> 00:05:31.080
I'd rather have that control then
not have it and there we go.

125
00:05:31.080 --> 00:05:34.140
But, there's a nice little feature
about the caching server I

126
00:05:34.140 --> 00:05:35.400
haven't mentioned yet.

127
00:05:35.400 --> 00:05:40.100
And that is it can cache a lot
more than just updates, right?

128
00:05:40.100 --> 00:05:42.510
Updates are the main thing, right?

129
00:05:42.510 --> 00:05:47.490
But it can also cache things like anything
you've purchased to the App Store, right?

130
00:05:47.490 --> 00:05:51.750
All the apps in the Mac app
store it can cache those.

131
00:05:51.750 --> 00:05:53.650
All the updates I've already mentioned.

132
00:05:53.650 --> 00:05:56.320
Any books that you've
purchased through iBooks.

133
00:05:56.320 --> 00:05:59.090
Any volume purchase program
stuff from iBooks and

134
00:05:59.090 --> 00:06:01.980
the App Store it can cache those too.

135
00:06:01.980 --> 00:06:05.250
It can cache
the Internet Recovery Partition.

136
00:06:05.250 --> 00:06:06.440
That's a cool one, right?

137
00:06:06.440 --> 00:06:08.850
When you boot your Mac and
the hard drive's completely wiped and

138
00:06:08.850 --> 00:06:12.150
you do Internet recovery, it's gonna
download that from Apple's servers,

139
00:06:12.150 --> 00:06:14.110
it's 700 megs, it takes a little while.

140
00:06:14.110 --> 00:06:17.260
Well your caching server can cache
the entire Internet recovery partition.

141
00:06:17.260 --> 00:06:18.860
And now when you boot a Mac,

142
00:06:18.860 --> 00:06:21.270
it's gonna boot off of that local
copy of the Internet recovery.

143
00:06:21.270 --> 00:06:24.990
It's a pretty sweet feature right there,
so makes troubleshooting go a lot faster.

144
00:06:24.990 --> 00:06:28.900
Same thing with Apple TV updates we
can go beyond what we have in just our

145
00:06:28.900 --> 00:06:29.860
regular systems.

146
00:06:29.860 --> 00:06:31.560
So it's really neat stuff.

147
00:06:31.560 --> 00:06:36.130
>> Don, when it comes to deploying your
caching server here are we talking

148
00:06:36.130 --> 00:06:40.790
about taking astronomical
readings Geological surveys.

149
00:06:40.790 --> 00:06:43.840
When it comes to the deployment here,
how complex is it?

150
00:06:43.840 --> 00:06:47.330
>> It's really the simplest one
to turn on, imaginable, right.

151
00:06:47.330 --> 00:06:48.050
In fact, let me show you.

152
00:06:48.050 --> 00:06:51.180
Cuz I can talk about this stuff but then
seeing it in action is a different story.

153
00:06:51.180 --> 00:06:52.860
So I'm gonna connect to my server here.

154
00:06:52.860 --> 00:06:56.670
And let's say that I want this
server to be a caching server, okay.

155
00:06:56.670 --> 00:06:59.960
So, first I'm gonna download
all my documentation so

156
00:06:59.960 --> 00:07:01.910
I can redo my steps, right.

157
00:07:01.910 --> 00:07:03.360
Well not really on this one.

158
00:07:03.360 --> 00:07:07.430
On this one, we can go in to our server
app, you can go over here to services and

159
00:07:07.430 --> 00:07:08.890
find caching.

160
00:07:08.890 --> 00:07:13.320
And on the caching screen,
you can hit the on button.

161
00:07:13.320 --> 00:07:14.610
And now you are a caching server.

162
00:07:14.610 --> 00:07:17.480
Just like that it's done and
you are caching, okay.

163
00:07:17.480 --> 00:07:21.100
There are actually a couple of options
right in here that we can tweak, but

164
00:07:21.100 --> 00:07:24.670
by default if you just turn it on you
are caching server in your business.

165
00:07:24.670 --> 00:07:27.550
Okay, so
what are some of this other options.

166
00:07:27.550 --> 00:07:29.360
Well, if you look at it
there is permissions, right.

167
00:07:29.360 --> 00:07:31.850
The default is it's only
set to local subnet.

168
00:07:31.850 --> 00:07:34.689
In other words, if somebody is out there
on the Internet you don't wanna cache for

169
00:07:34.689 --> 00:07:37.010
them they're in the Internet,
they can just go to Apple, right?

170
00:07:37.010 --> 00:07:40.283
But if they're local, if they're in your
building, you wanna provide a cache for

171
00:07:40.283 --> 00:07:42.100
them and that's the default.

172
00:07:42.100 --> 00:07:45.780
You can adjust that if you want or
you can leave like it is right here..

173
00:07:45.780 --> 00:07:48.370
And it will just do it for

00:19:52.330 --> 00:19:53.740
I'm going through 209.251.159.179.

393
00:19:53.740 --> 00:19:56.890
And so when I reach out to Apple,

394
00:19:56.890 --> 00:20:02.050
that's how Apple sees me, and
that's the same as this server.

395
00:20:02.050 --> 00:20:06.390
This server that's caching that data and
storing it right here inside of that

396
00:20:06.390 --> 00:20:09.580
caching server,
because we have the same public address.

397
00:20:09.580 --> 00:20:12.260
If I had different public addresses,
it wouldn't work.

398
00:20:12.260 --> 00:20:15.450
So, for
example if I have a central office, and

399
00:20:15.450 --> 00:20:18.930
then a bunch of branch offices, if each
branch office has their own internet

400
00:20:18.930 --> 00:20:21.350
connection, they're gonna have
a different public IP, they're

401
00:20:21.350 --> 00:20:24.380
not going to use the caching server
at headquarters, and that make sense.

402
00:20:24.380 --> 00:20:26.020
Cuz if you're going to have to
go out to the internet anyway,

403
00:20:26.020 --> 00:20:27.140
you might as well go to Apple and

404
00:20:27.140 --> 00:20:29.630
use their bandwidth instead of
using your headquarter's bandwidth.

405
00:20:29.630 --> 00:20:33.900
You really only wanna provide services for
people on the same network as you.

406
00:20:33.900 --> 00:20:35.494
So that's kinda a key component there,

407
00:20:35.494 --> 00:20:38.990
the caching server will only work
if the clients are going out

408
00:20:38.990 --> 00:20:42.450
to the internet with the same IP
address as the caching servers.

409
00:20:42.450 --> 00:20:45.280
So that's how we kinda make that happen.

410
00:20:45.280 --> 00:20:48.220
All right, now the cache,
it's being stored here on the hard drive.

411
00:20:48.220 --> 00:20:49.390
Let's take a look at that.

412
00:20:49.390 --> 00:20:51.500
Really, Apple doesn't want us
to mess with the cache too much.

413
00:20:51.500 --> 00:20:53.160
The cache is protected.

414
00:20:53.160 --> 00:20:56.240
The reason it's protected is,
imagine this,

415
00:20:56.240 --> 00:21:00.790
imagine we downloaded an El Capitan update
and it was stored here in the cache.

416
00:21:00.790 --> 00:21:03.360
And then somebody wanted to be
malicious and they went in and

417
00:21:03.360 --> 00:21:06.120
they modified the update,
they put some malware in it.

418
00:21:06.120 --> 00:21:08.810
And now every client on your network
goes to download that update,

419
00:21:08.810 --> 00:21:12.100
and they get this modified
copy from your server.

420
00:21:12.100 --> 00:21:13.770
They're not going to get
a modified copy from Apple,

421
00:21:13.770 --> 00:21:16.410
they would have got a good
update from Apple, but from us,

422
00:21:16.410 --> 00:21:18.740
they're now getting a modified
copy that's got malware in it, and

423
00:21:18.740 --> 00:21:20.350
it'll distribute through
your whole network.

424
00:21:20.350 --> 00:21:22.500
So the cache needs to protected.

425
00:21:22.500 --> 00:21:25.670
So it is, it's stuck on the hard drive,
and it's stuck in there in a way that we

426
00:21:25.670 --> 00:21:29.500
can't really mess with it, and if we do
mess with it, it invalidates the files.

427
00:21:29.500 --> 00:21:31.740
Apple does a digital
signature on every file so

428
00:21:31.740 --> 00:21:33.810
if they get tampered with
it just throws them away.

429
00:21:33.810 --> 00:21:35.560
But you can see them.

430
00:21:35.560 --> 00:21:38.280
Let me jump into my terminal here and
I'll show you where they are.

431
00:21:38.280 --> 00:21:40.880
There's not really a need for
you to ever go into this thing.

432
00:21:43.100 --> 00:21:48.220
If the cache ever fills up, it'll delete
old files to make room for new files.

433
00:21:48.220 --> 00:21:51.117
So you never really have to go in here
to delete anything or worry about it,

434
00:21:51.117 --> 00:21:52.586
it's all designed to be automatic.

435
00:21:52.586 --> 00:21:57.191
But if I go into /Library/Server,
so just right off the root,

436
00:21:57.191 --> 00:22:02.140
/Library/Server and you take a look
in there you'll see we've got

437
00:22:02.140 --> 00:22:07.290
a caching folder, and
inside of caching there's a data folder.

438
00:22:07.290 --> 00:22:12.610
Now that data folder, I can see it
right here, that's where the cache is.

439
00:22:12.610 --> 00:22:16.270
And if I browse into it,
I get permission denied.

440
00:22:16.270 --> 00:22:17.790
It's protected.

441
00:22:17.790 --> 00:22:21.570
I'm an admin, but it is not gonna let
me in get in and mess with that folder.

442
00:22:21.570 --> 00:22:24.834
And if you try the tried-and-trued,
like sudo commands,

443
00:22:24.834 --> 00:22:28.229
sudo doesn't really work with
the change directory command.

444
00:22:28.229 --> 00:22:31.755
So if I try that,
it's gonna try move me in there and

445
00:22:31.755 --> 00:22:34.052
then I move right back out again.

446
00:22:34.052 --> 00:22:35.710
And so, see, I'm not in the data folder.

447
00:22:35.710 --> 00:22:38.520
So, they're really trying to protect that
to make sure we can't get in there, but

448
00:22:38.520 --> 00:22:40.508
you can if you do like a sudo sh.

449
00:22:40.508 --> 00:22:45.840
So I'm gonna drop to a root shell,
which Apple really doesn't want you to do.

450
00:22:45.840 --> 00:22:49.980
But I can drop to a root shell and
now I can get right into that data folder.

451
00:22:49.980 --> 00:22:51.700
And once you're in there you
can start to see the cache.

452
00:22:51.700 --> 00:22:54.370
Now, the cache isn't going
to mean a whole lot to you.

453
00:22:54.370 --> 00:22:57.970
The main file is this guy right here,
AssetInfo.db.

454
00:22:57.970 --> 00:23:01.900
That's the database where it keeps
track of all the files that is cached.

455
00:23:01.900 --> 00:23:04.240
So when a client goes to download a file,
it asks us,

456
00:23:04.240 --> 00:23:05.780
hey do you have a copy of this file?

457
00:23:05.780 --> 00:23:08.300
And we just look at the database,
is it in my database?

458
00:23:08.300 --> 00:23:10.080
Yes or no?
If it's not in the database,

459
00:23:10.080 --> 00:23:12.260
I don't have it,
let's get it from the Internet.

460
00:23:12.260 --> 00:23:15.099
If it is in my database, I have it,
and I'll serve it up to the end user.

461
00:23:16.150 --> 00:23:20.990
Now, see this shm folder right here,
that's part of the security for

462
00:23:20.990 --> 00:23:21.600
this database.

463
00:23:21.600 --> 00:23:23.600
That's where our digital signatures are,
our hashing.

464
00:23:23.600 --> 00:23:25.870
So that's all being kind
of stored in there and

465
00:23:25.870 --> 00:23:29.290
then you've got a wal file
which is part of its indexing.

466
00:23:29.290 --> 00:23:32.160
So that's all part of that database.

467
00:23:32.160 --> 00:23:36.130
All these other folders
represent cached files.

468
00:23:36.130 --> 00:23:40.840
These are all UIDs, it's the unique
identifiers for the cached files.

469
00:23:40.840 --> 00:23:43.774
Because we could cache all sorts of
things, apps, updates, whatever.

470
00:23:43.774 --> 00:23:46.139
So everyone gets an ID, and
they don't really mean much to us.

471
00:23:46.139 --> 00:23:49.498
One of these will be that
digital camera update.

472
00:23:49.498 --> 00:23:52.240
Another of these will
be the iTunes update.

473
00:23:52.240 --> 00:23:54.880
A third one will be the Yosemite update.

474
00:23:56.110 --> 00:23:58.080
I mean El Capitan,
whatever it is we're using here,

475
00:23:58.080 --> 00:24:00.380
the 10.11.4 update for El Capitan.

476
00:24:00.380 --> 00:24:03.440
The other ones,
I don't know what the heck they are.

477
00:24:03.440 --> 00:24:06.620
Well, your Macs,
they do a lot of things in the background.

478
00:24:06.620 --> 00:24:11.560
They get various security updates and
things from Apple that don't show up as

479
00:24:11.560 --> 00:24:14.610
regular updates that are manually
pushed by Apple that you don't see.

480
00:24:14.610 --> 00:24:16.650
And so that'll probably be some of these.

481
00:24:16.650 --> 00:24:19.324
Or other things that we've reached out
to Apple for that have been cached.

482
00:24:19.324 --> 00:24:20.440
So it caches stuff automatically.

483
00:24:20.440 --> 00:24:22.310
You'll see things pop up
in here all the time.

484
00:24:22.310 --> 00:24:24.140
>> All right, Don,
I got another scenario for you.

485
00:24:24.140 --> 00:24:27.740
So far we've saved some bandwidth
having our caching server, but

486
00:24:27.740 --> 00:24:29.410
now management comes in and
says you know what?

487
00:24:29.410 --> 00:24:32.580
We don't have 2,000 Macs anymore,
now we got 10,000 Macs.

488
00:24:32.580 --> 00:24:36.490
While our bandwidth on the WAN
side is doing really good, man,

489
00:24:36.490 --> 00:24:40.248
our poor caching server,
it's just not doing so good anymore.

490
00:24:40.248 --> 00:24:45.220
So we decide we're gonna scale out and add
one or more caching servers to help our

491
00:24:45.220 --> 00:24:48.100
poor original caching server that
just isn't cutting the mustard.

492
00:24:48.100 --> 00:24:49.740
What can we expect to see there?

493
00:24:49.740 --> 00:24:52.737
>> All right,
you can do more than one caching server.

494
00:24:52.737 --> 00:24:55.840
You'll generally find it
doesn't work as well, right.

495
00:24:55.840 --> 00:24:59.050
That you'll have files that get cached
on one and not on the other, and so

496
00:24:59.050 --> 00:25:03.040
generally you don't want to do multiple
caching servers if you can avoid it.

497
00:25:03.040 --> 00:25:08.690
Really one caching server per public IP
network is really the way to go about it.

498
00:25:08.690 --> 00:25:11.920
You might have more than one subnet but
just one server per is the best.

499
00:25:11.920 --> 00:25:14.500
That way,
you've got a consistent database of

500
00:25:14.500 --> 00:25:17.330
all the cached files right there in one.

501
00:25:17.330 --> 00:25:19.680
The better solution is to add
more network adapters to it.

502
00:25:19.680 --> 00:25:22.406
You can add more network adapters
to it to increase the bandwidth.

503
00:25:22.406 --> 00:25:24.650
You can even bond network
adapters together.

504
00:25:24.650 --> 00:25:28.170
So if you have a gig adapter, you could
put two gigabit adapters in there and

505
00:25:28.170 --> 00:25:29.880
bond them together to
increase that bandwidth.

506
00:25:29.880 --> 00:25:32.820
So there's technologies like that to make
it where one server could do more for

507
00:25:32.820 --> 00:25:33.530
you, but

508
00:25:33.530 --> 00:25:37.140
you're always better off having one server
as opposed to more if you can avoid it.

509
00:25:37.140 --> 00:25:40.179
>> Now you did say that in
multiple geographical locations,

510
00:25:40.179 --> 00:25:43.164
a caching server really isn't intended for
that point.

511
00:25:43.164 --> 00:25:46.485
Would the same advice apply
to multiple geographical

512
00:25:46.485 --> 00:25:49.460
locations about multiple caching servers?

513
00:25:49.460 --> 00:25:50.430
>> Well, a little different.

514
00:25:50.430 --> 00:25:52.940
You still want one caching server,
one at each location.

515
00:25:52.940 --> 00:25:54.820
So let's use a school as an example,
right?

516
00:25:54.820 --> 00:25:58.090
So here in the United States our
schools are divided up into counties.

517
00:25:58.090 --> 00:26:02.970
And so you usually have a central county
office and then you'll have any number of

518
00:26:02.970 --> 00:26:07.223
elementary schools or high schools or
whatever located throughout.

519
00:26:07.223 --> 00:26:10.880
So let's say that I'm at a location
where you've got the central office and

520
00:26:10.880 --> 00:26:13.250
then you've got 100 schools.

521
00:26:13.250 --> 00:26:16.670
What I would need is 101 caching servers.

522
00:26:16.670 --> 00:26:20.540
I'd need one caching server at the central
office and then one caching server at

523
00:26:20.540 --> 00:26:24.510
every single school, assuming the schools
had enough machines to make it worthwhile.

524
00:26:24.510 --> 00:26:26.020
Some schools might be really small.

525
00:26:26.020 --> 00:26:29.430
They might only have 50 computers, and
so I don't worry about a caching server.

526
00:26:29.430 --> 00:26:31.760
Other schools might be bigger and
have 2,000 computers, and so

527
00:26:31.760 --> 00:26:33.130
I do put a caching server.

528
00:26:33.130 --> 00:26:35.720
It's up to us how you wanna do that.

529
00:26:35.720 --> 00:26:38.343
And remember your caching server
can be used for other stuff too, so

530
00:26:38.343 --> 00:26:40.426
it could be a file server,
an open directory server.

531
00:26:40.426 --> 00:26:44.017
You'll probably want an open directory
server at those schools anyway for

532
00:26:44.017 --> 00:26:46.880
authentication, so
you turn it into a caching server too.

533
00:26:46.880 --> 00:26:50.590
It can do more than one role with
the exception of software update, right?

534
00:26:50.590 --> 00:26:52.750
You can't do caching and software update.

535
00:26:52.750 --> 00:26:55.360
And even if there are two separate boxes,
you're not supposed to do both.

536
00:26:55.360 --> 00:26:56.410
You gotta pick one or the other.

537
00:26:56.410 --> 00:26:59.290
If I have a caching server,
no software update server.

538
00:26:59.290 --> 00:27:01.565
If I have a software update server,
no caching server.

539
00:27:01.565 --> 00:27:04.490
Right, you gotta pick one or
the other at those locations.

540
00:27:04.490 --> 00:27:09.430
So if we deploy this,
it's not based on subnets.

541
00:27:09.430 --> 00:27:13.675
It's based on the WAN connectivity,
so geographic locations.

542
00:27:13.675 --> 00:27:15.644
One caching server per
geographic location,

543
00:27:15.644 --> 00:27:17.520
if there's enough machines to warrant it.

544
00:27:18.840 --> 00:27:21.930
All right, I guess if we wanted to go
a little bit further, I could browse into

545
00:27:21.930 --> 00:27:25.450
one of these folders and just kinda
show you how these updates get stored.

546
00:27:25.450 --> 00:27:30.420
It's kind of a mess when you really
dig all the way down into here.

547
00:27:30.420 --> 00:27:32.760
That's a 0 byte file,
that's not a good example.

548
00:27:32.760 --> 00:27:36.340
So I don't know the actual
identifiers here, so

549
00:27:36.340 --> 00:27:38.720
I kind of have to just poke around.

550
00:27:38.720 --> 00:27:41.730
So it must be in the process
of downloading a few of these.

551
00:27:43.880 --> 00:27:47.720
But they're not necessarily named
anything that we would recognize.

552
00:27:47.720 --> 00:27:52.250
Hm, I was kind of hoping to
find at least one [LAUGH]

553
00:27:52.250 --> 00:27:56.320
that could show us the file, but
I'm not having much luck here.

554
00:27:56.320 --> 00:27:57.831
So once it downloads them, though,

555
00:27:57.831 --> 00:28:00.188
they are just files that sit
right here on the hard drive.

556
00:28:00.188 --> 00:28:03.403
And they are hashed and signed so
that they can't be tampered with.

557
00:28:03.403 --> 00:28:07.083
And you can spot them in here, yeah,
these are all showing as 0 byte.

558
00:28:07.083 --> 00:28:11.731
But they do get stored in here somewhere
in each of these, so they'll turn up.

559
00:28:11.731 --> 00:28:14.140
One just appeared too, so yeah,
they're gonna keep popping up.

560
00:28:14.140 --> 00:28:16.180
But that stuff gets stored right there.

561
00:28:16.180 --> 00:28:18.950
It gets saved until we reset the cache.

562
00:28:18.950 --> 00:28:23.690
So if I go back to my server and I reset
the cache, it's gonna wipe that out and

563
00:28:23.690 --> 00:28:24.960
it's gonna empty the cache out.

564
00:28:24.960 --> 00:28:26.280
But I'm still a caching server, so

565
00:28:26.280 --> 00:28:30.630
as people go to download updates, they'll
just repopulate and start to grow again.

566
00:28:30.630 --> 00:28:33.400
In the background that database will
get updated to reflect that we don't

567
00:28:33.400 --> 00:28:34.440
have the cache.

568
00:28:34.440 --> 00:28:36.723
These folders don't
always disappear though.

569
00:28:36.723 --> 00:28:40.103
In my case they did, but they don't always
disappear because sometimes it's gonna

570
00:28:40.103 --> 00:28:43.450
immediately start re-downloading them
again and so they pop right back up again.

571
00:28:43.450 --> 00:28:44.680
I kind of assumed that would happen for

572
00:28:44.680 --> 00:28:47.120
me, but
in my case I can see they're all gone.

573
00:28:47.120 --> 00:28:50.530
I've now emptied out my cache, and it'll
just start to regrow as people update.

574
00:28:50.530 --> 00:28:53.109
>> Well, Don, thank you for showing us
the ins and out of the caching server.

575
00:28:53.109 --> 00:28:56.110
And I can tell you right now,
I think I'm gonna volunteer my services

576
00:28:56.110 --> 00:28:58.403
to help your clients connect
to the caching server.

577
00:28:58.403 --> 00:29:01.060
I think that's a job that I
can definitely handle there.

578
00:29:01.060 --> 00:29:04.250
But I do see that we're approaching
the end of the episode here.

579
00:29:04.250 --> 00:29:07.540
But before we do that,
do you have any parting advice?

580
00:29:07.540 --> 00:29:09.630
>> The main thing,
I know I've said it like 20 times now,

581
00:29:09.630 --> 00:29:12.610
is you do need to make that decision
between caching and software update.

582
00:29:12.610 --> 00:29:15.660
Watch the software update server show,
because you'll see in there that it's

583
00:29:15.660 --> 00:29:17.730
a very useful product and
it does a lot of things.

584
00:29:17.730 --> 00:29:20.320
So it's a powerful one,
it's one you'll probably want.

585
00:29:20.320 --> 00:29:22.970
I usually pick software
update over caching, right?

586
00:29:22.970 --> 00:29:26.175
But if you've got a guest wireless
network, that's a great place to have

587
00:29:26.175 --> 00:29:28.604
a caching server because you
have all of these guests and

588
00:29:28.604 --> 00:29:32.150
you want to minimize their bandwidth
consumption so you can use it there.

589
00:29:32.150 --> 00:29:34.360
But just don't mix and match the two.

590
00:29:34.360 --> 00:29:36.040
That's the main lesson to take away here.

591
00:29:36.040 --> 00:29:38.290
>> Well, we thank you for
all that knowledge on this subject.

592
00:29:38.290 --> 00:29:39.920
And we thank you,
the viewer, for watching us.

593
00:29:39.920 --> 00:29:42.400
But we're gonna go ahead and
take the time to sign out here at ITProTV.

594
00:29:42.400 --> 00:29:44.390
I've been your host Wes Bryan.

595
00:29:44.390 --> 00:29:45.090
>> And I'm Don Pezet.

596
00:29:45.090 --> 00:29:48.691
>> And we'll see you next time.

597
00:29:48.691 --> 00:29:54.900
[MUSIC]

episodes.description: In this episode, Wes and Don demonstrate setting up a Software Update Service inside of Mac OS X. They discuss the considerations to understand when deploying the Software Update Service and well as approving, downloading and removing updates from the database.

494
00:24:17.640 --> 00:24:21.230
I'm just gonna hit the power button and
hold the end key on my keyboard.

495
00:24:21.230 --> 00:24:23.500
I hear my Apple charm go off
in the background there.

496
00:24:23.500 --> 00:24:27.180
And what I should see,
assuming I'm holding the right letter,

497
00:24:27.180 --> 00:24:32.340
is I should see the Apple logo
appear with a little flashing globe.

498
00:24:32.340 --> 00:24:33.940
There's my flashing globe, all right?

499
00:24:33.940 --> 00:24:37.060
So the little globe is flashing so that
let's me know it's checking the network.

500
00:24:37.060 --> 00:24:40.270
It's looking to find a server
out there on the network.

501
00:24:40.270 --> 00:24:41.610
A net install server.

502
00:24:41.610 --> 00:24:42.950
And if it finds one,

503
00:24:42.950 --> 00:24:46.870
it's gonna kick into that boot
process to install the default image.

504
00:24:46.870 --> 00:24:49.680
And as soon as it finds the net
install server, this should change and

505
00:24:49.680 --> 00:24:51.580
I should see the Apple logo.

506
00:24:51.580 --> 00:24:53.360
And so
I'll probably see the Apple logo and

507
00:24:53.360 --> 00:24:55.920
the globe on the screen at
the same time for a brief while.

508
00:24:55.920 --> 00:24:58.730
And then as soon as that's done,
the globe will go away and

509
00:24:58.730 --> 00:25:01.590
be replaced by a progress bar as it
actually starts the installation.

510
00:25:01.590 --> 00:25:03.640
It's all happening in the background.

511
00:25:03.640 --> 00:25:06.870
And here on the Mac Mini,
all we see is the flashing globe,

512
00:25:06.870 --> 00:25:09.780
which, take a little longer
than it normally would.

513
00:25:09.780 --> 00:25:11.720
Let me just double check and

514
00:25:11.720 --> 00:25:14.620
make sure I got my network cable plugged
in, because that does make a difference.

515
00:25:14.620 --> 00:25:16.990
And we'll give that a moment.

516
00:25:16.990 --> 00:25:18.640
Sometimes I get impatient with this stuff.

517
00:25:18.640 --> 00:25:21.470
And the idea is you're supposed to
boot holding N, and then walk away.

518
00:25:21.470 --> 00:25:24.280
And you just walk away, leave and
let it run and do its thing, and

519
00:25:24.280 --> 00:25:25.930
eventually it finds a server.

520
00:25:25.930 --> 00:25:28.620
I can look on the server though and do
some basic trouble shooting if I'm trying

521
00:25:28.620 --> 00:25:31.950
to figure out what's going wrong so
let's jump over to my laptop and do that.

522
00:25:31.950 --> 00:25:35.300
If it's not connecting there must be
some problem or, well, there we go.

523
00:25:35.300 --> 00:25:37.090
Patience right?

524
00:25:37.090 --> 00:25:41.740
So we can see here the Apple logo let's me
know it did find the net install server

525
00:25:41.740 --> 00:25:44.260
and the globe was that it was
downloading the boot files.

526
00:25:44.260 --> 00:25:46.360
Boot files are like 30 megs, pretty small.

527
00:25:46.360 --> 00:25:49.620
Now is actually going and
kicking forward with the image.

528
00:25:49.620 --> 00:25:51.360
Right?
So all that happened if I'd just been

529
00:25:51.360 --> 00:25:52.380
patient and walked away.

530
00:25:52.380 --> 00:25:55.540
But let's say I was impatient and
I wanted to troubleshoot it anyway.

531
00:25:55.540 --> 00:25:58.620
Let me show you how I could have told
it was working even though I wasn't

532
00:25:58.620 --> 00:25:59.950
seeing that on the Mac.

533
00:25:59.950 --> 00:26:03.100
On my server If you up to Logs,

534
00:26:03.100 --> 00:26:08.110
in your logs you can filter your
Service Log bound to just net install.

535
00:26:08.110 --> 00:26:10.250
And when you filter to net install,

536
00:26:10.250 --> 00:26:15.420
what you should see are the DHCP
requests from the client.

537
00:26:15.420 --> 00:26:19.440
So, the Mac Mini fired up and I can
tell where it started right here at 955.

538
00:26:19.440 --> 00:26:21.590
Right?
Because I got a bunch of activity kicking

539
00:26:21.590 --> 00:26:25.120
of, or,
actually at 959 Is a little more accurate.

540
00:26:25.120 --> 00:26:27.510
So that's where I actually
kicked it on right there.

541
00:26:27.510 --> 00:26:31.960
Okay, and so looking at what I've got,
I've got a DHCP discover.

542
00:26:31.960 --> 00:26:35.110
The Mac Mini booted up and
said hey I need an IP address.

543
00:26:35.110 --> 00:26:39.240
And I offered an address to it,
I gave it 192.168.0.150, so

544
00:26:39.240 --> 00:26:43.610
then it sent the request to use it,
and we acknowledged it.

545
00:26:43.610 --> 00:26:48.330
So we've got that whole DORA part of DHCP,
the four step handshake.

546
00:26:48.330 --> 00:26:53.720
As soon as that was done, we got the boot
strap protocol kicking in right here.

547
00:26:53.720 --> 00:26:54.220
Right?

548
00:26:54.220 --> 00:26:58.400
So it's kicking in and
I offered it a net boot image.

549
00:26:58.400 --> 00:26:59.610
Those are the bootable files.

550
00:26:59.610 --> 00:27:02.220
I'm not actually using a net boot
image I'm using a net install.

551
00:27:02.220 --> 00:27:05.700
But it's net boot that
we actually boot off of.

552
00:27:05.700 --> 00:27:09.260
And it's showing the architecture for
it, and that this is a Mac Mini 7.1,

553
00:27:09.260 --> 00:27:12.170
that's the model the Mac made
that was authorized to use this.

554
00:27:12.170 --> 00:27:13.730
So it gets that.

555
00:27:13.730 --> 00:27:18.300
It acknowledged that it was gonna
boot off of those boot files.

556
00:27:18.300 --> 00:27:21.740
And once it booted off of the Boot files,
right,

557
00:27:21.740 --> 00:27:27.120
it revalidated its address,
it updated its lease on the IP address.

558
00:27:27.120 --> 00:27:30.710
And then it said okay now I'm ready
to actually install something.

559
00:27:30.710 --> 00:27:31.720
And so we've got it right here.

560
00:27:31.720 --> 00:27:34.300
BSDP INFORM, the server told it, hey,

561
00:27:34.300 --> 00:27:39.650
I need you to install this image here,
and it provided it another image.

562
00:27:39.650 --> 00:27:42.610
And now, it actually started the install.

563
00:27:42.610 --> 00:27:44.640
So the install should be running.

564
00:27:44.640 --> 00:27:47.090
Here's that acknowledgement where we
acknowledged that we were getting it.

565
00:27:47.090 --> 00:27:48.680
And see how it was a list here.

566
00:27:48.680 --> 00:27:50.020
Gave me a list of what's available.

567
00:27:50.020 --> 00:27:51.340
And here it's a select.

568
00:27:51.340 --> 00:27:54.950
Give me that default image and
we're gonna install it.

569
00:27:54.950 --> 00:27:58.210
And so now that Mac Mini is
starting the install process.

570
00:27:58.210 --> 00:27:59.470
And it's not much to see.

571
00:27:59.470 --> 00:28:02.510
If we jump back over to the Mac Mini,
it's an Apple logo on the screen and

572
00:28:02.510 --> 00:28:05.490
a little status bar that's
gonna crawl across the screen.

573
00:28:05.490 --> 00:28:07.930
And this is the bigger image.

574
00:28:07.930 --> 00:28:09.720
Right?
We did the student lab image.

575
00:28:09.720 --> 00:28:13.420
And so it's, I forget how big we said it
was, nine gigs or something like that.

576
00:28:13.420 --> 00:28:15.750
So it's got t o transfer all
that data across the network and

577
00:28:15.750 --> 00:28:17.280
it's going to take a while right?

578
00:28:17.280 --> 00:28:18.950
But at this point It is transferring.

579
00:28:18.950 --> 00:28:22.080
Now, interesting thing about this process,
is that,

580
00:28:22.080 --> 00:28:27.170
while it's at this state, I may or may not
actually see it in the connection screen.

581
00:28:27.170 --> 00:28:30.745
And, if I refresh here, yeah, I'm still
not showing it in the connection screen,

582
00:28:30.745 --> 00:28:32.460
because we're still at the Apple logo,
right.

583
00:28:32.460 --> 00:28:36.260
If we jump back over to the Mac Mini,
we'll see that it is just that Apple logo.

584
00:28:36.260 --> 00:28:38.110
As long as you're at this screen,

585
00:28:38.110 --> 00:28:40.460
it doesn't actually show
up in the connections yet.

586
00:28:40.460 --> 00:28:45.520
But, as soon as it advances past this,
then it's going to flip over and

587
00:28:45.520 --> 00:28:49.070
its going to start using the actual
connection to the server.

588
00:28:49.070 --> 00:28:50.540
And we will see it show up.

589
00:28:50.540 --> 00:28:53.780
The main thing that's going on here is
it's running a lot slower then before.

590
00:28:53.780 --> 00:28:57.570
And the reason is I had a cross over
cable run between the Mac Mini and

591
00:28:57.570 --> 00:28:59.450
my laptop a few moments ago.

592
00:28:59.450 --> 00:29:03.330
And I had to move off to a switch to make
sure that the net discovery would occur.

593
00:29:03.330 --> 00:29:06.480
Well, when I was on a crossover
cable I was at a gigabit,

594
00:29:06.480 --> 00:29:07.620
now I'm only at 100 megabits.

595
00:29:07.620 --> 00:29:09.580
So it's actually running
significantly slower.

596
00:29:09.580 --> 00:29:15.060
Kind of shows you how big an impact your
network speed can have on this process.

597
00:29:15.060 --> 00:29:19.040
But from this point,
it's identical to what we say earlier.

598
00:29:19.040 --> 00:29:21.130
The only difference is here is it's
just gonna use that default image.

599
00:29:21.130 --> 00:29:23.130
So it's gonna reach out to the server and
grab it.

600
00:29:23.130 --> 00:29:25.490
Install it, and when it's done,
it'll boot back up.

601
00:29:25.490 --> 00:29:28.250
And because I did the lab machine,
I should have Google Chrome,

602
00:29:28.250 --> 00:29:31.090
I should have the Apple Remote Desktop
account, all that stuff should still be

603
00:29:31.090 --> 00:29:34.980
present, because that's part of the net
restore image that we pushed out.

604
00:29:34.980 --> 00:29:37.390
>> All right Don,
a lot of great information, but

605
00:29:37.390 --> 00:29:39.860
it does look like we're coming to
the end of another great episode.

606
00:29:39.860 --> 00:29:41.984
But before we sign out,
you got anything else for us?

607
00:29:41.984 --> 00:29:46.100
>> Yeah, key thing, the thing we don't
see in the lab here that I do is

608
00:29:46.100 --> 00:29:47.550
definitely pay attention
to your bandwidth.

609
00:29:47.550 --> 00:29:49.870
Pay attention to how loaded
your servers get, and

610
00:29:49.870 --> 00:29:54.290
recognize that today you might not need
more than one net install server but

611
00:29:54.290 --> 00:29:56.970
down the road you might need more or
you might need to add a second or a third.

612
00:29:56.970 --> 00:29:59.770
And it's easy enough to do as long as
you keep your index number straight.

613
00:29:59.770 --> 00:30:04.550
It's a pretty straightforward system and
it makes deploying Mac OS pretty easy and

614
00:30:04.550 --> 00:30:05.860
even if you've got hundreds or

615
00:30:05.860 --> 00:30:08.300
thousands of machines you can
knock things out pretty quick.

616
00:30:08.300 --> 00:30:10.810
>> Well Don as always,
we appreciate you being in the studios and

617
00:30:10.810 --> 00:30:12.350
we appreciate you, the viewer watching.

618
00:30:12.350 --> 00:30:14.270
But we're gonna go ahead and
sign out for ITProTV.

619
00:30:14.270 --> 00:30:15.634
I've been your host, Wes Bryan.

620
00:30:15.634 --> 00:30:16.390
>> And I'm Don Pezet.

621
00:30:16.390 --> 00:30:18.654
>> And we'll see you next time.

622
00:30:18.654 --> 00:30:26.300
[MUSIC]

episodes.description: In this episode, Wes and Don demonstrate setting up a Time Machine server for centralized management of Time Machine backups. They discuss the considerations that should be taken into account before setting up a Time Machine server. They take a look at configuring storage for the Time Machine Server.
episodes.title: Time Machine
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.000 --> 00:00:10.000
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:11.647 --> 00:00:15.882
Welcome back to another exciting episode
here at ITProTV, I'm your host, Wes Bryan.

3
00:00:15.882 --> 00:00:19.437
And in today's episode we
are continuing through our series on

4
00:00:19.437 --> 00:00:24.211
Mac OS X Server Essentials, and we're
focusing in on providing network services.

5
00:00:24.211 --> 00:00:28.093
And today, we're gonna be taking a trip
back in time, driving 88.5 miles an hour,

6
00:00:28.093 --> 00:00:30.985
just kidding you here,
we're gonna be looking at Time Machine.

7
00:00:30.985 --> 00:00:33.063
And to help us out with that is Mr.
Don Pezet.

8
00:00:33.063 --> 00:00:34.283
Don, how're you doing today, sir?

9
00:00:34.283 --> 00:00:37.509
>> I am doing great, Wes, ready to dive
right back into OS X Server Essentials.

10
00:00:37.509 --> 00:00:40.092
And like Wes said, we're gonna be
taking a look at Time Machine.

11
00:00:40.092 --> 00:00:44.590
And I know what some of you guys are
thinking, we said network services, right?

12
00:00:44.590 --> 00:00:45.990
Time Machine is not a network service.

13
00:00:45.990 --> 00:00:49.450
If I have a desktop or a laptop,
I can just hook a hard drive up to it and

14
00:00:49.450 --> 00:00:51.120
do a Time Machine backup.

15
00:00:51.120 --> 00:00:55.152
Well, there actually is a network version
of Time Machine where we can set up

16
00:00:55.152 --> 00:00:58.176
a centralized server to
provide Time Machine services.

17
00:00:58.176 --> 00:01:00.575
And you'll see it's actually
not that hard to set up and

18
00:01:00.575 --> 00:01:02.470
there's a lot of good reasons to do that.

19
00:01:02.470 --> 00:01:06.470
So before I dive into that though, let's
just cover a couple of basics here to make

20
00:01:06.470 --> 00:01:08.640
sure that everybody's on the same page.

21
00:01:08.640 --> 00:01:11.365
I imagine if you're watching this
show that you've probably implemented

22
00:01:11.365 --> 00:01:12.191
Time Machine before.

23
00:01:12.191 --> 00:01:15.705
But if you haven't, let's just
kinda recap what that does, right?

24
00:01:15.705 --> 00:01:19.845
Time Machine is a built-in backup
program that's a part of OS X.

25
00:01:19.845 --> 00:01:23.275
And it's not necessarily
a part of the server app,

26
00:01:23.275 --> 00:01:25.405
it's a part of the base
operating system itself.

27
00:01:25.405 --> 00:01:30.041
So if you have a Mac that's been
manufactured in the last, probably

28
00:01:30.041 --> 00:01:34.700
like eight years I think, then it's going
to have Time Machine built into it.

29
00:01:34.700 --> 00:01:36.600
Now it's not turned on by default.

30
00:01:36.600 --> 00:01:39.580
So just because the support is there
doesn't mean you're actually running it,

31
00:01:39.580 --> 00:01:41.600
it is up to you to get it set up.

32
00:01:41.600 --> 00:01:46.440
The idea is that you could hook up a hard
drive, a Thunderbolt hard drive, or

33
00:01:46.440 --> 00:01:49.515
USB FireWire, or
even an extra internal hard drive, but

34
00:01:49.515 --> 00:01:51.215
some kind of extra hard drive.

35
00:01:51.215 --> 00:01:55.525
You hook it up to your system,
and the Mac will back itself up.

36
00:01:55.525 --> 00:01:58.025
And if there's ever a problem, and

37
00:01:58.025 --> 00:02:00.105
the problems could kind of span
several different sources.

38
00:02:00.105 --> 00:02:02.020
But if there's ever a problem,
you could go and

39
00:02:02.020 --> 00:02:05.250
restore your data from that hard drive,
so you don't lose any information.

40
00:02:05.250 --> 00:02:06.650
That's the nice part.

41
00:02:06.650 --> 00:02:09.680
Apple tried to make it
as easy as possible, so

42
00:02:09.680 --> 00:02:12.370
Time Machine is very flexible,
very simple to get going, and

43
00:02:12.370 --> 00:02:13.920
we're gonna see that as
we move through here.

44
00:02:13.920 --> 00:02:18.020
It's designed to be a simple technology
to make it a lot more approachable for

45
00:02:18.020 --> 00:02:19.310
regular end users.

46
00:02:19.310 --> 00:02:22.450
>> Don, with the Time Machine that's
built in, they really do make it easy.

47
00:02:22.450 --> 00:02:25.870
I've got a Western Digital drive,
1 terabyte, set up for Mac and everything.

48
00:02:25.870 --> 00:02:27.314
All I had to do is plug it in and

49
00:02:27.314 --> 00:02:30.100
it basically helped me out
through the whole process.

50
00:02:30.100 --> 00:02:32.790
So if I've got that,
if you've got that into your computer,

51
00:02:32.790 --> 00:02:34.540
why would we need the server?

52
00:02:34.540 --> 00:02:36.470
>> All right, so here's the thing,

53
00:02:36.470 --> 00:02:39.730
if we've got tons of people's
computers that are out there, right?

54
00:02:39.730 --> 00:02:42.620
If it's just one, it's not a big deal,
you do just like Wes said,

55
00:02:42.620 --> 00:02:45.350
you stick a drive on there, and
it'll automatically pop up.

56
00:02:45.350 --> 00:02:48.330
Hey, do you wanna use this drive for
Time Machine, you just hit Yes, and

57
00:02:48.330 --> 00:02:49.950
off you go, right?

58
00:02:49.950 --> 00:02:53.136
But if you've got 1,000 people out there,

59
00:02:53.136 --> 00:02:57.300
do you wanna pass out
1,000 USB hard drives?

60
00:02:57.300 --> 00:02:57.850
Probably not.

61
00:02:57.850 --> 00:03:00.320
And the other thing is, let's say
you do that, let's say all right,

62
00:03:00.320 --> 00:03:03.300
I'm gonna go ahead and
send out 1,000 of these USB hard drives.

63
00:03:03.300 --> 00:03:05.370
How do I know that people
are actually plugging them in?

64
00:03:05.370 --> 00:03:07.035
Somebody might plug in and
do the first back up, and

65
00:03:07.035 --> 00:03:09.592
then they stick the hard drive in their
desk drawer, and they're like, yep,

66
00:03:09.592 --> 00:03:10.282
I've got a back up.

67
00:03:10.282 --> 00:03:12.910
[LAUGH] And that's it,
and then they just go.

68
00:03:12.910 --> 00:03:17.100
Well now, they're not backing up anymore,
the hard drive is in their desk drawer.

69
00:03:17.100 --> 00:03:19.611
And they've gotta remember to go and
plug that thing back in,

70
00:03:19.611 --> 00:03:21.700
otherwise it's not gonna perform a backup.

71
00:03:21.700 --> 00:03:23.744
>> Okay, I'm guilty, I gotta say.

72
00:03:23.744 --> 00:03:27.431
I'm running Time Machine backups, okay,
and I'm looking at my machine today, and

73
00:03:27.431 --> 00:03:30.160
today it's May 13th, right,
when we're recording this.

74
00:03:30.160 --> 00:03:34.829
And I'm looking at the last time I backed
up, I think I'm guilty here, May 3rd,

75
00:03:34.829 --> 00:03:36.874
so I'm not following the backups.

76
00:03:36.874 --> 00:03:38.802
>> Yep, so you're creeping up
on two weeks without a backup.

77
00:03:38.802 --> 00:03:39.962
So what's gonna happen?

78
00:03:39.962 --> 00:03:43.220
One day you have a failure, and that
failure could be any number of things.

79
00:03:43.220 --> 00:03:45.030
It could be the hard drive fails.

80
00:03:45.030 --> 00:03:49.300
It could be somebody steals your laptop,
they just steal the whole thing, right?

81
00:03:49.300 --> 00:03:51.610
The hard drive's perfectly fine,
you just don't have it any more.

82
00:03:51.610 --> 00:03:54.550
It could be that you
accidentally delete a file.

83
00:03:54.550 --> 00:03:56.440
It could be that you modified a file.

84
00:03:56.440 --> 00:03:59.320
Maybe I went inside of
a Microsoft Word document and

85
00:03:59.320 --> 00:04:01.000
deleted a paragraph and saved it.

86
00:04:01.000 --> 00:04:04.490
And then later on I'm like, I wish I
had that paragraph back again, right?

87
00:04:04.490 --> 00:04:07.760
Or I edited a photo to try and
remove red eye and messed it up, and

88
00:04:07.760 --> 00:04:10.440
I'm like,
I wish I had that original file again.

89
00:04:10.440 --> 00:04:14.452
I know, I'll go back to my Time Machine,
except the last Time Machine back up was

90
00:04:14.452 --> 00:04:17.200
back on May 3rd,
it's been almost two weeks.

91
00:04:17.200 --> 00:04:19.070
I don't have that data now, right?

92
00:04:19.070 --> 00:04:21.810
That's what happens,
that's where your users get.
