Your initial backup is your biggest one.

542
00:26:17.765 --> 00:26:20.225
So, it's gotta do a full
backup from my computer.

543
00:26:20.225 --> 00:26:23.885
If I go and configure this on a thousand
machines all at the same time,

544
00:26:23.885 --> 00:26:26.355
they're all gonna go to backup
within two minutes, and

545
00:26:26.355 --> 00:26:29.425
I'm gonna saturate the bandwidth
on my server, right?

546
00:26:29.425 --> 00:26:32.745
After the first backup,
now it's just backing up changes.

547
00:26:32.745 --> 00:26:34.540
And we don't worry about that so much.

548
00:26:34.540 --> 00:26:37.470
But, you probably don't
wanna turn on Time Machine

549
00:26:37.470 --> 00:26:39.190
on a thousand computers all at once.

550
00:26:39.190 --> 00:26:41.350
You probably wanna roll it out slowly.

551
00:26:41.350 --> 00:26:44.113
And roll it out to ten machines here,
and ten machines there, and

552
00:26:44.113 --> 00:26:45.429
ten machines somewhere else.

553
00:26:45.429 --> 00:26:47.829
A great way to do that is
with Apple Remote Desktop.

554
00:26:47.829 --> 00:26:50.894
Apple Remote Desktop can push the
configuration settings for Time Machine.

555
00:26:50.894 --> 00:26:54.780
And, you can set it to only apply to
a handful of computers per hour and

556
00:26:54.780 --> 00:26:56.189
spread it out over days.

557
00:26:56.189 --> 00:27:00.070
So, it's a great way to do it where you're
not having to get manually involved.

558
00:27:00.070 --> 00:27:02.200
All right, now,
it's preparing the backups.

559
00:27:02.200 --> 00:27:04.200
If you look at my little status here,
it says it's preparing backup.

560
00:27:04.200 --> 00:27:05.992
It's not actually backing up.

561
00:27:05.992 --> 00:27:07.080
What is preparing?

562
00:27:07.080 --> 00:27:11.400
Well, it's looking at my hard drive and
indexing all the files it needs to backup,

563
00:27:11.400 --> 00:27:15.110
and it's starting to create
the directory structure on the server.

564
00:27:15.110 --> 00:27:18.780
So, even though I'm not backing up yet,
now I am, I stalled long enough.

565
00:27:18.780 --> 00:27:20.970
So, now it's actually started backing up.

566
00:27:20.970 --> 00:27:25.830
I can jump over to the server and I'll see
that it's creating a structure over here.

567
00:27:25.830 --> 00:27:30.150
If I browse into the Storage Drive,
and I browse into Shared Items, and

568
00:27:30.150 --> 00:27:32.990
Backups, this was empty.

569
00:27:32.990 --> 00:27:35.580
Now, I've got Don's Mac, right?

570
00:27:35.580 --> 00:27:40.500
For each user that backs up, it's gonna
create an item inside of here for them.

571
00:27:40.500 --> 00:27:43.740
And so, I'll be able to see all the
computers in my company that are backing

572
00:27:43.740 --> 00:27:46.190
up, right here in one central location.

573
00:27:46.190 --> 00:27:51.170
And, if we try and browse inside
of that now I can start to see

574
00:27:51.170 --> 00:27:55.900
the actual Time Machine backup information
that we'd normally see on a computer and

575
00:27:55.900 --> 00:27:57.940
the data that's being backed
up as a part of that.

576
00:27:57.940 --> 00:28:00.720
Unless it's encrypted, if it's encrypted
we really won't be able to get much

577
00:28:00.720 --> 00:28:02.630
further than what we're
looking at right here.

578
00:28:02.630 --> 00:28:04.976
Okay, but it is backing up.

579
00:28:04.976 --> 00:28:09.503
This screen right here doesn't necessarily
refresh for us, we've seen that before,

580
00:28:09.503 --> 00:28:11.593
where we have to do a Cmd+R or whatever.

581
00:28:11.593 --> 00:28:13.726
But, it is starting to update,

582
00:28:13.726 --> 00:28:18.180
see how it's only got 548.1
GB available instead of .95?

583
00:28:18.180 --> 00:28:20.010
So, it is starting to fill, and

584
00:28:20.010 --> 00:28:24.460
we'll see this progress bar change to
reflect that storage being consumed.

585
00:28:24.460 --> 00:28:28.295
And instead of browsing to the hard drive,
we can go right over here to this Backup

586
00:28:28.295 --> 00:28:31.050
tab, and now I can see
the backups that are available.

587
00:28:31.050 --> 00:28:34.450
And so, I see Don's Mac right here,
which is owned by me.

588
00:28:34.450 --> 00:28:39.120
Backup is currently in progress, and
it's tied to the first Backup drive,

589
00:28:39.120 --> 00:28:40.420
not Backups-1.

590
00:28:40.420 --> 00:28:42.950
And the current size is 621.1 MB.

591
00:28:42.950 --> 00:28:45.670
So, I can see all of my users.

592
00:28:45.670 --> 00:28:48.600
I can see how much space they're using,
and

593
00:28:48.600 --> 00:28:50.060
I can see the last time they backed up.

594
00:28:50.060 --> 00:28:52.190
So, see how it says Latest Backup,
Backup in progress.

595
00:28:52.190 --> 00:28:53.570
So, I know they're backing up now.

596
00:28:53.570 --> 00:28:57.230
If I wasn't backing up now it would
tell be the last time that I did backup.

597
00:28:57.230 --> 00:28:59.310
So, you can sort by this column and

598
00:28:59.310 --> 00:29:01.630
find users that haven't
backed up in over a week.

599
00:29:01.630 --> 00:29:02.600
And you can call them on the phone and

600
00:29:02.600 --> 00:29:05.330
say, hey,
I don't have a good backup of your system.

601
00:29:05.330 --> 00:29:06.450
You haven't backed up in over a week.

602
00:29:06.450 --> 00:29:08.246
You need to connect to the network,
what's going on?

603
00:29:08.246 --> 00:29:10.090
And they say, well, I was on vacation.

604
00:29:10.090 --> 00:29:12.640
Like okay, we'll let that slide.

605
00:29:12.640 --> 00:29:15.847
Or, you find out, well, you know,
I've been working from home, and

606
00:29:15.847 --> 00:29:18.530
I just haven't come into
the office to get that connected.

607
00:29:18.530 --> 00:29:22.610
And you can say, well, understand if you
lose your laptop you're gonna lose this

608
00:29:22.610 --> 00:29:25.110
whole week's worth of data because I
don't have a backup for it, right?

609
00:29:25.110 --> 00:29:27.199
We can start to communicate
that to the users.

610
00:29:27.199 --> 00:29:31.690
And, if you're really worried about it,
you can set up a VPN.

611
00:29:31.690 --> 00:29:34.790
So that remote users can VPN in,

612
00:29:34.790 --> 00:29:39.130
a virtual private network, and connect and
do the Time Machine backup over a VPN.

613
00:29:39.130 --> 00:29:42.330
Be careful though, you don't wanna
do the initial backup that way,

614
00:29:42.330 --> 00:29:44.080
cuz the backup's gonna be huge.

615
00:29:44.080 --> 00:29:46.930
But the other backups are just changed
files, and the bigger those are the more

616
00:29:46.930 --> 00:29:49.040
internet bandwidth it's gonna
consume to do that backup.

617
00:29:49.040 --> 00:29:51.200
It may just take a long
time to backup that way.

618
00:29:51.200 --> 00:29:52.830
Hourly backups might not be possible.

619
00:29:52.830 --> 00:29:55.150
So, just a little caveat there.

620
00:29:55.150 --> 00:29:57.520
>> We've seen a lot of great
information about Time Machine.

621
00:29:57.520 --> 00:29:58.505
Don, I'm looking at the time,

622
00:29:58.505 --> 00:30:00.526
does look like we're coming to
the end of another great episode.

623
00:30:00.526 --> 00:30:03.080
But before we do that,
got any final words?

624
00:30:03.080 --> 00:30:04.980
>> Main thing,
getting it set up is really easy.

625
00:30:04.980 --> 00:30:07.550
You guys saw here,
it's just a couple of steps.

626
00:30:07.550 --> 00:30:09.770
Monitoring, right, constant vigilance.

627
00:30:09.770 --> 00:30:12.100
You are gonna run out of hard drive
space on your Time Machine server.

628
00:30:12.100 --> 00:30:13.140
It's a given right.

629
00:30:13.140 --> 00:30:16.000
It's gonna back up as much as it can
until it runs out of hard drive space.

630
00:30:16.000 --> 00:30:19.340
And when that happens, it's gonna start
deleting the older backups to make room.

631
00:30:19.340 --> 00:30:23.160
Pay attention to that, pay attention
to how far back in time you can go.

632
00:30:23.160 --> 00:30:26.440
Because, you probably have some kind of
service level agreement in your company

633
00:30:26.440 --> 00:30:30.510
that says, we need to be able to
back up data up to a month ago.

634
00:30:30.510 --> 00:30:32.942
So, you need to make sure you've
got enough storage on the server to

635
00:30:32.942 --> 00:30:33.503
support that.

636
00:30:33.503 --> 00:30:36.040
If you start seeing that time
creep closer, and closer, and

637
00:30:36.040 --> 00:30:38.700
closer to the present,
it means you need to add storage.

638
00:30:38.700 --> 00:30:40.020
So, you can't just turn this on and

639
00:30:40.020 --> 00:30:43.560
forget about it, you've gotta pay
attention to it, you've gotta watch it.

640
00:30:43.560 --> 00:30:45.434
And make sure you got enough
storage to support it,

641
00:30:45.434 --> 00:30:46.573
just keep an eye on the server.

642
00:30:46.573 --> 00:30:47.919
>> Thank you for that information, Don.

643
00:30:47.919 --> 00:30:49.808
And thank you,
the viewer here, for watching.

644
00:30:49.808 --> 00:30:53.220
I'm gonna go clean out my ISO folder
before I have to clean out my desk.

645
00:30:53.220 --> 00:30:55.920
But, before we do that we're gonna go
ahead and sign out here at ITProTV.

646
00:30:55.920 --> 00:30:57.350
I've been your house Wes Bryan.

647
00:30:57.350 --> 00:30:58.470
>> And I'm Don Pezet.

648
00:30:58.470 --> 00:31:00.592
>> And we'll see you next time.

649
00:31:00.592 --> 00:31:08.300
[MUSIC]

episodes.description: In this episode, Wes and Don discuss one of the most important services in networking today known as the Dynamic Host Configuration Protocol. They demonstrate the common options that can be deployed to clients through DHCP like IP addresses, routers, DNS Servers and DNS search domains. They also examine setting up reservations for machines that need to keep the same IP addresses.
episodes.title: DHCP
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.000 --> 00:00:10.000
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:11.752 --> 00:00:14.451
Welcome back to the another
exciting episode here at ITPro.TV.

3
00:00:14.451 --> 00:00:18.490
I'm your host Wes Brian and today's
episode we're continue through our series

4
00:00:18.490 --> 00:00:24.160
on Mac OS X server essentials and we've
been looking at providing network services

5
00:00:24.160 --> 00:00:28.100
and more specifically, we're going to
be focusing in on the world of DHCP.

6
00:00:28.100 --> 00:00:30.690
Help us out with that is Don Pezet,
Don how you doing today sir?

7
00:00:30.690 --> 00:00:33.575
>> I'm doing great, Wes,
ready to jump into acronym soup today.

8
00:00:33.575 --> 00:00:39.145
We're gonna be covering DHCP, which is
the Dynamic Host Configuration Protocol.

9
00:00:39.145 --> 00:00:40.645
That's quite a mouthful.

10
00:00:40.645 --> 00:00:44.955
And what it is is a neat little network
service that almost everybody runs.

11
00:00:44.955 --> 00:00:48.145
The odds are you're running
it on your network right now.

12
00:00:48.145 --> 00:00:52.465
What we need to see is that we can
actually use our Mac as that DHCP server

13
00:00:52.465 --> 00:00:53.165
if we want.

14
00:00:53.165 --> 00:00:56.155
Now, I guess before I get ahead of myself,
what the heck is DHCP?

15
00:00:56.155 --> 00:00:57.400
What does it do?

16
00:00:57.400 --> 00:01:00.820
Well whenever you plug a computer into
a network, or even connect to a wireless

17
00:01:00.820 --> 00:01:06.140
network, if you wanna communicate on
a network, you have to have an address.

18
00:01:06.140 --> 00:01:09.700
And most networks use what's called IP,
or the internet protocol, and so

19
00:01:09.700 --> 00:01:11.700
you have an IP address.

20
00:01:11.700 --> 00:01:13.440
We've seen them in some
of the other episodes,

21
00:01:13.440 --> 00:01:16.410
where you had an address attached so
that we could talk.

22
00:01:16.410 --> 00:01:18.840
Now where do you get that address from?

23
00:01:18.840 --> 00:01:19.915
Your computer doesn't really care,

24
00:01:19.915 --> 00:01:21.400
there's a number of different
places it can get it.

25
00:01:21.400 --> 00:01:24.580
As long as it has one it'll use it and
it'll work.

26
00:01:24.580 --> 00:01:29.520
So we can give our computer
a address by hand if we want, but

27
00:01:29.520 --> 00:01:34.500
imagine if you had a laptop or your iPhone
or an iPad and you go home and you connect

28
00:01:34.500 --> 00:01:38.010
to a network, and then you go to Starbucks
and you use their wireless network, and

29
00:01:38.010 --> 00:01:40.540
then you get to the office and
you plugin to their network.

30
00:01:40.540 --> 00:01:41.690
Imagine having to go in and

31
00:01:41.690 --> 00:01:44.778
change your IP address every single
time you connect to a network.

32
00:01:44.778 --> 00:01:46.900
That would be really frustrating.

33
00:01:46.900 --> 00:01:48.030
Most people don't want to deal with that.

34
00:01:48.030 --> 00:01:50.000
Most people don't even know
what an IP address is, so

35
00:01:50.000 --> 00:01:52.220
they don't want to worry
about that at all.

36
00:01:52.220 --> 00:01:54.090
So that's where DHCP comes in.

37
00:01:54.090 --> 00:01:58.535
DHCP takes an IP address and
makes it dynamic, right?

38
00:01:58.535 --> 00:02:01.215
Dynamic host configuration.

39
00:02:01.215 --> 00:02:03.765
We're going to configure our laptops,
our desktops,

40
00:02:03.765 --> 00:02:07.255
whatever with a dynamic set of values so

41
00:02:07.255 --> 00:02:11.637
we don't have to manually put them in,
and they can change on the fly as needed.

42
00:02:11.637 --> 00:02:13.665
So that when I travel from one network,
to another,

43
00:02:13.665 --> 00:02:16.860
to another,
my system automatically configures it.

44
00:02:16.860 --> 00:02:21.980
The way it works is when your computer
boots up, it sees the network.

45
00:02:21.980 --> 00:02:26.250
And if it has an address already,
it'll talk and it will be fine.

46
00:02:26.250 --> 00:02:29.880
But if it doesn't have an address,
it will shout out on the network.

47
00:02:29.880 --> 00:02:33.440
It will say, hey, is there somebody
out there who can help me?

48
00:02:33.440 --> 00:02:34.230
I need an address.

49
00:02:34.230 --> 00:02:35.676
I can't talk without an address.

50
00:02:35.676 --> 00:02:36.570
Somebody help.

51
00:02:36.570 --> 00:02:39.980
I say it's shouting,
it's actually called broadcasting.

52
00:02:39.980 --> 00:02:42.560
A broadcast is a message that is
just thrown on the network and

53
00:02:42.560 --> 00:02:43.670
goes to everyone.

54
00:02:43.670 --> 00:02:45.100
It's done without an address.

55
00:02:45.100 --> 00:02:47.590
It actually does have an address,
but it's a fake kind of address,

56
00:02:47.590 --> 00:02:50.475
but one that's designed to
just go out to everybody.

57
00:02:50.475 --> 00:02:53.895
And if you have a DHCP
server on the network,

58
00:02:53.895 --> 00:02:58.045
the DHCP server can respond back and
say, hey, let me help you out.

59
00:02:58.045 --> 00:02:59.855
Here's an address that you can use.

60
00:02:59.855 --> 00:03:03.825
Here's some other information you
can use to get on the network and

61
00:03:03.825 --> 00:03:05.045
to start talking.

62
00:03:05.045 --> 00:03:08.055
The DHCP server will
help you get connected.

63
00:03:08.055 --> 00:03:10.455
And this is all done
invisibly to the end user.

64
00:03:10.455 --> 00:03:12.155
The end user doesn't
know this is happening.

65
00:03:12.155 --> 00:03:14.230
It's just an automatic process.

66
00:03:14.230 --> 00:03:15.770
And boy is it nice.

67
00:03:15.770 --> 00:03:16.500
And that's why I say,

68
00:03:16.500 --> 00:03:21.180
most of you out there in TV land
are probably using this right now.

69
00:03:21.180 --> 00:03:24.330
Your router might be doing it,
or your wireless access point,

70
00:03:24.330 --> 00:03:27.670
you might have a dedicated server
on the network who's doing it, but

71
00:03:27.670 --> 00:03:31.240
you can use the OS X server app also.

72
00:03:31.240 --> 00:03:33.310
It's got a DACP server built into it.

73
00:03:33.310 --> 00:03:35.090
It's turned off by default.

74
00:03:35.090 --> 00:03:39.190
We can turn it on and start automatically
configuring machines on our network.

75
00:03:39.190 --> 00:03:41.230
So it's a nice little process.

76
00:03:41.230 --> 00:03:43.620
It's not that hard to get set up.

77
00:03:43.620 --> 00:03:46.880
If you're using another
device as your DACP server,

78
00:03:46.880 --> 00:03:49.580
don't feel like you have to
use the server app, right?

79
00:03:49.580 --> 00:03:53.560
It can certainly do it but usually if
you have a router that's providing it,

80
00:03:53.560 --> 00:03:55.380
it's kind of better to leave it there.

81
00:03:55.380 --> 00:03:57.920
Just let the router handle
it's dedicated hardware.

82
00:03:57.920 --> 00:04:01.530
But if you don't, if you don't have a DHP
server on network, you can use your Mac.

83
00:04:01.530 --> 00:04:03.380
I does a great job, works really well.

84
00:04:03.380 --> 00:04:05.744
You can get it set up and you can manage
it right from in the server app and

85
00:04:05.744 --> 00:04:07.773
that's what we are going to see
right here in this episode.

86
00:04:07.773 --> 00:04:12.164
>> Don, one of the things I was going to
ask is if we have seen you aesthetically

87
00:04:12.164 --> 00:04:13.315
configure an IP.

88
00:04:13.315 --> 00:04:15.585
We see the setting and the parameters.

89
00:04:15.585 --> 00:04:18.400
I know I can set an IP address as well.

90
00:04:18.400 --> 00:04:20.500
Why wouldn't I just go
from machine to machine?

91
00:04:20.500 --> 00:04:23.510
What would be some of
the benefits of having DHCP,

92
00:04:23.510 --> 00:04:25.030
rather than me just doing sneakernet?

93
00:04:25.030 --> 00:04:28.790
>> All right, so
first off there's just effort, right.

94
00:04:28.790 --> 00:04:32.070
If I have 1,000 machines,
I'd have to go to all 1,000 of them and

95
00:04:32.070 --> 00:04:33.260
manually put in an address.

96
00:04:33.260 --> 00:04:34.730
That's gonna take a lot of work.

97
00:04:34.730 --> 00:04:35.380
Right?

98
00:04:35.380 --> 00:04:36.960
Versus they're just automatic.

99
00:04:36.960 --> 00:04:40.010
All we do is push a power button now, and
they get their address and it's done.

100
00:04:40.010 --> 00:04:43.030
So that's one thing,
it saves us a lot of effort.

101
00:04:43.030 --> 00:04:47.590
Another is, if I have to manually type in
the address, Wes, you've seen me type.

102
00:04:47.590 --> 00:04:48.420
It's typo city.

103
00:04:48.420 --> 00:04:50.010
I'm gonna make mistakes left and right.

104
00:04:50.010 --> 00:04:52.370
And if you make a mistake,
now your machine can't talk.

105
00:04:52.370 --> 00:04:54.920
Right?
So you're prone to making mistakes.

106
00:04:54.920 --> 00:04:56.780
But probably the riskiest part,

107
00:04:56.780 --> 00:05:00.350
the worst part,
is if we do manual address assignment

108
00:05:00.350 --> 00:05:05.560
it is super easy to accidentally use the
same address on more than one computer.

109
00:05:05.560 --> 00:05:09.320
If you use the same address on more
than one computer, it's a conflict and

110
00:05:09.320 --> 00:05:10.800
one of them won't be able to talk.

111
00:05:10.800 --> 00:05:12.830
It'll basically be stuck on
the network and it can't communicate.

112
00:05:12.830 --> 00:05:15.410
So you run the risk of duplicate IPs.

113
00:05:15.410 --> 00:05:16.900
And how do you solve that?

114
00:05:16.900 --> 00:05:18.770
Well in the old days we
use to make a spreadsheet.

115
00:05:18.770 --> 00:05:21.780
You use to keep a notebook and
say I put this IP on this computer.

116
00:05:21.780 --> 00:05:23.940
Well, that's fine if you
have ten computers or

117
00:05:23.940 --> 00:05:27.700
50 computers, but if you have 5,000
computers that's one big notebook.

00:10:57.151 --> 00:11:00.333

00:11:00.333 --> 00:11:02.241

00:11:02.241 --> 00:11:05.984

00:11:05.984 --> 00:11:08.090

00:11:08.090 --> 00:11:09.320
That's discovery.

00:11:09.320 --> 00:11:12.470
We're sending a message out
just to anybody on the network,

236
00:11:12.470 --> 00:11:14.330
somebody help, right?

237
00:11:14.330 --> 00:11:16.120
So D is for discovery.

238
00:11:16.120 --> 00:11:18.130
Then we have O for offer.

239
00:11:18.130 --> 00:11:21.950
A DHCP on the network will
hear that discover message and

00:11:21.950 --> 00:11:23.830

00:11:23.830 --> 00:11:25.830

00:11:25.830 --> 00:11:26.380

00:11:29.310 --> 00:11:30.550

00:11:34.610 --> 00:11:36.200

00:11:36.200 --> 00:11:37.080
At R's request,

00:11:37.080 --> 00:11:40.390

00:11:40.390 --> 00:11:41.520
I wanna use it.

00:11:41.520 --> 00:11:44.990

00:11:44.990 --> 00:11:48.090

00:11:48.090 --> 00:11:51.350
And the server is then going to

00:11:51.350 --> 00:11:55.420

00:11:55.420 --> 00:11:58.260

those printers, and
the IP address changes.

575
00:26:39.120 --> 00:26:41.290
Do I have to turn around and go back and

576
00:26:41.290 --> 00:26:44.110
map all the IP addresses Do
we have a solution in DHCP?

577
00:26:44.110 --> 00:26:46.010
>> Yeah,
your printers are a great example that.

578
00:26:46.010 --> 00:26:50.100
Those little menus on a printer to go in
and configure things, it's a nightmare.

579
00:26:50.100 --> 00:26:51.910
It's really hard to to go in and
set those things.

580
00:26:51.910 --> 00:26:53.060
So using DHCP for

581
00:26:53.060 --> 00:26:55.180
a printer is nice, because you don't
have to configure the network.

582
00:26:55.180 --> 00:26:57.610
But you always want your printer
to have the same IP address so

583
00:26:57.610 --> 00:26:58.790
you can reliably find it.

584
00:26:58.790 --> 00:27:01.700
So with DHCP, that is not a guarantee.

585
00:27:01.700 --> 00:27:03.740
You are not guaranteed to
always have the same address.

586
00:27:03.740 --> 00:27:06.035
If your lease expires,
you could get a new address and

587
00:27:06.035 --> 00:27:09.250
now you've got to remap all the printers,
like Wes said.

588
00:27:09.250 --> 00:27:13.120
So what we can do is we can set
up what's called a reservation.

589
00:27:13.120 --> 00:27:17.050
A reservation is where you take one IP and
you reserve it, you set it aside.

590
00:27:17.050 --> 00:27:20.240
And you say this is available just for
this It's one client.

591
00:27:20.240 --> 00:27:23.060
And we can do that right here in
the server app, let me show you.

592
00:27:23.060 --> 00:27:27.770
So here my client just got the address on
its own, but if I go back to my server and

593
00:27:27.770 --> 00:27:31.180
I go to the clients tab,
I can see all the addresses that I issued.

594
00:27:31.180 --> 00:27:32.800
And so here's Don's Mac.

595
00:27:32.800 --> 00:27:35.240
Don's Mac got 192.168.1.201 and
it was dynamic.

596
00:27:35.240 --> 00:27:38.700
I just asked for it and it gave it to me.

597
00:27:38.700 --> 00:27:39.500
Okay?

598
00:27:39.500 --> 00:27:41.780
So that's coming right
out of that lab network.

599
00:27:41.780 --> 00:27:47.380
Well, when I highlight that client down
at the bottom you can hit the gear and

600
00:27:47.380 --> 00:27:50.130
you'll see, View Client, which will
just like browse through it that's not

601
00:27:50.130 --> 00:27:53.510
exciting, and create static address.

602
00:27:53.510 --> 00:27:56.310
Creating a static address
creates a reservation.

603
00:27:56.310 --> 00:27:59.950
It reserves that IP and
holds it for this one client.

604
00:27:59.950 --> 00:28:03.650
No one else will be allowed
to use this IP address.

605
00:28:03.650 --> 00:28:06.350
It's going to map it to my MAC address.

606
00:28:06.350 --> 00:28:11.190
And that's not Mac as in Macintosh,
that's MAC as in Media Access Control.

607
00:28:11.190 --> 00:28:15.860
Every network adapter, be it wireless or
wired, be it in a Windows or

608
00:28:15.860 --> 00:28:17.880
Linux or Mac machine, it doesn't matter.

609
00:28:17.880 --> 00:28:19.200
Every network adapter and

610
00:28:19.200 --> 00:28:24.060
every device that supports networking
has a media access control address.

611
00:28:24.060 --> 00:28:28.330
It's a hardware address that's
burned into the hardware.

612
00:28:28.330 --> 00:28:31.900
I guess redundant there, but
it's a 48 bit hexadecimal number.

613
00:28:31.900 --> 00:28:35.920
So it looks something like this, and it's
going to vary based on your device, so

614
00:28:35.920 --> 00:28:40.350
yours may look wildly different than mine
but it'll be in the same format, right?

615
00:28:40.350 --> 00:28:45.540
So, when it sees a broadcast come
from this Mac address, it'll look and

616
00:28:45.540 --> 00:28:48.150
it'll say, this guy always get 201.

617
00:28:48.150 --> 00:28:49.880
Nobody else is allowed to get 201.

618
00:28:49.880 --> 00:28:53.800
So for a printer,
that's nice because we can have set and

619
00:28:53.800 --> 00:28:56.590
now we'll know that it will
always get that address.

620
00:28:56.590 --> 00:28:59.810
And so now when I look,
Dons-Mac no longer shows as dynamic.

621
00:28:59.810 --> 00:29:01.090
It shows as static.

622
00:29:01.090 --> 00:29:03.350
A static address is one
that's been manually set.

623
00:29:03.350 --> 00:29:05.700
This one's manually
assigned to this client.

624
00:29:05.700 --> 00:29:06.950
Nobody else will get it.

625
00:29:06.950 --> 00:29:08.530
Now I don't have a lease timer, right?

626
00:29:08.530 --> 00:29:13.320
So back here, when I got an address
through DHCP, normally I have a lease.

627
00:29:13.320 --> 00:29:17.920
Now, I technically still have a lease,
but I'll always have that address even if

628
00:29:17.920 --> 00:29:20.540
my lease expires,
I don't have to worry about that anymore.

629
00:29:20.540 --> 00:29:23.070
Now Don, theoretically,
what if I have 50 servers and

630
00:29:23.070 --> 00:29:24.870
I wanted to manage their IP addresses?

631
00:29:24.870 --> 00:29:26.760
It's kind of funny,
we've been setting them statically but

632
00:29:26.760 --> 00:29:30.810
is there any way maybe I could
implement this on a server as well?

633
00:29:30.810 --> 00:29:33.410
>> You could,
I don't like to do that personally.

634
00:29:33.410 --> 00:29:37.360
Personally, on a server, I manually
assign the IPs, that's what I do.

635
00:29:37.360 --> 00:29:40.820
But you could use the DACP
server with reservations.

636
00:29:40.820 --> 00:29:45.220
The risk there is if your DACP server
goes down, what happens to your servers?

637
00:29:45.220 --> 00:29:48.800
Well, now they might lose their
address when their lease expires and

638
00:29:48.800 --> 00:29:49.650
now your servers go down.

639
00:29:49.650 --> 00:29:50.568
You don't want that.

640
00:29:50.568 --> 00:29:54.250
So if you're going to use DACP for
your server make sure,

641
00:29:54.250 --> 00:29:58.130
make doubly sure,
that you've got more than one DACPserver.

642
00:29:58.130 --> 00:30:02.260
And remember how I said you don't want
the IP's to overlap on your DACP servers?

643
00:30:02.260 --> 00:30:04.720
Well, reservations like these
would be the exception,

00:30:04.720 --> 00:30:07.340

00:30:07.340 --> 00:30:11.060
It doesn't matter if I get two offers for
the same address, if I'm reserved for

00:30:11.060 --> 00:30:12.300

00:30:12.300 --> 00:30:13.550

00:30:13.550 --> 00:30:15.970
I would need to create it on

00:30:15.970 --> 00:30:17.580

00:30:17.580 --> 00:30:19.470
I will tell you, there is some

00:30:19.470 --> 00:30:21.530

00:30:25.940 --> 00:30:29.450

655
00:30:36.300 --> 00:30:38.870

656
00:30:38.870 --> 00:30:41.180
And then one day I say, you know what,

657
00:30:41.180 --> 00:30:42.740
I'm setting up an open directory, so

00:30:42.740 --> 00:30:45.050
I need to point everybody

659
00:30:46.090 --> 00:30:49.310
Now I've got to go to 10,000 computers and

660
00:30:49.310 --> 00:30:50.900
Not with DHCP.

661
00:30:50.900 --> 00:30:54.440
With DHCP I can change
the values right here.

662
00:30:54.440 --> 00:31:01.100
And so I'm going to change that out
to my own server, and now, the next

663
00:31:01.100 --> 00:31:06.350
time they renew their lease, they will get
the new DNS configurations, all right?

664
00:31:06.350 --> 00:31:09.310
And so
if I have a one day lease duration here,

665
00:31:09.310 --> 00:31:13.660
right then within 12 hours,
everybody is going to check in and

666
00:31:13.660 --> 00:31:16.890
everybody is going to get the DNS, so

667
00:31:16.890 --> 00:31:22.076
So I just made a change in one place,
is going to affect all of my computers.

668
00:31:22.076 --> 00:31:25.310
So it's kind of nice to be able to do
that to be able to change those settings.

669
00:31:25.310 --> 00:31:29.380

if I look I still have those DNS servers,

670
00:31:29.380 --> 00:31:33.735

671
00:31:33.735 --> 00:31:36.405
But if I disconnect from the network, and

672

673
00:31:41.065 --> 00:31:46.166

674
00:31:46.166 --> 00:31:47.930

675

and I'm just going to give it

676
00:31:50.230 --> 00:31:52.468
And then when I turn it back on,

677
00:31:52.468 --> 00:31:56.070
it's going to reach back out and

678
00:31:56.070 --> 00:32:00.220

679
00:32:00.220 --> 00:32:02.830

680
00:32:02.830 --> 00:32:06.320
And so it renewed, and
look at that DNS Server, right.

681
00:32:06.320 --> 00:32:08.550
So that happens automatically and

682
00:32:08.550 --> 00:32:12.120

network by changing it in just one place.

683
00:32:12.120 --> 00:32:13.900

684
00:32:13.900 --> 00:32:16.660

685
00:32:16.660 --> 00:32:19.900

we've been talking about IP addresses,

00:32:19.900 --> 00:32:23.750

a lot of things that you can do with DHCP.

687
00:32:23.750 --> 00:32:26.700
So get into the settings,
find out what you can do.

688

Don, I'm looking at the clock right

00:32:29.760 --> 00:32:33.660
the batteries up of the clock, but before
we call it a day, got anything else?

690
00:32:33.660 --> 00:32:36.860
The only other thing that I think I didn't
mention is if you ever have a problem with

691
00:32:36.860 --> 00:32:40.310
DHCP, remember, it's got service
logs right in the server app.

692
00:32:40.310 --> 00:32:44.680
So if I go back into my server app and
I go up here to Logs.

00:32:44.680 --> 00:32:49.320
In the Logs, we can come in here and Just

00:32:49.320 --> 00:32:51.240
I can go in here and find DHTP.

00:32:51.240 --> 00:32:54.420
And so it's got a service log right here.

696
00:32:54.420 --> 00:32:59.991
And it'll show you when people request
addresses and we can even see happening.

00:32:59.991 --> 00:33:03.670
Right there is DISCOVER,

698
00:33:03.670 --> 00:33:08.260
You can see that whole process occurring

699
00:33:08.260 --> 00:33:09.120
I can see the address.

700
00:33:09.120 --> 00:33:11.230
It's a great place to
go to troubleshoot and

701
00:33:11.230 --> 00:33:13.740
find out what's going on if
you're having issues with DACP.

702
00:33:13.740 --> 00:33:17.160
>> Well Don, as always, thank you for that
wealth of knowledge that you've showed us

703
00:33:17.160 --> 00:33:20.060
and we look forward to seeing
more in this series, but

704
00:33:20.060 --> 00:33:23.250
it looks like we're going to go ahead and

00:33:23.250 --> 00:33:24.720

>> And I'm Don Paset.

00:33:28.280 --> 00:33:32.490

episodes.description: In this episode, Wes and Don examine setting up and configuring VPNs inside of OS X Server. They discuss the benefits of using virtual private networks, the protocols associated with tunneling like PPTP and L2TP. They demonstrate client-side configuration, connections and Configuration Profiles. They explain the TCP/IP ports that PPTP and L2TP as well as the encryption technologies used with these associated protocols.

visual confirmation by default

544
00:26:42.710 --> 00:26:44.140
whether I'm connected or not.

545
00:26:44.140 --> 00:26:47.290
But, you can do this
showtime connected option.

546
00:26:47.290 --> 00:26:50.010
And now it'll display a time and

547
00:26:50.010 --> 00:26:52.820
that way if I ever get
disconnected the time disappears.

548
00:26:52.820 --> 00:26:54.830
And so now I've got that visual cue and

549
00:26:54.830 --> 00:26:59.550
it's in the grey visual format that
Apple likes for whatever reason.

550
00:26:59.550 --> 00:27:02.580
I've been connected for a solid minute,
let's see if this thing is even working.

551
00:27:02.580 --> 00:27:09.000
If I also click and look at it here,
you get Show Status While Connecting,

552
00:27:09.000 --> 00:27:13.240
but I don't see the actual status,
I don't know, am I actually using it?

553
00:27:13.240 --> 00:27:17.900
I'm going to try and ping, and
this time I'm pinging that server and

554
00:27:17.900 --> 00:27:19.860
I can actually get to it.

555
00:27:19.860 --> 00:27:24.130
I'm able to see the 192.168.0 network even
though I couldn't see it before cause I

556
00:27:24.130 --> 00:27:27.720
was remote and I'm going over
that VPN tunnel to get there.

557
00:27:27.720 --> 00:27:31.730
All my data is being encrypted, sent
across the tunnel to the other side, and

558
00:27:31.730 --> 00:27:34.440
now I can talk to this network
that I did have access to before.

559
00:27:34.440 --> 00:27:35.065
>> Don, let's say.

560
00:27:35.065 --> 00:27:37.755
If you were pinging right now and
like you've shown us,

561
00:27:37.755 --> 00:27:39.735
you've got both sides set up right.

562
00:27:39.735 --> 00:27:43.105
And all of a sudden, you go to ping,
and you can't ping, and

563
00:27:43.105 --> 00:27:44.505
you've got a firewall in between.

564
00:27:44.505 --> 00:27:46.855
Is there any consideration,
something you can troubleshoot,

565
00:27:46.855 --> 00:27:48.430
as to why it might block that?

566
00:27:48.430 --> 00:27:53.270
Well Wes, the firewall wouldnt
like interrupt your connection,

567
00:27:53.270 --> 00:27:55.500
it would stop you from
connecting in the first place.

568
00:27:55.500 --> 00:27:59.480
In order to get connected,
youve got to pass through a firewall to

569
00:27:59.480 --> 00:28:04.350
get to the VPN server, and its expecting
certain ports and connections to be open,

570
00:28:04.350 --> 00:28:06.210
and if they arent, its gonna break.

571
00:28:06.210 --> 00:28:10.140
Now the ports are different
based on whether its PPTP or

572
00:28:10.140 --> 00:28:15.200
L2TP PPTP, the point to point tunneling
protocol, it's the most basic of the two,

573
00:28:15.200 --> 00:28:18.040
and so it's really just using
two things to get connected.

574
00:28:18.040 --> 00:28:19.740
It's got TCP port 1723,

575
00:28:19.740 --> 00:28:24.390
that's the main port that is establishing
it's connection on and is running with.

576
00:28:24.390 --> 00:28:27.400
But it also uses another
protocol called GRE.

577
00:28:27.400 --> 00:28:30.880
GRE is the generic routing and
encapsulation protocol.

578
00:28:30.880 --> 00:28:33.680
And what it does is it allows you to
move traffic across the tunnel, but

579
00:28:33.680 --> 00:28:34.980
the traffic's not encrypted.

580
00:28:34.980 --> 00:28:37.100
And then it uses NPPE
to do the encryption.

581
00:28:37.100 --> 00:28:42.450
So on your firewall it has
to allow TCP port 723 and

582
00:28:42.450 --> 00:28:45.120
GRE, which is sometimes
called protocol 47.

583
00:28:45.120 --> 00:28:48.350
A lot of protocols have a number assigned
to them, this one's protocol 47.

584
00:28:48.350 --> 00:28:53.160
So, if those two things are open on the
firewall to allow us to get to the server

585
00:28:53.160 --> 00:28:55.960
that's acting as our VPN server
we'll get to it and it's just fine.

586
00:28:55.960 --> 00:28:58.720
If those aren't opened,
we won't connect them in the first place.

587
00:28:58.720 --> 00:29:02.070
So, it's not so much a matter of
our connection being interrupted.

588
00:29:02.070 --> 00:29:04.840
It's just we never, actually,
get there to begin with.

589
00:29:04.840 --> 00:29:07.330
And, it's easy to spot that type of thing
on your server because you can look in

590
00:29:07.330 --> 00:29:11.420
the logs and you won't see people even get
to the server better yet get there and

591
00:29:11.420 --> 00:29:12.040
fail, right?

592
00:29:12.040 --> 00:29:14.990
So, if they don't even get there,
it's probably a firewall problem.

593
00:29:14.990 --> 00:29:16.280
But that's just PPTP.

594
00:29:16.280 --> 00:29:18.340
It's the easier of the two.

595
00:29:18.340 --> 00:29:20.110
L2TP is a little more involved.

596
00:29:20.110 --> 00:29:22.290
There's actually four things
that need to be open for L2TP.

597
00:29:22.290 --> 00:29:26.710
We had a couple of ports,
there's UDP port 500,

598
00:29:26.710 --> 00:29:31.970
there's UDP port 1701, and
then there's UDP port 4500.

599
00:29:31.970 --> 00:29:33.520
Three different ports.

600
00:29:33.520 --> 00:29:36.970
And that's because L2TP is using IPsec.

601
00:29:36.970 --> 00:29:38.930
And IPsec is not a protocol.

602
00:29:38.930 --> 00:29:39.780
It's a framework.

603
00:29:39.780 --> 00:29:41.910
It's a collection of protocols.

604
00:29:41.910 --> 00:29:45.270
And so each of these ports are responsible
for different functions inside of

605
00:29:45.270 --> 00:29:48.630
the communication as far as
setting up your hashing algorithm,

606
00:29:48.630 --> 00:29:53.360
doing your verified signatures,
doing your actual tunnel and encryption.

607
00:29:53.360 --> 00:29:54.530
Each one needs different connectivity.

608
00:29:54.530 --> 00:29:56.370
So, it's three different ports.

609
00:29:56.370 --> 00:30:00.130
And then, when it actually starts
moving the encrypted data,

610
00:30:00.130 --> 00:30:05.380
it's using a protocol called ESP,
the Encapsulated Security Payload.

611
00:30:05.380 --> 00:30:09.240
And what ESP does Is it actually
encrypts and tunnels your data, and

612
00:30:09.240 --> 00:30:11.340
it has a protocol number
just like GRE does.

613
00:30:11.340 --> 00:30:16.400
ESP is protocol number 50, and so
on your firewall it might show as ESP or

614
00:30:16.400 --> 00:30:19.100
it might show as protocol 50,
but that'll have to be enabled.

615
00:30:19.100 --> 00:30:24.800
If you're just using L2TP You don't
need to open up the PPTP Ports.

616
00:30:24.800 --> 00:30:27.330
If you're just using PPTP,
you don't have to open up the L2TP.

617
00:30:27.330 --> 00:30:30.950
But if you're using both, you're
going to need to open them all up and

618
00:30:30.950 --> 00:30:35.190
let them through to be able to get to
the Mac that's acting as your VPN server.

619
00:30:35.190 --> 00:30:36.840
If you can, you'll be able to connect.

620
00:30:36.840 --> 00:30:39.660
If you can't,
you won't even make it to the server, and

621
00:30:39.660 --> 00:30:41.550
that's just going to kill it right there.

622
00:30:41.550 --> 00:30:44.130
Don't expect to see
intermittent disconnects.

623
00:30:44.130 --> 00:30:47.480
If you get intermittent disconnects,
it's not gonna be because of a firewall.

624
00:30:47.480 --> 00:30:50.170
It's going to be because of
things like network congestion,

625
00:30:50.170 --> 00:30:52.840
poor wireless networks, low bandwidth.

626
00:30:52.840 --> 00:30:56.250
That's what's going to cause you to
intermittently disconnect and that's

627
00:30:56.250 --> 00:30:59.870
not the fault of the VPN or your firewall,
it's the fault of your network connection.

628
00:30:59.870 --> 00:31:03.880
But once you're connected you can kind
of rule the firewall out as a problem.

629
00:31:03.880 --> 00:31:05.220
You've already passed
through the firewall,

630
00:31:05.220 --> 00:31:08.060
you got connected, everything else
is gonna be tied to the network.

631
00:31:08.060 --> 00:31:11.110
>> Don, with the Generic Routing
Encapsulation protocol is there any kind

632
00:31:11.110 --> 00:31:14.500
of identifier or anything that I
can ensure that it is turned on?

633
00:31:14.500 --> 00:31:17.339
Cuz you said the protocol itself, is
there any identifier associated with it?

634
00:31:18.632 --> 00:31:23.340
Not really, you have these [INAUDIBLE]
that define these protocol numbers, and

635
00:31:23.340 --> 00:31:25.120
GRE is actually protocol number 47.

636
00:31:25.120 --> 00:31:28.140
So on some firewalls they'll
call it protocol 47.

637
00:31:28.140 --> 00:31:30.810
But normally they just call it GRE.

638
00:31:30.810 --> 00:31:35.000
And so TCP 1723 and GRE or protocol 47,

639
00:31:35.000 --> 00:31:39.060
those need to be open, that's going
to make sure we have functionality.

640
00:31:39.060 --> 00:31:44.600
There's a few others that you might bump
into with L2TP, which is, let's see,

641
00:31:44.600 --> 00:31:50.885
I've got them jotted down here, UDP port
500, UDP port 1701 and UDP port 4500.

642
00:31:50.885 --> 00:31:56.559
But if I enable all of those on a PPTP and
L2TP functionality If I just want L2TP,

643
00:31:56.559 --> 00:32:00.911
you can actually get away with
just the last three that i said.

644
00:32:00.911 --> 00:32:05.278
The UDP500, UDP1701 and UDP4500.

645
00:32:05.278 --> 00:32:07.820
You guys probably notice I'm
looking at my notes on that.

646
00:32:07.820 --> 00:32:08.790
I don't have these memorized.

647
00:32:08.790 --> 00:32:11.060
They don't expect you to have them
memorized on the exam, either.

648
00:32:11.060 --> 00:32:13.760
But, just know that these are the port
numbers that you've gotta have open

649
00:32:13.760 --> 00:32:14.590
on that firewall.

650
00:32:14.590 --> 00:32:16.590
>> All right, I'm going to test
my memory on this one, Don, and

651
00:32:16.590 --> 00:32:18.410
see if I can remember.

652
00:32:18.410 --> 00:32:21.390
Boy, those UDP ports,
that port 500 and that port 4500,

653
00:32:21.390 --> 00:32:23.730
those really sound like
IPsec encryption ports.

654
00:32:23.730 --> 00:32:24.780
Is that what we're looking at there?

655
00:32:24.780 --> 00:32:25.760
>> That's exactly it.

656
00:32:25.760 --> 00:32:28.400
It L2TP is using IPsec.

657
00:32:28.400 --> 00:32:30.850
That's what it's using to encrypt and
secures data.

658
00:32:30.850 --> 00:32:31.870
IPsec is not a protocol.

659
00:32:31.870 --> 00:32:35.410
It's actually a framework, so
multiple protocols to get in the mix, and

660
00:32:35.410 --> 00:32:38.190
so you'll see all sorts of different
things that bump up there.

661
00:32:38.190 --> 00:32:40.760
Another one that can creep up,
it's another protocol,

662
00:32:42.030 --> 00:32:46.590
GRE is the Generic Routing Encapsulation
and PPTP really likes to use that.

663
00:32:46.590 --> 00:32:52.950
L2TP will typically use ESP,
the Encapsulating Security Payload.

664
00:32:52.950 --> 00:32:54.000
There we go, ESP.

665
00:32:54.000 --> 00:32:55.660
And that one is protocol 50.

666
00:32:55.660 --> 00:32:59.260
So protocol 47 for GRE,
protocol 50 for ESP.

667
00:32:59.260 --> 00:33:01.360
Those two get into the mix also.

668
00:33:01.360 --> 00:33:03.620
These are all different
ports that get into the mix.

669
00:33:03.620 --> 00:33:06.850
And like I said, if they're not open,
you just won't connect, right.

670
00:33:06.850 --> 00:33:09.310
And so you just don't get in
there in the first place.

671
00:33:09.310 --> 00:33:13.370
But, once you get connected, usually the
only reason you get disconnected is if you

672
00:33:13.370 --> 00:33:16.740
stayed connected too long,
cuz there is a maximum time on a tunnel.

673
00:33:16.740 --> 00:33:18.970
Usually something less than 24 hours.

674
00:33:18.970 --> 00:33:21.460
And then the other thing is just
if the network gets too congested,

675
00:33:21.460 --> 00:33:23.920
you start dropping too many packets,
you can get disconnected.

676
00:33:23.920 --> 00:33:27.260
And when you get disconnected now you're
not gonna be able to talk to those remote

677
00:33:27.260 --> 00:33:27.870
hosts anymore.

678
00:33:27.870 --> 00:33:30.310
You become isolated and unsecured.

679
00:33:30.310 --> 00:33:34.370
So, all different things to think about
to make sure that we secure the system.

680
00:33:34.370 --> 00:33:37.910
Another thing you can do if you ever wanna
test, you can fire up a network sniffer

681
00:33:37.910 --> 00:33:41.040
and see if your traffic's actually
getting encrypted on the network.

682
00:33:41.040 --> 00:33:43.860
You're average end user's not gonna
do that, but as an admin you can do

683
00:33:43.860 --> 00:33:47.340
it to see and actually verify your
VPNs doing what it's supposed to do.

684
00:33:47.340 --> 00:33:51.100
>> A lot of great information on VPNs, and
I love it when we talk security there.

685
00:33:51.100 --> 00:33:54.380
Now, I know in the past I've talked to you
before, supporting them sometimes can be

686
00:33:54.380 --> 00:33:57.440
a little bit difficult, but it does look
like we're coming to the end of another

687
00:33:57.440 --> 00:34:01.170
episode here Don, but before we do,
do you got any additional advice on VPNs?

688
00:34:01.170 --> 00:34:02.770
>> If they don't work, right?

689
00:34:02.770 --> 00:34:05.240
If things aren't working your
firewall is a great place to check,

690
00:34:05.240 --> 00:34:06.040
one thing to look at.

691
00:34:07.340 --> 00:34:09.387
Also you have logs on your server,
like everything,

692
00:34:09.387 --> 00:34:10.756
I can pull those up here real quick.

693
00:34:10.756 --> 00:34:14.906
So, if I go to the server app, and
I go to logs and I go to my system log,

694
00:34:14.906 --> 00:34:19.588
you've got a VPN service log in there and
it will show you people connecting.

695
00:34:19.588 --> 00:34:23.000
If somebody tries to connect and
it fails, it will turn up in here.

696
00:34:23.000 --> 00:34:26.810
You can also see whether people
are connecting with L2TP or PPTP and

697
00:34:26.810 --> 00:34:28.960
evaluate how they're connecting.

698
00:34:28.960 --> 00:34:31.540
Earlier I tried to connect and
I had a bad password, right.

699
00:34:31.540 --> 00:34:36.710
So if I scroll back through the logs,
here I can see user dpezet authorized for

700
00:34:36.710 --> 00:34:39.120
access, that's when I was
actually able to connect.

701
00:34:39.120 --> 00:34:42.445
But if I keep going back I should be
able to find where I tried to connect as

702
00:34:42.445 --> 00:34:44.195
donpozet right here.

703
00:34:44.195 --> 00:34:47.085
CHAP peer authentication failed for
donpozet.

704
00:34:47.085 --> 00:34:51.595
So, you can start to see and then find
out this is why he was disconnected.

705
00:34:51.595 --> 00:34:56.557
He tried to connect with L2TP but got
disconnected because bad password, right.

706
00:34:56.557 --> 00:34:57.800
Authentication failure.

707
00:34:57.800 --> 00:35:01.470
In my case, it was bad user name,
not bad password, but you get the idea.

708
00:35:01.470 --> 00:35:04.370
So, remember that you've got these logs
that if you need to troubleshoot and

709
00:35:04.370 --> 00:35:07.160
find out why something went wrong,
this is a great place to look.

710
00:35:07.160 --> 00:35:08.940
>> Well,
Don we appreciate that information and

711
00:35:08.940 --> 00:35:12.080
we appreciate you the viewer for
watching, signing up for ITProTV.

712
00:35:12.080 --> 00:35:13.940
I've been your host Wes Bryan.

713
00:35:13.940 --> 00:35:14.670
>> I'm Don Pizet.

714
00:35:14.670 --> 00:35:16.279
>> And we'll see you next time.

715

Welcome back to another exciting

3
00:00:14.653 --> 00:00:16.394
I'm your host Wes Bryan and

00:00:16.394 --> 00:00:21.481
today's episode we're continuing through
our OS X Server Essential series.

5
00:00:21.481 --> 00:00:24.381
And what we're looking at today
is providing network services,

6
00:00:24.381 --> 00:00:26.730
more specifically web services.

7
00:00:26.730 --> 00:00:29.000
And we've got none other than Mr.
Don Pezet in the house.

8
00:00:29.000 --> 00:00:30.180
Don, how are you doing sir?

9
00:00:30.180 --> 00:00:30.850
>> I'm doing great Wes.

10
00:00:30.850 --> 00:00:33.530
Ready to dive right back into
the world of the server app in OS X.

11
00:00:33.530 --> 00:00:35.380
And looking at a web server.

12
00:00:35.380 --> 00:00:38.850
Right now a lot of organizations use
web servers for various purposes.

13
00:00:38.850 --> 00:00:41.640
You might have web applications,
you might have an internal website.

14
00:00:41.640 --> 00:00:45.290
Or maybe you're just messing around and

15
00:00:45.290 --> 00:00:48.128
Well, the server app has support for that.

16
00:00:48.128 --> 00:00:51.300
I know I've mentioned in other episodes
how really the server app is a graphical

17
00:00:51.300 --> 00:00:53.920
user interface to a lot of
open source technologies.

18
00:00:53.920 --> 00:00:55.960
So these are things that Apple
didn't have to create from scratch,

19
00:00:55.960 --> 00:00:57.560
they just made the UI for it.

00:00:57.560 --> 00:00:58.860
The web server is no exception.

21
00:00:58.860 --> 00:01:02.140
So the web server available in

Apache is the most common

23
00:01:05.530 --> 00:01:07.920
Some people say that nginX

00:01:07.920 --> 00:01:10.410
but nginX is not technically a web server,

25
00:01:10.410 --> 00:01:12.990
So Apache is the most popular

26
00:01:12.990 --> 00:01:14.850
and, it's built in to your Mac.

00:01:14.850 --> 00:01:19.040

00:01:19.040 --> 00:01:21.880

This first one, I just wanna

How it works, what it does, how we can

38

get our own site created.

39

In the next episode we're gonna

Actually getting executable programs

00:01:54.470 --> 00:01:56.880
Its neat stuff, definitely

00:01:59.350 --> 00:02:03.770
For the basics I think most of you

00:02:03.770 --> 00:02:06.440
So its a server that's holding
a bunch of web pages, and

00:02:06.440 --> 00:02:10.460

in HTML, hyper text markup language.

48
00:02:10.460 --> 00:02:14.080

files that are in HTML format.

00:02:14.080 --> 00:02:18.290

00:26:35.320 --> 00:26:38.280
And the script runs on the server.

493
00:26:38.280 --> 00:26:42.120
So the end user,
they see whatever we echo.

494
00:26:42.120 --> 00:26:42.790
This little blurb right here.

495
00:26:42.790 --> 00:26:44.480
They just see the HTML.

496
00:26:44.480 --> 00:26:48.339
But I can be pulling in variables querying
today's date, querying a user name,

497
00:26:48.339 --> 00:26:51.010
populating, you can do all
sorts of stuff with PHP.

498
00:26:51.010 --> 00:26:52.590
This isn't a programming show.

499
00:26:52.590 --> 00:26:54.320
But you can do a ton of stuff.

500
00:26:54.320 --> 00:26:58.554
But here I'm just managing this one line,
pulling it with PHP.

501
00:26:58.554 --> 00:27:00.280
All right, so let's see if this works.

502
00:27:01.400 --> 00:27:03.510
We'll see if I can write valid code.

503
00:27:03.510 --> 00:27:09.200
So I'm gonna go back to my browser, and
when I browse to the server on 8080,

504
00:27:09.200 --> 00:27:12.890
whoops, which I can't type,
so let me try that again.

505
00:27:12.890 --> 00:27:16.520
There we go, I get a message that
this text is rendered using HTML,

506
00:27:16.520 --> 00:27:21.210
I'm just going to add to the end of that,
/test.php.

507
00:27:21.210 --> 00:27:26.040
And now I get,
This text is rendered using PHP.

508
00:27:26.040 --> 00:27:29.410
And if I were to view
the source code of this page,

509
00:27:29.410 --> 00:27:32.010
which does Safari let us
view the source code?

510
00:27:33.500 --> 00:27:34.800
A lot of browsers have that option.

511
00:27:34.800 --> 00:27:37.930
I don't know if Safari lets us do it.

512
00:27:37.930 --> 00:27:42.370
But if we were to view the source code,
we actually won't see that PHP.

513
00:27:42.370 --> 00:27:48.390
All you'll see in here is HTML,
what was echoed out by PHP, and that's it.

514
00:27:48.390 --> 00:27:53.390
So we get just that kinda simplified view,
the server did the work.

515
00:27:53.390 --> 00:27:56.640
But it was easy enough, we just checked
that PHP box and now we're running it.

516
00:27:56.640 --> 00:27:59.870
And PHP needs updates,
just like anything, so

517
00:27:59.870 --> 00:28:02.950
you need to make sure that you're
running your updates on the server.

518
00:28:02.950 --> 00:28:04.730
Because Apache will get updated, and

519
00:28:04.730 --> 00:28:08.370
Apache will come along with PHP updates
also, and so those stay hand in hand.

520
00:28:09.680 --> 00:28:16.000
All right, so we've seen HTML,
we've seen PHP, we've created a website.

521
00:28:16.000 --> 00:28:18.470
Those are the basics for
getting this up and going.

522
00:28:19.550 --> 00:28:22.370
Be careful with port numbers because your
end users have to remember to type in

523
00:28:22.370 --> 00:28:23.010
those port numbers.

524
00:28:23.010 --> 00:28:24.590
That can always be a challenge.

525
00:28:24.590 --> 00:28:26.800
Be careful with DNS aliases.

526
00:28:26.800 --> 00:28:30.638
So for example, when I come in and
I add a website and attach it to an IP,

527
00:28:30.638 --> 00:28:33.610
I need some kind of DNS
alias that ties it to that.

528
00:28:33.610 --> 00:28:35.734
So for example,
let me show you real quick.

529
00:28:35.734 --> 00:28:37.528
I made lab.itpro.tv, but

530
00:28:37.528 --> 00:28:42.552
if somebody were to type in lab.itpro.tv
right now, what are they gonna get?

531
00:28:42.552 --> 00:28:43.570
They're gonna get nothing.

532
00:28:43.570 --> 00:28:45.840
I need DNS to go along with it, right?

533
00:28:45.840 --> 00:28:50.520
So when I look at lab.itpro.tv, it's
tied to all IP addresses on this server.

534
00:28:50.520 --> 00:28:51.916
I've only got one IP address.

535
00:28:51.916 --> 00:28:55.740
But I would need to go into DNS,
wherever I'm hosting that,

536
00:28:55.740 --> 00:28:58.270
which might be right here,
it might be on a public service.

537
00:28:58.270 --> 00:29:02.685
But I would need to go into DNS, and
I would need to create an entry for

538
00:29:02.685 --> 00:29:08.840
lab.itpro.tv that pointed to
this server's IP address.

539
00:29:08.840 --> 00:29:12.430
Now DNS will only point to IP addresses.

540
00:29:12.430 --> 00:29:14.511
It can't point to port numbers, right.

541
00:29:14.511 --> 00:29:18.820
So if I put this in here, and I create it.

542
00:29:18.820 --> 00:29:20.700
Now, somebody will be
able to do a lookup and

543
00:29:20.700 --> 00:29:24.545
they'll be able to find
out about lab.itpro.tv.

544
00:29:24.545 --> 00:29:27.880
But they won't necessarily know
to put in the port number, so

545
00:29:27.880 --> 00:29:29.690
that's where that becomes
a bit of a challenge.

546
00:29:29.690 --> 00:29:32.215
So the better option is if
you have more than one IP,

547
00:29:32.215 --> 00:29:35.860
cuz then you can have the DNS for
each site point to the different IPs, and

548
00:29:35.860 --> 00:29:38.595
now they're separated and
nobody has to remember port numbers.

549
00:29:38.595 --> 00:29:40.980
Cuz everybody can be reusing port 80.

550
00:29:40.980 --> 00:29:43.898
You can have port 80 on 5
different IPs and it's fine.

551
00:29:43.898 --> 00:29:46.809
So, it definitely makes things a little
smoother as far as your end user

552
00:29:46.809 --> 00:29:47.422
experience.

553
00:29:47.422 --> 00:29:51.510
All right, otherwise I think that's
about it for the basic web server.

554
00:29:51.510 --> 00:29:54.330
Just like all the other services you
do have your logs that you can look at.

555
00:29:54.330 --> 00:29:59.040
If i jump in to my logs up here,
I can filter my service logs and

556
00:29:59.040 --> 00:30:00.970
I can filter it down to
just the web servers.

557
00:30:00.970 --> 00:30:03.280
So if I filter that and
I come in and look,

558
00:30:03.280 --> 00:30:08.430
now notice on the websites we actually
have logs for each of the different sites.

559
00:30:08.430 --> 00:30:11.640
Here's lab.itpro.tv as
well as the default site.

560
00:30:11.640 --> 00:30:16.080
So those are in there, and I can go and
pull just the access log for

561
00:30:16.080 --> 00:30:17.450
the lab site that I just created.

562
00:30:17.450 --> 00:30:21.270
So you can see already clients connecting
to it, and I can pull up the error log,

563
00:30:21.270 --> 00:30:23.240
which hopefully I don't have any errors.

564
00:30:23.240 --> 00:30:29.065
But if I had written bad PHP, the errors
that PHP generates would be right in here.

565
00:30:29.065 --> 00:30:32.145
And I would see those,
in fact maybe I did make an error.

566
00:30:32.145 --> 00:30:34.355
So, let's see.

567
00:30:34.355 --> 00:30:35.475
No, these are just core notices.

568
00:30:35.475 --> 00:30:37.615
This is just it creating the log files.

569
00:30:37.615 --> 00:30:40.911
So when it starts up, it ties it to
a log file and that's all these are.

570
00:30:40.911 --> 00:30:42.269
Ooh, actually that's
a bad one right there.

571
00:30:42.269 --> 00:30:44.925
When, did that happen today?

572
00:30:44.925 --> 00:30:49.590
[LAUGH] Just real world kind of example
here,if you ever see a SIGTERM like this

573
00:30:49.590 --> 00:30:55.110
right, that's a signal termination,
and it means that a program crashed.

574
00:30:55.110 --> 00:30:57.668
Every PHP page that you write
is technically a program,

575
00:30:57.668 --> 00:30:58.927
it runs in the background.

576
00:30:58.927 --> 00:31:02.970
And so something ran and
crashed, and that's not good.

577
00:31:02.970 --> 00:31:05.450
So, that's telling me I've got a problem.

578
00:31:05.450 --> 00:31:09.990
My PHP, I might have had a non-terminating
character or something like that.

579
00:31:09.990 --> 00:31:11.980
And so I'm getting a SIGTERM.

580
00:31:11.980 --> 00:31:16.150
I can ignore it, except if you look,
I've got another SIGTERM right here.

581
00:31:16.150 --> 00:31:16.950
And another one here.

582
00:31:16.950 --> 00:31:19.930
So it's happening over and
over and over again.

583
00:31:19.930 --> 00:31:23.730
Which more than likely means I wrote some
bad PHP and I need to troubleshoot it.

584
00:31:23.730 --> 00:31:27.230
Fortunately, you've got a log
that you can jump into and look,

585
00:31:27.230 --> 00:31:32.980
the Apache error log right here,
/var/log/apache2/error_log.

586
00:31:32.980 --> 00:31:35.780
And so I can always go and
take a look at that and try and

587
00:31:35.780 --> 00:31:39.490
get an idea of what is going on.

588
00:31:39.490 --> 00:31:43.370
And it actually looks like it's
showing me pretty much the same thing.

589
00:31:43.370 --> 00:31:44.420
So not a lot of detail there.

590
00:31:44.420 --> 00:31:47.690
So I'm gonna need to add
some debug code to my PHP

591
00:31:47.690 --> 00:31:50.400
to be able to find out where
that's actually crashing out.

592
00:31:50.400 --> 00:31:53.230
But I can see here that
basically it's crashing.

593
00:31:53.230 --> 00:31:55.670
And then you've got this
resuming normal operations,

594
00:31:55.670 --> 00:31:57.940
where it's basically restarting Apache.

595
00:31:57.940 --> 00:31:59.109
That's a problem.

596
00:31:59.109 --> 00:32:01.550
It's a developer problem,
not my problem, fortunately.

597
00:32:01.550 --> 00:32:03.470
So you turn it over to them and
let them find out.

598
00:32:03.470 --> 00:32:09.260
But basically, the web server is a fully
functional installation of Apache and

599
00:32:09.260 --> 00:32:11.040
you fill your web pages in there,
it'll serve them up.

600
00:32:11.040 --> 00:32:11.730
It does a pretty good job.

601
00:32:11.730 --> 00:32:13.720
>> A lot of great information, Don.

602
00:32:13.720 --> 00:32:18.080
And thank you for pushing the ends
of your development knowledge there.

603
00:32:18.080 --> 00:32:20.940
But I do see that we are running
to the end of another episode.

604
00:32:20.940 --> 00:32:23.670
But we before sign out,
you got any additional words?

605
00:32:23.670 --> 00:32:25.920
>> What I showed you right
there was super basic, right.

606
00:32:25.920 --> 00:32:28.684
We did HTML, we did PHP, and that was it.

607
00:32:28.684 --> 00:32:32.084
Some of you are gonna wanna do bigger
things, like throw WordPress in there, or

608
00:32:32.084 --> 00:32:33.526
all sorts of crazy other things.

609
00:32:33.526 --> 00:32:35.097
And you certainly can do that.

610
00:32:35.097 --> 00:32:37.129
The functionality is there for
you to do it.

611
00:32:38.710 --> 00:32:42.910
But you'll bump into
things where like Apple

612
00:32:42.910 --> 00:32:45.650
doesn't necessarily run
the latest version of Apache.

613
00:32:45.650 --> 00:32:48.226
They don't necessarily run
the latest version of PHP.

614
00:32:48.226 --> 00:32:51.694
So if you really need the latest
versions of those softwares,

615
00:32:51.694 --> 00:32:56.150
you might not want to use the website
that's built into the server app.

616
00:32:56.150 --> 00:32:59.250
Instead, you might want to install
something like the Homebrew

617
00:32:59.250 --> 00:33:02.000
service into Apple, into OS X.

618
00:33:02.000 --> 00:33:05.640
And you can get the latest
version of Apache and MySQL, and

619
00:33:05.640 --> 00:33:10.000
all those other services that are a part
of whatever your web application is.

620
00:33:10.000 --> 00:33:13.550
So, just understand that this is
great as a basic web server, but

621
00:33:13.550 --> 00:33:15.290
when you wanna start
getting more advanced,

622
00:33:15.290 --> 00:33:19.030
Apple doesn't provide any support on this,
and so you're kind of left to your own.

623
00:33:19.030 --> 00:33:21.250
Don't hesitate to move away
from this web server and

624
00:33:21.250 --> 00:33:23.490
just natively install
Apache on the system.

625
00:33:23.490 --> 00:33:26.240
Use Brew to do that,
it'll make life a lot easier for you.

626
00:33:26.240 --> 00:33:27.840
>> Well, Don, we thank you for
that information.

627
00:33:27.840 --> 00:33:30.610
We thank you the viewer for joining
us today but we're gonna go ahead and

628
00:33:30.610 --> 00:33:32.340
sign out here at ITProTV.

629
00:33:32.340 --> 00:33:33.880
I've been your host, Wes Bryan.

630
00:33:33.880 --> 00:33:34.580
>> And I'm Don Pezet.

631
00:33:34.580 --> 00:33:36.765
>> And we'll see you next time.

632
00:33:36.765 --> 00:33:44.520
[MUSIC]

episodes.description: In this episode, Wes and Don dive into the more of the advanced configuration that can be performed on OS Xs Web Server. They discuss topics range from Server Side Includes, htaccess files, CGI execution, to customizing error pages.
episodes.title: Advanced Web Server
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.000 --> 00:00:10.000
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:11.806 --> 00:00:14.790
Welcome back to another exciting
episode here at ITPro TV.

3
00:00:14.790 --> 00:00:16.313
I'm your host Wes Bryan and

4
00:00:16.313 --> 00:00:21.220
in today's episode we're continuing
through our OS X server essentials series.

5
00:00:21.220 --> 00:00:23.770
And today we're looking at
providing network services.

6
00:00:23.770 --> 00:00:26.902
More specifically we're looking
at advanced web server.

7
00:00:26.902 --> 00:00:29.595
Joining me in the studio today is
none other than Mr. Don Pezet.

8
00:00:29.595 --> 00:00:30.775
Don, how are you doing today, sir?

9
00:00:30.775 --> 00:00:31.865
>> I'm doing great, Wes.

10
00:00:31.865 --> 00:00:34.975
Ready to jump right back into
the wacky world of web services.

11
00:00:34.975 --> 00:00:37.765
In our last episode, we had a chance
to see the web server that's

12
00:00:37.765 --> 00:00:40.275
built into the server app as part of OS X.

13
00:00:40.275 --> 00:00:42.499
And that web server, it's Apache so

00:00:42.499 --> 00:00:47.541
it's an open-source web server that's

15
00:00:47.541 --> 00:00:51.050
And we just saw the basic configuration.

16
00:00:51.050 --> 00:00:56.780
How to get a web server up and running and

17
00:00:56.780 --> 00:00:58.210
But in this episode,

18
00:00:58.210 --> 00:01:01.530
I wanna go a little bit deeper into
that web server cuz there's some really

00:01:01.530 --> 00:01:05.780
advanced features that you can turn

20
00:01:05.780 --> 00:01:07.600
So I just wanna run

00:01:07.600 --> 00:01:10.800
And then, I just want to show

00:01:10.800 --> 00:01:14.220
On the exam, they want you to be familiar
with what each of the advanced options

00:01:14.220 --> 00:01:19.010
are but they don't necessarily really
hit you on how to truly use them.

24
00:01:19.010 --> 00:01:20.660
And if you go out into the world,

25
00:01:20.660 --> 00:01:22.860
the documentation on this
is actually really light.

26
00:01:22.860 --> 00:01:26.320
Apple hasn't done a great job documenting
it because well, it's dance stuff,

27
00:01:26.320 --> 00:01:27.720
they figure you're already gonna know it.

28
00:01:27.720 --> 00:01:30.840
So I wanna show you guys an actual
implementation of how we can load

29
00:01:30.840 --> 00:01:34.740
something like a server based
application into the web server and

30
00:01:34.740 --> 00:01:35.920
get that fired up and going.

31
00:01:35.920 --> 00:01:40.010
It's a pretty neat process and we'll
get a chance to see it all right here.

32
00:01:40.010 --> 00:01:42.670
All right, well let's pick things
up kinda where we left off.

33
00:01:42.670 --> 00:01:45.520
We actually have an all new server
to use on this episode from the one

34
00:01:45.520 --> 00:01:46.790
that I had in the last episode.

35
00:01:46.790 --> 00:01:51.980
So I've got a OS X Server up and that
just means that its running El Capitan.

36
00:01:51.980 --> 00:01:53.501
I'm running, I think I'm on 10.11.3,

37
00:01:53.501 --> 00:01:56.530
10.11.5 is current, but
they're all the same.

38
00:01:56.530 --> 00:02:02.740
So I'm up and I'm running that one and I'm
not configured as a web server just yet.

39
00:02:02.740 --> 00:02:05.947
So if I look over here at my left bar,
I can come down here and

40
00:02:05.947 --> 00:02:08.509
find websites and
I don't have the green dot.

41
00:02:08.509 --> 00:02:09.670
So I'm not a web server.

42
00:02:09.670 --> 00:02:12.694
And in our last episode, we walked
through all these different options,

43
00:02:12.694 --> 00:02:14.340
how to get things configured.

44
00:02:14.340 --> 00:02:17.250
I'm just gonna come in here and
turn this thing on.

45
00:02:17.250 --> 00:02:17.820
So there we go.

46
00:02:17.820 --> 00:02:18.790
So now I'm up and

47
00:02:18.790 --> 00:02:22.400
I'm running just the default web
server that's a part of my system.

48
00:02:22.400 --> 00:02:28.210
Now notice how my available statement up
here says that it's OSX-SERVER01.local.

49
00:02:28.210 --> 00:02:29.500
That's my local name.

50
00:02:29.500 --> 00:02:34.590
And my local name is not necessarily what
I wanna serve my website up as, right.

51
00:02:34.590 --> 00:02:37.040
So I probably want to set something up

52
00:02:37.040 --> 00:02:40.860
that is named a little more
appropriate from what this is.

53
00:02:40.860 --> 00:02:45.220
Now, that name right there
is actually being pulled

54
00:02:45.220 --> 00:02:47.220
from the main server configuration.

55
00:02:47.220 --> 00:02:50.030
So if I go up here to OSX-SERVER01,
I can look and

56
00:02:50.030 --> 00:02:52.660
there's my host name, OSX-SERVER01.Local.

57
00:02:52.660 --> 00:02:56.630
So that's where that name comes from and
that's where people are kinda seeing this.

58
00:02:56.630 --> 00:03:00.100
Now, if I wanna change the name
of the whole sever, I can.

59
00:03:00.100 --> 00:03:03.790
If I want this to be www.ITProTV.com,

60
00:03:03.790 --> 00:03:08.320
I could change the name
of my server to that.

61
00:03:08.320 --> 00:03:10.380
But I might have more than one web server.

62
00:03:10.380 --> 00:03:14.810
I might have five web servers that
are all serving up www.ITProTV.com,

63
00:03:14.810 --> 00:03:17.060
because I know I might
get a lot of traffic.

64
00:03:17.060 --> 00:03:19.700
I don't want all my servers
to have the same name,

65
00:03:19.700 --> 00:03:20.790
that's going to cause some problems.

66
00:03:20.790 --> 00:03:24.750
We normally leave that as some kind of
generic name, based on this server.

67
00:03:24.750 --> 00:03:29.020
But on the site, we go in and
we give it an alias, right?

68
00:03:29.020 --> 00:03:32.088
So when we look at this site here,
I've got Server Website,

69
00:03:32.088 --> 00:03:36.510
it's tied to all my IP addresses,
it's on Port 80, and I can edit that.

70
00:03:36.510 --> 00:03:41.140
And in the definition, you'll start
to see things like Aliases and

71
00:03:41.140 --> 00:03:42.090
Additional Domains.

72
00:03:42.090 --> 00:03:44.400
Now Aliases are sub-directories,
Additional Domains,

73
00:03:44.400 --> 00:03:45.450
that's the domain name itself.

74
00:03:45.450 --> 00:03:51.486
And I'm gonna add one to mine, so
that I call it Lab.itpro.tv, all right?

75
00:03:51.486 --> 00:03:57.450
So I'm just going to add that alias in
here, so the server is OSX-server01.

76
00:03:57.450 --> 00:04:00.630
And I might have server 02,
server 03, server 04, but

77
00:04:00.630 --> 00:04:04.840
they all have an alias of lab.itpro.tv
that's shared across them, right?

78
00:04:04.840 --> 00:04:06.774
So I'm just setting that domain name.

79
00:04:06.774 --> 00:04:08.340
Now, understand in order for

80
00:04:08.340 --> 00:04:12.585
this work I probably need a DNS server
set up to be able to resolve this.

81
00:04:12.585 --> 00:04:17.350
And you may or may not host your own DNS
server, you might have your registrar

82
00:04:17.350 --> 00:04:20.715
where you registered your domain with or
