file that registered it.

537
00:27:03.480 --> 00:27:06.640
And normally, I'd say time to check for
some typos, but

538
00:27:06.640 --> 00:27:10.710
this time I copied the files so I know
there's no typo in there, they're right.

539
00:27:10.710 --> 00:27:15.310
So I must have missed a step, and
I can kind of think of it already here.

540
00:27:15.310 --> 00:27:20.356
When we mounted to this, that is an alias,
right, /example is an alias.

541
00:27:20.356 --> 00:27:25.488
And I pointed out earlier how even
though we've got these guys /wsgi and

542
00:27:25.488 --> 00:27:29.613
/example, that if I go back
into my Advanced Settings and

543
00:27:29.613 --> 00:27:34.010
I look at aliases,
there's no aliases configured, right.

544
00:27:34.010 --> 00:27:36.031
If I edit that,
there's no folders that are mapped.

545
00:27:36.031 --> 00:27:38.644
So how does it actually know
that those aliases exist?

546
00:27:38.644 --> 00:27:43.296
And the answer is Python applications
don't have an alias listed here, but

547
00:27:43.296 --> 00:27:48.110
they do have an alias registered in the
background and I forgot to register it.

548
00:27:48.110 --> 00:27:49.980
So that's the third step that I missed.

549
00:27:49.980 --> 00:27:52.150
You gotta copy your application
to the web app folder.

550
00:27:52.150 --> 00:27:54.850
You gotta create the plist
file to register it.

551
00:27:54.850 --> 00:27:58.090
And then you've got to add the alias,
and I have not done that.

552
00:27:58.090 --> 00:28:01.560
So let me fire up my terminal and
we will fix that.

553
00:28:01.560 --> 00:28:04.612
And the way this works
is the alias is actually

554
00:28:04.612 --> 00:28:07.755
stored in the configuration file for
Apache.

555
00:28:07.755 --> 00:28:15.475
So I need to get back into
/Library/Server,/Web/Config/apache2.

556
00:28:15.475 --> 00:28:17.556
So I'm gonna get all the way back there,
and

557
00:28:17.556 --> 00:28:20.520
that's where we saw all
those various Apache files.

558
00:28:20.520 --> 00:28:27.580
And the one I'm looking for
in here is called httpd_wsgi.conf, right.

559
00:28:27.580 --> 00:28:31.330
That's the configuration file for
all of the registered Python apps.

560
00:28:31.330 --> 00:28:36.690
And so I'm gonna edit that file and

561
00:28:36.690 --> 00:28:40.560
inside of it, I have to do a sudo,
cuz you gotta be an administrator.

562
00:28:40.560 --> 00:28:45.780
But inside of it, I can see right here the
alias for Apple, right, for their example.

563
00:28:45.780 --> 00:28:48.690
And I just need to add to this, mine.

564
00:28:48.690 --> 00:28:53.490
So I'm just gonna come in here and
say, WSGIScriptAlias,

565
00:28:53.490 --> 00:28:56.260
which if I spell right will
work a little bit better.

566
00:28:57.350 --> 00:29:01.903
And I'm gonna mount mine to /example,
instead of /wsgi like they're doing.

567
00:29:01.903 --> 00:29:07.868
And it'll be
/Library/Server/Web/Data/WebApps/,

568
00:29:07.868 --> 00:29:12.689
and then mine was called example.wsgi,
right.

569
00:29:12.689 --> 00:29:15.443
That's how it's gonna know
about that subdirectory.

570
00:29:15.443 --> 00:29:18.752
That's how it'll know about that
mapping and it'll put it in place.

571
00:29:18.752 --> 00:29:20.772
Let me just save that.

572
00:29:20.772 --> 00:29:23.765
And so now that I've got the alias
in there, I'm good to go,

573
00:29:23.765 --> 00:29:26.010
but I do need to restart
the web server again.

574
00:29:26.010 --> 00:29:33.110
So I'm gonna restart it just one more time
with a little sudo apachectl restart.

575
00:29:34.800 --> 00:29:39.820
And now my web application's registered,
it's turned on, and the alias is there.

576
00:29:39.820 --> 00:29:42.316
So hopefully it'll work this time,
hopefully.

577
00:29:42.316 --> 00:29:46.070
So [LAUGH] so I'll fire up Safari again.

578
00:29:46.070 --> 00:29:47.570
I'm gonna pull up Apple's example.

579
00:29:49.320 --> 00:29:51.810
All right, and now I'm gonna try and
pull up my example.

580
00:29:53.260 --> 00:29:55.980
And, it still didn't load.

581
00:29:55.980 --> 00:29:57.070
So why didn't it load?

582
00:29:57.070 --> 00:30:03.340
Well, I restarted Apache, but it may
not have recognized that taking affect.

583
00:30:03.340 --> 00:30:04.420
So I'm just gonna do one more thing.

584
00:30:04.420 --> 00:30:11.470
I'm gonna go into the server app and make
sure that I actually did turn that app on.

585
00:30:11.470 --> 00:30:12.550
So it is on.

586
00:30:13.640 --> 00:30:16.790
And then I 'm just gonna flip
the old power switch here and

587
00:30:16.790 --> 00:30:19.640
give it just a second to stop and then
I'll flip it and turn it back on again.

588
00:30:19.640 --> 00:30:21.500
Just one more quick restart
to make sure it gets that.

589
00:30:21.500 --> 00:30:23.486
The other thing is my web browser
might be causing the problem, so

590
00:30:23.486 --> 00:30:24.796
I'm gonna close Safari and open it again.

591
00:30:24.796 --> 00:30:29.474
But assuming that it does,
then it should work and we should be in.

592
00:30:29.474 --> 00:30:30.973
All right, so that's started.

593
00:30:30.973 --> 00:30:37.136
I'm gonna get out of Safari and
relaunch Safari, and we'll try and

594
00:30:37.136 --> 00:30:42.665
browse that one more time,
so live.itpro.tv/example.

595
00:30:42.665 --> 00:30:44.347
There we go, now it's working for us.

596
00:30:44.347 --> 00:30:48.350
So I can see this text is
rendered using Python, right.

597
00:30:48.350 --> 00:30:50.490
So my Python app is now firing.

598
00:30:50.490 --> 00:30:51.920
It was a lot of steps to go through,
right.

599
00:30:51.920 --> 00:30:54.290
I had to copy the app
to the web apps folder.

600
00:30:54.290 --> 00:30:57.970
I had to register it with a plist file,
and then I had to create the alias for

601
00:30:57.970 --> 00:30:58.500
the subfolder.

602
00:30:58.500 --> 00:30:59.800
But once all that was done,

603
00:31:01.020 --> 00:31:03.460
now I've got a valid web
application that's up and running.

604
00:31:03.460 --> 00:31:05.590
And I can actually use it on
more than one site if I want.

605
00:31:05.590 --> 00:31:09.170
Because if I've got a secure version of
the site, I'll actually need to go into

606
00:31:09.170 --> 00:31:12.780
the server manager, and
edit the secure version of the site, and

607
00:31:12.780 --> 00:31:15.940
go into Advanced Settings and
turn it on there, too, right.

608
00:31:15.940 --> 00:31:19.050
So I've gotta enable those applications
to be able to run on the site.

609
00:31:19.050 --> 00:31:23.200
So you may need to reuse that in more than
one place or it could just be tied here.

610
00:31:23.200 --> 00:31:27.650
But now you've got a lot more power,
but without a GUI to manage it.

611
00:31:27.650 --> 00:31:29.040
>> Don, thanks for that information.

612
00:31:29.040 --> 00:31:32.360
A lot of great information here and
advance configurations as well.

613
00:31:32.360 --> 00:31:35.190
Now, I do see that we're creeping
up on the end of another episode.

614
00:31:35.190 --> 00:31:38.990
Before we do though,
do you have any additional information?

615
00:31:38.990 --> 00:31:40.030
>> That's really about it.

616
00:31:40.030 --> 00:31:41.250
Just be careful with these things.

617
00:31:41.250 --> 00:31:44.858
And you'll find that if you have
a really complex web application,

618
00:31:44.858 --> 00:31:48.560
the server app and Apple subsystems
just may not be able to handle it.

619
00:31:48.560 --> 00:31:52.810
So don't hesitate to install full-blown
Apache on your system if you need it.

620
00:31:52.810 --> 00:31:56.220
You can use the Brew app to install that
really quickly and get it up and running,

621
00:31:56.220 --> 00:31:59.720
especially if you need advanced
things like a MySQL database.

622
00:31:59.720 --> 00:32:01.910
That can work out a lot
better in many scenarios.

623
00:32:01.910 --> 00:32:03.450
So don't hesitate to do that.

624
00:32:03.450 --> 00:32:04.530
This web server's great.

625
00:32:04.530 --> 00:32:07.580
It works fine, but
the more complex your configuration,

626
00:32:07.580 --> 00:32:10.430
the more difficult it becomes to support,
so just be aware of that.

627
00:32:10.430 --> 00:32:11.580
>> Well, Don, we thank you for that.

628
00:32:11.580 --> 00:32:13.600
And we thank you,
the viewer out there, for watching.

629
00:32:13.600 --> 00:32:16.160
We're gonna go ahead and
sign off here at ITProTV.

630
00:32:16.160 --> 00:32:17.680
I've been your host, Wes Bryan.

631
00:32:17.680 --> 00:32:19.721
>> And I'm Don Pezet.
>> And we'll see you next time.

632
00:32:19.721 --> 00:32:28.080
[MUSIC]

episodes.description: In this episode, Wes and Don explore using OS X Server to create Wiki Websites. They discuss the basics to consider when implementing Wiki Websites as well showing the viewer how to create a Wiki. They talk about Blogs and their characteristics as well as demonstrating how to create a blog.
episodes.title: Wiki Websites
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.178 --> 00:00:10.178
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:11.858 --> 00:00:14.660
Welcome back to another exciting
episode here at ITProTV.

3
00:00:14.660 --> 00:00:16.300
I'm your host Wes Bryan.

4
00:00:16.300 --> 00:00:20.930
And in today's episode we're moving
through our OS10 Server Essentials.

5
00:00:20.930 --> 00:00:22.780
Now through the last couple of episodes,

6
00:00:22.780 --> 00:00:25.060
we've really been focusing
on network services.

7
00:00:25.060 --> 00:00:26.760
Well, it's gonna change
up a little bit today and

8
00:00:26.760 --> 00:00:30.350
we're gonna be talking about
collaborative services and Wiki websites.

9
00:00:30.350 --> 00:00:33.530
And joining us in the studios to help us
with that very endeavor is none other than

10
00:00:33.530 --> 00:00:34.360
Mr Don Pezet.

11
00:00:34.360 --> 00:00:35.680
Don, how you doing today, sir?

12
00:00:35.680 --> 00:00:37.610
>> I'm doing great, Wes,
ready to jump into our new section.

13
00:00:37.610 --> 00:00:40.030
And when we call it a new section,

14
00:00:40.030 --> 00:00:42.920
really all these collaborative
services are network services.

15
00:00:42.920 --> 00:00:44.960
But they're network services
that have a common goal.

16
00:00:44.960 --> 00:00:47.550
And that goal is to help
people talk to each other.

17
00:00:47.550 --> 00:00:50.960
So, I know, you could just go and talk
to somebody but God forbid we did that.

18
00:00:50.960 --> 00:00:53.495
So instead, we've got a number of
different different services here that we

19
00:00:53.495 --> 00:00:57.375
can use to collaborate things like
the email server and the wiki server.

20
00:00:57.375 --> 00:01:01.445
Now wiki is one of those things that
10 years ago nobody cared about and

21
00:01:01.445 --> 00:01:02.345
it seemed like a dumb idea.

22
00:01:02.345 --> 00:01:06.160
But today people use wiki
type services all the time.

23
00:01:06.160 --> 00:01:07.960
If you're not familiar what wikis, well,

24
00:01:07.960 --> 00:01:11.220
you probably heard of Wikipedia which is
one of them biggest examples of this.

25
00:01:11.220 --> 00:01:13.450
All a wiki is is a webpage.

26
00:01:13.450 --> 00:01:17.250
But unlike a normal webpage that
has content that you can just view,

27
00:01:17.250 --> 00:01:19.830
a wiki can be edited and changed.

28
00:01:19.830 --> 00:01:23.090
And so you can use it just like a central
notice board of sorts, where people can

29
00:01:23.090 --> 00:01:27.120
post information and edit and change
the data to keep it lively and relevant.

30
00:01:27.120 --> 00:01:30.760
A lot of companies use these internally
for employees to do knowledge transfer,

31
00:01:30.760 --> 00:01:32.150
to exchange information.

32
00:01:32.150 --> 00:01:33.800
So they're powerful from that respect.

33
00:01:33.800 --> 00:01:37.080
But you can also have it where
your customers make use of it to

34
00:01:37.080 --> 00:01:39.680
help flesh out the documentation for
your product, or whatever.

35
00:01:39.680 --> 00:01:43.000
Which is, one of the, I guess,
sadder uses of wikis.

36
00:01:43.000 --> 00:01:44.270
But it is a neat function and

37
00:01:44.270 --> 00:01:48.860
we do have a wiki server built
right into the server app in OS X.

38
00:01:48.860 --> 00:01:53.490
Now, it is turned off by default and it
is built on top of the website's service.

39
00:01:53.490 --> 00:01:57.380
So, it's very similar to what we
covered in the website service.

40
00:01:57.380 --> 00:02:02.500
But when we talk about websites, that
was simply us making pages available for

41
00:02:02.500 --> 00:02:03.860
viewing by other users.

42
00:02:03.860 --> 00:02:07.240
We weren't letting users
edit the site at all.

43
00:02:07.240 --> 00:02:11.560
With the wiki, we do allow them to edit
and we don't require third party software

44
00:02:11.560 --> 00:02:15.260
for it or anything like that, they can
edit it right from their web browser.

45
00:02:15.260 --> 00:02:18.390
It's actually using web distributed
authoring versioning here, WEBDAV,

46
00:02:18.390 --> 00:02:20.130
to be able to provide that functionality.

47
00:02:20.130 --> 00:02:23.390
And it's entirely web based which
means you don't have software you

48
00:02:23.390 --> 00:02:24.520
have to use to support it.

49
00:02:24.520 --> 00:02:29.012
People can be on a Linux box, Windows,
Mac, whatever, and they can edit the Wiki,

50
00:02:29.012 --> 00:02:31.758
access the information and
do whatever they need.

51
00:02:31.758 --> 00:02:34.350
Let's take a look at the service.

52
00:02:34.350 --> 00:02:37.920
This is one of those services that's
really simple to get fired up.

53
00:02:37.920 --> 00:02:40.040
If you go into your server app and
look down the left side,

54
00:02:40.040 --> 00:02:43.590
you've got websites which you don't
necessarily have to have turned on.

55
00:02:43.590 --> 00:02:45.130
I've got mine turned on already.

56
00:02:45.130 --> 00:02:48.400
When you turn on wiki, it's gonna turn
on the website functionality anyway.

57
00:02:48.400 --> 00:02:50.140
So they kind of go hand in hand.

58
00:02:50.140 --> 00:02:52.130
But when you go to the wiki service,

59
00:02:52.130 --> 00:02:56.150
there's not a whole lot
we can customize on it.

60
00:02:56.150 --> 00:02:59.030
You can edit permissions as far
as who's allowed to use it.

61
00:02:59.030 --> 00:03:00.120
So that's kind of a nice thing.

62
00:03:00.120 --> 00:03:02.320
You might not want everybody
to be able to access it.

63
00:03:02.320 --> 00:03:06.835
And then after that enable
WebDAV access to Wiki files.

64
00:03:06.835 --> 00:03:09.680
You can actually use the Wikis and

65
00:03:09.680 --> 00:03:13.120
edit the content without
having WebDAV turned on.

66
00:03:13.120 --> 00:03:16.200
But if you have it turned on,
you can use third party software and

67
00:03:16.200 --> 00:03:17.160
actually melt the files, and

68
00:03:17.160 --> 00:03:19.790
if you need to make bulk changes
that becomes a lot more convenient.

69
00:03:19.790 --> 00:03:23.050
So you've got the ability to turn
that on or off, that's up to you.

70
00:03:23.050 --> 00:03:26.190
But otherwise, there's not really
much that we need to tweak.

71
00:03:26.190 --> 00:03:26.700
Notice here,

72
00:03:26.700 --> 00:03:31.420
it says that if we have WebDAV turned on,
IOS users can edit the files using iWork.

73
00:03:31.420 --> 00:03:34.610
They can actually fire up the iWork app,
which is kinda being replaced right now,

74
00:03:34.610 --> 00:03:38.250
but anyhow, they can use it to access
that and start to modify those files very

75
00:03:38.250 --> 00:03:40.690
easily, but they could just as
well do it from the Web browser.

76
00:03:41.750 --> 00:03:45.310
All right, so as far as configuration
there's not much to be seen here.

77
00:03:45.310 --> 00:03:48.220
And that's because it's kind of
similar to the profile manager.

78
00:03:48.220 --> 00:03:50.370
Where profile manager you
turn on in the server app,

79
00:03:50.370 --> 00:03:54.300
and then everything else you do via
the webpage, that's how the wikis are.

80
00:03:54.300 --> 00:03:57.530
You turn it on here,
everything else you do via the webpage.

81
00:03:57.530 --> 00:03:58.470
So, I'm gonna turn this on.

82
00:03:58.470 --> 00:04:01.380
I'm gonna try and turn it on, there we go.

83
00:04:01.380 --> 00:04:05.090
And right now it says,
all users can create wikis.

84
00:04:05.090 --> 00:04:07.250
I could change that to say that you know,
just me.

85
00:04:07.250 --> 00:04:09.690
I'm able to create wikis and
the other people can use it.

86
00:04:09.690 --> 00:04:12.760
But, I'm gonna leave it where
all my users can do this.

87
00:04:12.760 --> 00:04:15.400
Then, everything else is
done via the web page.

88
00:04:15.400 --> 00:04:16.950
We fire up our browser.

89
00:04:16.950 --> 00:04:18.940
And when we browse to it,

90
00:04:18.940 --> 00:04:24.030
the default path is whatever your
server name is /wiki, right.

91
00:04:24.030 --> 00:04:27.620
So, that's the folder that it's gonna
send us to, right there, /wiki.

92
00:04:27.620 --> 00:04:30.730
And so, in the background,
I see that Welcome to the server.

93
00:04:30.730 --> 00:04:34.960
I'm now connected to the Wiki
service inside of my server app.

94
00:04:34.960 --> 00:04:40.230
Now as you look at it here, it's showing
us kinda this default overview page.

95
00:04:41.280 --> 00:04:44.070
And we don't see a whole lot of
information here because it's locked.

96
00:04:44.070 --> 00:04:47.310
Up at the top it's telling me,
log in to access more services.

97
00:04:47.310 --> 00:04:50.060
And I got a little gear here
where I can get About and Help.

98
00:04:50.060 --> 00:04:54.880
And I've got the lock which is tied
into me not being logged in, all right.

99
00:04:54.880 --> 00:04:57.590
Because they don't know if
I'm coming from a Mac, or

100
00:04:57.590 --> 00:04:58.810
a Windows machine or a Linux machine.

101
00:04:58.810 --> 00:05:01.555
They don't know much about me, they just
know that I've viewed this web page.

102
00:05:01.555 --> 00:05:04.095
I want people to be able
to view the web page.

103
00:05:04.095 --> 00:05:06.935
But in order to be able to edit and
make changes you've got to authenticate.

104
00:05:06.935 --> 00:05:09.205
So, I'm going to log in as me.

105
00:05:09.205 --> 00:05:10.895
And so I'll punch in those credentials.

106
00:05:10.895 --> 00:05:12.645
And your end users would
need to do this too,

107
00:05:12.645 --> 00:05:15.020
they're going to log in as themselves.

108
00:05:15.020 --> 00:05:18.680
And once they log in,
this is where the real power comes in.

109
00:05:18.680 --> 00:05:22.420
Up top, I now have a little pencil icon.

110
00:05:22.420 --> 00:05:24.450
And that pencil icon is the edit one.

111
00:05:24.450 --> 00:05:27.820
Now I can edit this page and
change what's on it, modify it,

112
00:05:27.820 --> 00:05:29.230
change the way that it works.

113
00:05:29.230 --> 00:05:31.430
I can hit the plus sign
to create new Wikis.

114
00:05:31.430 --> 00:05:34.640
You might want to have several
Wikis that are nested in here.

115
00:05:34.640 --> 00:05:37.350
And my little gear,
I don't just have About and Help,

116
00:05:37.350 --> 00:05:38.780
now I have my User Settings also.

117
00:05:38.780 --> 00:05:40.440
So, I can start to set
some of the defaults for

118
00:05:40.440 --> 00:05:44.190
how I experience this page and
I can log back out again, right?

119
00:05:44.190 --> 00:05:48.000
So, that's all stuff that we gain by
making sure that we're logged in.

120
00:05:48.000 --> 00:05:53.230
If I hit my little navigation bar over
here, I can see the main wiki that I'm on,

121
00:05:53.230 --> 00:05:57.600
My Activity and My Documents, so stuff
that I've added, and all activities and

122
00:05:57.600 --> 00:06:00.830
wikis, so I can start to see that
information too, and then the Web Calendar

123
00:06:00.830 --> 00:06:03.070
that we'll talk about a little

Let me get in the right folder,
there we go.

673
00:33:52.775 --> 00:33:57.125
/Library/server/mail and
I'm gonna get into the Data folder.

674
00:33:57.125 --> 00:34:01.105
And in the Data folder is where you'll
start to find your mailbox database.

675
00:34:01.105 --> 00:34:02.395
Now there's other stuff in here but

676
00:34:02.395 --> 00:34:06.902
this right here is where our mailbox
database is stored, that mail folder.

677
00:34:06.902 --> 00:34:10.663
And if I go into the mail folder I'm
gonna see that little shared folder for

678
00:34:10.663 --> 00:34:13.707
Dovecot and I actually don't
see my mailbox database yet.

679
00:34:13.707 --> 00:34:16.182
And that's because we haven't
processed a single email.

680
00:34:16.182 --> 00:34:17.612
But as soon as we process an email,

681
00:34:17.612 --> 00:34:20.472
as soon as we get a client connected,
the mailbox database will appear.

682
00:34:20.472 --> 00:34:23.172
And we'll start to see our data,
and that'll start to

683
00:34:23.172 --> 00:34:27.222
grow as information gets put in there,
so you can kinda track how big that is.

684
00:34:27.222 --> 00:34:32.480
Incoming and outgoing email is being
processed goes in the Spool folder,

685
00:34:32.480 --> 00:34:38.030
so I'm in /Library/Server/Mail/Data/Spool.

686
00:34:38.030 --> 00:34:42.670
And if you look in there, here's where
your incoming email, your bounced email,

687
00:34:42.670 --> 00:34:45.880
mail that's dropped,
all those things are going right here

688
00:34:45.880 --> 00:34:49.190
while it's handling them before
putting them into our mailbox.

689
00:34:49.190 --> 00:34:54.900
And the last one that's important
to us is the virus quarantine.

690
00:34:54.900 --> 00:35:00.166
If something gets quarantined, it ends
up in the data folder in the scanner

691
00:35:00.166 --> 00:35:05.098
folder and if we go into scanner there
is another folder in there called

692
00:35:05.098 --> 00:35:09.845
virusmail which might not exist yet
it doesn't exist yet for me.

693
00:35:09.845 --> 00:35:14.085
No it's virusmail with an s that
will make a difference there we go.

694
00:35:14.085 --> 00:35:18.080
So that virusmail's folder that's
where it get quarantined email goes.

695
00:35:18.080 --> 00:35:21.140
So if it finds a virus it sticks it there
and then after a while it deletes it.

696
00:35:21.140 --> 00:35:23.240
Now, I got permission
denied because it's secure.

697
00:35:23.240 --> 00:35:25.990
They don't want just any old user browsing
into that folder cuz this is where

698
00:35:25.990 --> 00:35:27.640
the infected emails are.

699
00:35:27.640 --> 00:35:33.760
But we could always do a sudo and pull
up what's in there, it should be empty.

700
00:35:33.760 --> 00:35:36.970
So let me just get it and,
yeah, so it's empty.

701
00:35:36.970 --> 00:35:39.850
I haven't received any infected email but
if I had they'd be right there.

702
00:35:39.850 --> 00:35:43.600
They'd be eml files that you could
read if If it was actually safe,

703
00:35:43.600 --> 00:35:45.200
you could pull the data out of there.

704
00:35:45.200 --> 00:35:48.070
Odds are if it makes it into that
folder though it's not safe and

705
00:35:48.070 --> 00:35:50.560
you may want to flush it out every now and
then on your own, or you can just wait and

706
00:35:50.560 --> 00:35:52.320
the system will flush it out for you.

707
00:35:52.320 --> 00:35:56.216
>> Don, great information on
getting the server side app setup.

708
00:35:56.216 --> 00:35:59.224
Now I know, we don't have any
information in that database yet,

709
00:35:59.224 --> 00:36:01.040
because we don't have a client setup.

710
00:36:01.040 --> 00:36:04.390
And you're going to show us that, so
a lot more good information on that, but

711
00:36:04.390 --> 00:36:06.990
looking at the clock here, it does look
like we're coming to the end of another

712
00:36:06.990 --> 00:36:09.970
episode, but before we sign out,
do you got any additional information?

713
00:36:09.970 --> 00:36:12.698
>> Yeah, we'll do a part two because
we need to show the client side,

714
00:36:12.698 --> 00:36:14.161
get an email client connected, and

715
00:36:14.161 --> 00:36:17.158
show some email actually moving
because that's kinda the whole point.

716
00:36:17.158 --> 00:36:20.320
Just be aware that setting a mail server
is really easy It does require some

717
00:36:20.320 --> 00:36:21.340
maintenance, right?

718
00:36:21.340 --> 00:36:24.340
We need to make sure we are doing those
backups, that's really important.

719
00:36:24.340 --> 00:36:28.330
And then make sure your MX records
are configured properly otherwise

720
00:36:28.330 --> 00:36:29.300
email is not gonna come in.

721
00:36:29.300 --> 00:36:31.430
Your outgoing email will work fine,
but your incoming won't.

722
00:36:31.430 --> 00:36:33.270
So definitely be aware of that.

723
00:36:33.270 --> 00:36:36.090
>> Well Don, we appreciate your wealth of
knowledge on that, and we appreciate you,

724
00:36:36.090 --> 00:36:36.940
the viewer, for watching.

725
00:36:36.940 --> 00:36:40.480
We are gonna go ahead and sign off for
ITProTV, I have been your host, Wes Bryan.

726
00:36:40.480 --> 00:36:41.057
>> And I'm Don Pezet.

727
00:36:41.057 --> 00:36:43.241
>> And we'll see you next time.

728
00:36:43.241 --> 00:36:50.930
[MUSIC]

episodes.description: In this episode, Wes and Don continue their demonstration of OS X Servers Mail Server. They focus on the client-side setup using the Mail App. They explore the common protocols used to send and receive emails as well as the configurations needed to successfully use the email client.
episodes.title: Mail Server Part 2
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.100 --> 00:00:10.100
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:12.034 --> 00:00:14.922
Welcome back to another exciting
episode here at ITProTV.

3
00:00:14.922 --> 00:00:17.670
I'm your host Wes Bryan,
and in today's episode,

4
00:00:17.670 --> 00:00:21.115
we're continuing through our
series on OSX Server essentials.

5
00:00:21.115 --> 00:00:23.785
Specifically, we're looking
at collaborative services and

6
00:00:23.785 --> 00:00:27.400
we're coming back with a part two,
that's right, mail server the sequel.

7
00:00:27.400 --> 00:00:29.740
Joining me in the studios today,
is none other than Mr. Don Pezet.

8
00:00:29.740 --> 00:00:31.020
Don, how are you doing to day, sir?

9
00:00:31.020 --> 00:00:33.664
>> Doing great Wes, ready to wrap
up our mail server conversation.

10
00:00:33.664 --> 00:00:34.662
If you didn't watch it,

11
00:00:34.662 --> 00:00:37.419
we filmed an episode already about
setting up the mail server piece,

12
00:00:37.419 --> 00:00:40.940
we went through that whole process,
got the mail server up and running.

13
00:00:40.940 --> 00:00:42.600
But we never actually used the darn thing,
right.

14
00:00:42.600 --> 00:00:43.480
It was just sitting there.

15
00:00:43.480 --> 00:00:46.520
And we say it's a mail server, but
how do we know it's actually working?

16
00:00:46.520 --> 00:00:49.380
So in this episode what we're gonna do is
we're gonna get some clients connected to

17
00:00:49.380 --> 00:00:51.250
it, and actually send some email,

18
00:00:51.250 --> 00:00:52.820
cuz that's kinda the whole point
of having one of these things.

19
00:00:52.820 --> 00:00:55.470
So we're gonna jump in and
get that set up.

20
00:00:55.470 --> 00:01:01.150
Now fortunately, OS X includes an email
plan, it's actually a pretty good one.

21
00:01:01.150 --> 00:01:04.270
Some operating systems,
like that one from those Microsoft people,

22
00:01:04.270 --> 00:01:06.830
have a really crummy email
plan package with them.

23
00:01:06.830 --> 00:01:09.700
But in OS X,
the mail app is pretty full featured.

24
00:01:09.700 --> 00:01:13.096
And if we're running our own mail server,
we can get connected really fast and

25
00:01:13.096 --> 00:01:16.455
now we're up and we're running and
we don't need any third party software.

26
00:01:16.455 --> 00:01:18.370
It's all kind of self contained.

27
00:01:18.370 --> 00:01:19.373
So let's tackle that.

28
00:01:19.373 --> 00:01:23.077
And before I jump into the client, let me
start here in this server and just recap

29
00:01:23.077 --> 00:01:27.270
so my settings, cuz we are gonna need
some information to get a client setup.

30
00:01:27.270 --> 00:01:32.050
When a client connects to a mail server,
they're going to use two protocols.

31
00:01:32.050 --> 00:01:35.066
One for sending e-mail and
one for receiving e-mail.

32
00:01:35.066 --> 00:01:40.070
Now on the sending side it's only SMTP,
there's just one protocol, that's easy.

33
00:01:40.070 --> 00:01:42.130
But on the receiving side
there's two protocols, and so

34
00:01:42.130 --> 00:01:45.400
I need to look at my server
to see what's even supported.

35
00:01:45.400 --> 00:01:48.901
So before you connect a client,
we need to understand some basic things,

36
00:01:48.901 --> 00:01:50.790
like how can I authenticate?

37
00:01:50.790 --> 00:01:53.365
Right now my authentication is
set to automatic, right, so

38
00:01:53.365 --> 00:01:56.457
I'm in the server app and I'm just
going to the mail server to find this.

39
00:01:56.457 --> 00:02:00.713
And authentication is set to automatic, so
that means that I can use Open Directory,

40
00:02:00.713 --> 00:02:03.270
Active Directory,
Local Users, whatever it is.

41
00:02:03.270 --> 00:02:05.140
Now I'm not connected
to an Active Directory,

42
00:02:05.140 --> 00:02:07.790
so I'm gonna have to use
an Open Directory account or

43
00:02:07.790 --> 00:02:10.890
a Local User account to be able to
authenticate and connect to email.

44
00:02:10.890 --> 00:02:15.000
So that's fine, I've got an Open
Directory, that's what I'm gonna use.

45
00:02:15.000 --> 00:02:15.638
After that,

46
00:02:15.638 --> 00:02:18.954
I'm kind of left to the various
protocols that I wanna connect via.

47
00:02:18.954 --> 00:02:24.150
And Apple supports all the main ones.

48
00:02:24.150 --> 00:02:30.455
SMTP for sending email, and we have
POP3 and IMAP4 for receiving email.

49
00:02:30.455 --> 00:02:33.405
So when I set up my client,
I can kind of pick and choose.

50
00:02:33.405 --> 00:02:36.155
So let's jump over to
a client like this guy.

51
00:02:36.155 --> 00:02:40.475
So here I've got an El Capitan install
that is basically a stock install that I

52
00:02:40.475 --> 00:02:43.755
haven't really messed with, and
we're gonna configure that mail app.

53
00:02:43.755 --> 00:02:46.335
And the mail app is right
here in our dock by default.

54
00:02:46.335 --> 00:02:50.100
So we'll just fired that up, and
it's got no mail account by default, so

55
00:02:50.100 --> 00:02:51.380
we gotta add one.

56
00:02:51.380 --> 00:02:56.096
So it's offering to connect iCloud,
which is what Apple wants everybody use

57
00:02:56.096 --> 00:03:00.810
these days, we've got Microsoft Exchange,
you've got Google for Gmail or

58
00:03:00.810 --> 00:03:04.456
Google apps, Yahoo email and
AOL, or Other Mail Account.

59
00:03:04.456 --> 00:03:08.280
If you're hosting your own server,
you are a Other Mail Account.

60
00:03:08.280 --> 00:03:10.250
So I'll need to choose that and
hit Continue.

61
00:03:10.250 --> 00:03:13.570
The nice part about picking
one of these others is that

62
00:03:13.570 --> 00:03:16.750
Apple already knows who
the mail server should be.

63
00:03:16.750 --> 00:03:20.200
Apple already knows,
do they use SMTP, do they use POP3,

64
00:03:20.200 --> 00:03:24.342
do they use IMAP 4, they already know
all of that for these providers.

65
00:03:24.342 --> 00:03:27.177
So if you are using one of those
providers, that's what you wanna choose,

66
00:03:27.177 --> 00:03:30.740
but in our case we have our own server,
so we've gotta choose other.

67
00:03:30.740 --> 00:03:33.440
And now it's gonna try and
automatically discover the mail server.

68
00:03:33.440 --> 00:03:39.560
Now this works great for things like
Gmail, Hotmail, Yahoo, whatever, because

69
00:03:39.560 --> 00:03:42.970
they have auto discovery records that
are set up to be able to find your server.

70
00:03:42.970 --> 00:03:47.640
For your own private server though, we
don't have those auto discovery records,

71
00:03:47.640 --> 00:03:49.800
and so this doesn't normally work.

72
00:03:49.800 --> 00:03:53.970
Sometimes it will work if your client is
on the same network as the mail server,

73
00:03:53.970 --> 00:03:55.667
like Bonjour could do some discovery, but

74
00:03:55.667 --> 00:03:57.360
you'll find that most of
the time it doesn't work.

75
00:03:57.360 --> 00:04:00.370
I'll give it a shot here just
to see if it finds mine.

76
00:04:00.370 --> 00:04:05.640
So I am putting in my email
address donpezet@lab.itpro.tv and

77
00:04:05.640 --> 00:04:07.460
I'll punch in my password.

78
00:04:08.530 --> 00:04:10.800
And then we will attempt to sign in.

79
00:04:10.800 --> 00:04:13.040
So what it's going to do is going
to try and find that mail server.

80
00:04:13.040 --> 00:04:14.790
Now I fully expect it to fail.

81
00:04:14.790 --> 00:04:18.820
And if it fails, the screen just
becomes a little more complex.

82
00:04:18.820 --> 00:04:21.780
And now we have the ability to type
in all the details it couldn't

83
00:04:21.780 --> 00:04:23.570
automatically figure out.

84
00:04:23.570 --> 00:04:26.320
So, the user name is set to automatic.

85
00:04:26.320 --> 00:04:29.170
And by automatic it means I'm
gonna use the email address.

86
00:04:29.170 --> 00:04:33.410
Most systems use the email address as the
user name and so we can stick with that.

87
00:04:33.410 --> 00:04:34.540
But some don't.

88
00:04:34.540 --> 00:04:37.780
Like if I'm connecting to a Microsoft
Active Directory, your user name might

89
00:04:37.780 --> 00:04:41.790
not match your email address and so you
can override that right here if you want.

90
00:04:41.790 --> 00:04:43.690
Then you punch in your password.

91
00:04:43.690 --> 00:04:48.010
Next, you've gotta provide what
type of account it's going to be.

92
00:04:48.010 --> 00:04:50.940
Is it IMAP or POP?

93
00:04:50.940 --> 00:04:52.910
I always talk about these two.

94
00:04:52.910 --> 00:04:57.630
The original protocol for receiving
email is POPs, the Post Office Protocol.

95
00:04:57.630 --> 00:05:00.916
And what it would let you do is your
client can connect to a mail server, and

96
00:05:00.916 --> 00:05:02.931
it can say,
hey do you have a new email for me?

97
00:05:02.931 --> 00:05:04.620
And the server would say yes.

98
00:05:04.620 --> 00:05:06.860
And you would grab a copy of it and

99
00:05:06.860 --> 00:05:11.070
delete the email from the server, and so
now the email just existed on your system.

100
00:05:11.070 --> 00:05:13.659
And so the server only had new email,
it never had old email.

101
00:05:14.870 --> 00:05:18.930
Well, that was fine when people
just had one computer, but

102
00:05:18.930 --> 00:05:20.240
there's some problems with that.

103
00:05:20.240 --> 00:05:24.400
For example, what happens if your computer
crashes, if your hard drive dies?

104
00:05:24.400 --> 00:05:25.900
You just lost all your email, right?

105
00:05:25.900 --> 00:05:28.590
The server doesn't have a copy of it
anymore, so that was one problem.

106
00:05:28.590 --> 00:05:30.923
Another problem is what
if I had two devices?

107
00:05:30.923 --> 00:05:34.090
I might download some email on one
device and some email on another device.

108
00:05:34.090 --> 00:05:37.393
So back when POP was created, it was
lucky for someone to have one computer,

109
00:05:37.393 --> 00:05:39.580
better yet two, so it wasn't a big deal.

110
00:05:39.580 --> 00:05:42.260
But in today's world where you
have a tablet, and a phone and

111
00:05:42.260 --> 00:05:44.630
a computer, it doesn't work so well.

112
00:05:44.630 --> 00:05:46.230
So they actually had to change POP.

113
00:05:46.230 --> 00:05:50.380
In POP version 3, you can leave email on
the server and you can mark it as read.

114
00:05:50.380 --> 00:05:53.828
So now one device will know that another
device has already read the email or

115
00:05:53.828 --> 00:05:57.100
downloaded it, but it gets left
on the server, so that's good.

116
00:05:57.100 --> 00:05:58.782
But it also is still very simple.

117
00:05:58.782 --> 00:06:00.920
It doesn't support things like folders.

118
00:06:00.920 --> 00:06:02.350
I don't about you Wes, but

119
00:06:02.350 --> 00:06:06.090
I create a ton of folders inside of my
mailbox, POP doesn't let you do that.

120
00:06:06.090 --> 00:06:10.350
So everything is in one big folder,
and if you have an email box

121
00:06:10.350 --> 00:06:13.160
with 10,000 emails in it,
that's a bit of challenge, right.

122
00:06:13.160 --> 00:06:15.324
So POP is the older protocol.

123
00:06:15.324 --> 00:06:19.724
Still works, still perfectly viable,
but largely it's been replaced by IMAP.

124
00:06:19.724 --> 00:06:22.023
And you saw how the mail
client defaulted to IMAP,

125
00:06:22.023 --> 00:06:24.620
that's what most people
are going to want to use.

126
00:06:24.620 --> 00:06:29.220
With IMAP, it supports sub-folders,
it was designed to leave the emails

127
00:06:29.220 --> 00:06:32.130
on the server, so, if your client loses
its hard drive, it's no big deal,

128
00:06:32.130 --> 00:06:33.580
all your email's still on the server.

129
00:06:33.580 --> 00:06:35.250
You can mark messages as read, so

130
00:06:35.250 --> 00:06:36.950
everybody can see that
it's already been read.

131
00:06:36.950 --> 00:06:38.550
It handles multiple devices just fine.

132
00:06:38.550 --> 00:06:42.170
So it's a very well rounded protocol and
it's the one you wanna use.

133
00:06:42.170 --> 00:06:44.060
Now, the Mac mail server supports both.

134
00:06:44.060 --> 00:06:46.600
So I could choose either here and
get connected, but for

135
00:06:46.600 --> 00:06:47.899
the best functionality, I wanna do IMAP.

136
00:06:49.160 --> 00:06:51.070
Then I need to put the name of my server.

137
00:06:51.070 --> 00:06:54.590
Now the name of the server, is well,
however you connect to it, right?

138
00:06:54.590 --> 00:06:58.664
So mine is osxserver01.lab.itpro.tv,

139
00:06:58.664 --> 00:07:02.526
you'll put in whatever
the name of yours is.

140
00:07:03.660 --> 00:07:07.630
Your outgoing mail server might not be
the same as your incoming mail server.

141
00:07:07.630 --> 00:07:11.810
So you might have one SMTP server that you
send out through, and a different POP and

142
00:07:11.810 --> 00:07:13.780
IMAP server that you receive through.

143
00:07:13.780 --> 00:07:17.150
In my scenario where I'm using
the Mac mail server, it's all in one.

144
00:07:17.150 --> 00:07:21.321
So I'm gonna put the exact
same name in the next box.

145
00:07:21.321 --> 00:07:22.919
There, so it'll be the same.

146
00:07:24.000 --> 00:07:26.920
Now it only lets me set one username and
password here.

147
00:07:26.920 --> 00:07:31.240
Most SMTP servers authenticate based on
IP, so you don't need a user name and

148
00:07:31.240 --> 00:07:32.720
password to send an email.

149
00:07:32.720 --> 00:07:35.500
But some do, and if that happens,
it will prompt me for that password later.

150
00:07:36.740 --> 00:07:38.910
All right, so
I'm gonna go ahead and sign in.

151
00:07:38.910 --> 00:07:42.280
Now it's gonna reach out to that server,
and try and connect.

152
00:07:42.280 --> 00:07:43.763
All right, hopefully it connects.

153
00:07:43.763 --> 00:07:45.030
That's what I expect to see.

154
00:07:45.030 --> 00:07:46.820
If it gets a failure, it will let me know.

155
00:07:46.820 --> 00:07:47.390
There I go, all right.

156
00:07:47.390 --> 00:07:50.339
So it connected, it's asking if I
wanna do Mail and Notes or just Mail.

157
00:07:50.339 --> 00:07:53.369
A lot of people don't realize it,
but the notes system that is in,

158
00:07:53.369 --> 00:07:55.983
that is in Mac OS,
those notes are actually just emails.

159
00:07:55.983 --> 00:07:58.885
It stores them like emails,
and they show up as notes.

160
00:07:58.885 --> 00:08:00.977
Well you can sync that
through your server and so

161
00:08:00.977 --> 00:08:05.140
now you can synchronize your notes across
multiple devices, kind of a cool feature.

162
00:08:05.140 --> 00:08:07.540

screw this up as much as I can.

388
00:19:44.830 --> 00:19:48.930
So, what happened was, the email came in,
and the email came in to this

389
00:19:48.930 --> 00:19:53.650
folder right here,
/Library/Server/Mail/Data/spool.

390
00:19:53.650 --> 00:19:55.080
That's where incoming email comes in.

391
00:19:55.080 --> 00:19:57.990
So, he wrote an email via SMTP,
which transferred to the server.

392
00:19:57.990 --> 00:19:59.510
It was dropped right here in this folder.

393
00:19:59.510 --> 00:20:02.070
Okay, when you look at this folder.

394
00:20:02.070 --> 00:20:03.590
For the most part it should be empty.

395
00:20:03.590 --> 00:20:04.160
Right?

396
00:20:04.160 --> 00:20:09.590
And, well, it's got some folders, so,
incoming is where it actually ends up.

397
00:20:09.590 --> 00:20:13.310
There, which is protected,
so let me get around that.

398
00:20:13.310 --> 00:20:15.770
And eventually we'll be able to
see the contents of this folder,

399
00:20:15.770 --> 00:20:16.970
which should be empty.

400
00:20:16.970 --> 00:20:19.540
There we go.
[LAUGH] It's kinda anti-climactic, right?

401
00:20:19.540 --> 00:20:23.990
But it should be empty, because emails
shouldn't sit there in the spool.

402
00:20:23.990 --> 00:20:27.030
An email should come in,
be processed and sent out.

403
00:20:27.030 --> 00:20:30.650
If emails are sitting here in the spool,
that means you've got a problem, right?

404
00:20:30.650 --> 00:20:33.900
Maybe the server that it's heading for
is down, and it can't get there.

405
00:20:33.900 --> 00:20:36.660
Or maybe the mailbox is corrupt,
and so it's stuck here.

406
00:20:36.660 --> 00:20:38.710
If you see emails stuck here,
that's a problem.

407
00:20:38.710 --> 00:20:40.240
So, it should be empty.

408
00:20:40.240 --> 00:20:42.930
His email came here, the server saw it.

409
00:20:42.930 --> 00:20:46.040
It looked at it, scanned it for
spam, scanned it for viruses.

410
00:20:46.040 --> 00:20:49.000
Once that was done,
it recognized that it was destined for

411
00:20:49.000 --> 00:20:52.150
my mailbox, and it put it in my mailbox.

412
00:20:52.150 --> 00:20:55.490
Now my mailbox,
is not here in the Spool folder,

413
00:20:55.490 --> 00:21:00.980
it's actually back here in the Data
folder inside of the Mail sub-folder.

414
00:21:00.980 --> 00:21:04.050
And inside of the Mail
sub-folder what you're gonna see

415
00:21:04.050 --> 00:21:07.330
are a couple of different folders here and
see how they're all owned by dovecot?

416
00:21:07.330 --> 00:21:09.240
Dovecot is the POP3 and IMAP4 server.

417
00:21:10.520 --> 00:21:14.720
And so I can see these individual
GUIDs that are created.

418
00:21:14.720 --> 00:21:16.180
The map to each of our mailboxes.

419
00:21:16.180 --> 00:21:17.490
Now I don't know which one is me.

420
00:21:17.490 --> 00:21:19.060
One of those would be mine.

421
00:21:19.060 --> 00:21:20.360
One of those would be Wes.

422
00:21:20.360 --> 00:21:24.080
And you've got this users folder
where additional data is stored,

423
00:21:24.080 --> 00:21:26.340
which is like metadata for our mailboxes.

424
00:21:26.340 --> 00:21:31.290
And if I pull some of that,
actually that one.

425
00:21:31.290 --> 00:21:32.200
There we go.

426
00:21:32.200 --> 00:21:38.130
I can see Don Pezet and [LAUGH], having
a hard time typing today, there we go.

427
00:21:38.130 --> 00:21:44.670
Don Pezet and Wes Bryan, and if I look in
there, I can start to see the message log,

428
00:21:44.670 --> 00:21:48.840
the key words, all that metadata
that's being stored from my mailbox.

429
00:21:48.840 --> 00:21:50.190
All right in there and somewhere in there,

430
00:21:50.190 --> 00:21:53.970
one of those entities
are identified which GUID is mine.

431
00:21:53.970 --> 00:21:58.720
And then my actual message is,
end up in whichever one of these nice,

432
00:21:58.720 --> 00:22:01.400
long easier member folders is typed me.

433
00:22:01.400 --> 00:22:02.880
I don't know which one.

434
00:22:02.880 --> 00:22:07.400
So, if I were to try and
pull out just one of those, there we go.

435
00:22:07.400 --> 00:22:10.550
You look inside of it and you see a lot
of the same type data that's tied to it.

436
00:22:10.550 --> 00:22:15.260
So that's where all of our information is
actually ending up, maildirfolder, right?

437
00:22:15.260 --> 00:22:18.600
So it's all tucked away in there,
and then when I go to check my mail,

438
00:22:18.600 --> 00:22:20.930
I reach out with dovecot
IMAP 4 in this case.

439
00:22:20.930 --> 00:22:24.190
And it says yeah, you've got new email,
here let me send it to you.

440
00:22:24.190 --> 00:22:28.270
And the client downloads it, and
we see it right here in the mail app.

441
00:22:28.270 --> 00:22:30.850
So its a lot cleaner and a lot easier.

442
00:22:30.850 --> 00:22:33.680
The end users don't see all the stuff
going on behind the scenes, but

443
00:22:33.680 --> 00:22:36.500
that's what's actually happening.

444
00:22:36.500 --> 00:22:40.380
A lot of places something can go wrong and
stop an email from flowing And

445
00:22:40.380 --> 00:22:43.190
with troubleshooting,
the Telnet tool that I showed you guys,

446
00:22:43.190 --> 00:22:44.610
that works out really well.

447
00:22:44.610 --> 00:22:48.660
But usually the first place I go
to troubleshoot is the server log.

448
00:22:48.660 --> 00:22:53.460
That if we jump back to our server and
you go up to logs,

449
00:22:53.460 --> 00:22:57.650
inside of logs you've got specific
logs for the mail server.

450
00:22:57.650 --> 00:22:58.720
And so if I come down here and

451
00:22:58.720 --> 00:23:02.470
look at it, under mail it's got
more logs than anything else.

452
00:23:02.470 --> 00:23:04.120
You've got antivirus logs.

453
00:23:04.120 --> 00:23:06.537
You got junk mail and spam scanning logs.

454
00:23:06.537 --> 00:23:08.210
You got the mail server log itself.

455
00:23:08.210 --> 00:23:12.170
You got a log just for IMAP,
just for POP and just for SMTP.

456
00:23:12.170 --> 00:23:14.270
How do I know I'm actually using IMAP 4?

457
00:23:14.270 --> 00:23:17.605
Well it's kind of hard to see,
in the mail client it doesn't show you but

458
00:23:17.605 --> 00:23:20.395
I can go to my POP log and
see that it's empty.

459
00:23:20.395 --> 00:23:22.895
Right?
So nobody's connecting via POP, and

460
00:23:22.895 --> 00:23:27.515
I can flip to my i-map log and
see that I've got all these connections.

461
00:23:27.515 --> 00:23:30.770
And I can see connections coming
from a particular client.

462
00:23:30.770 --> 00:23:32.960
If the user's not filled in
then it hasn't logged in.

463
00:23:32.960 --> 00:23:33.690
But right after that,

464
00:23:33.690 --> 00:23:37.450
see how I see the login for wesbryan,
so this is Wes connecting via imap.

465
00:23:37.450 --> 00:23:40.660
And up here I see donpezet
connecting via imap.

466
00:23:40.660 --> 00:23:41.900
So you can actually spot that.

467
00:23:41.900 --> 00:23:43.757
And if there's some kind of
troubleshooting problems,

468
00:23:43.757 --> 00:23:46.260
if it's a bad password, or whatever,
you'll see that information.

469
00:23:46.260 --> 00:23:51.810
Or here I'm just seeing
Disconnected: Logged out in=30 out=510.

470
00:23:51.810 --> 00:23:55.010
I was connected and I idled,
and so I disconnected.

471
00:23:55.010 --> 00:23:59.530
And so, in that time I sent 30 bytes of
data and I received 510 bytes of data.

472
00:23:59.530 --> 00:24:02.050
And you'll see more connections
that are like that as we

473
00:24:02.050 --> 00:24:04.130
query to see if the mailbox
had data in it.

474
00:24:04.130 --> 00:24:06.540
Those are periodic check
ins that are occurring.

475
00:24:06.540 --> 00:24:08.250
All that's right here in the logs,

476
00:24:08.250 --> 00:24:10.780
you can pull up all that
information if you have a problem.

477
00:24:10.780 --> 00:24:13.720
The mail server error log is
another great way to look.

478
00:24:13.720 --> 00:24:15.740
And you'll see here where
I made some changes and

479
00:24:15.740 --> 00:24:17.460
sort of had to reload the config.

480
00:24:17.460 --> 00:24:19.910
That's not a error,
that is just kind of a notice.

481
00:24:19.910 --> 00:24:23.050
But then you have other
errors that pop up in here.

482
00:24:23.050 --> 00:24:26.220
>> Well, Don, if we do not have anything
else, what do you say if we wrap this up?

483
00:24:26.220 --> 00:24:29.370
But before we do,
do you got any additional information?

484
00:24:29.370 --> 00:24:31.330
>> You know, here in the show for
the sake of the exam,

485
00:24:31.330 --> 00:24:34.880
we focused on the mail app inside of OS
10 because that will be what on the exam.

486
00:24:34.880 --> 00:24:36.658
In real life land,
you could be using anything.

487
00:24:36.658 --> 00:24:40.290
You could use Thunderbird, or heck,
you can even go old school Unix and

488
00:24:40.290 --> 00:24:42.630
throw in Pine or
something crazy like that if you wanted.

489
00:24:42.630 --> 00:24:46.970
It all works, this is all open standard
stuff so really compatible, but

490
00:24:46.970 --> 00:24:48.280
on the exam you will
just see the mail client.

491
00:24:48.280 --> 00:24:50.870
So as long as you've got that under
your belt, you're in good shape.

492
00:24:50.870 --> 00:24:53.620
>> All right, well we appreciate that
information and we appreciate you,

493
00:24:53.620 --> 00:24:54.220
the viewer.

494
00:24:54.220 --> 00:24:56.940
Signing out for ITProTV,
I've been your host, Wes Bryan.

495
00:24:56.940 --> 00:24:57.940
>> And I'm Don Pezet.

496
00:24:57.940 --> 00:25:00.327
>> And we'll see you next time.

497
00:25:00.327 --> 00:25:08.300
[MUSIC]

episodes.description: In this episode, Wes and Don demonstrate setting up a centralized calendar system using Calendar inside the server app. The CalDAV and protocols like IMAP and POP that are used by Calendar. They explain the different locations and resources that can be reserved through Calendar like meeting rooms, projectors and computers.
episodes.title: Calendar Server
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.000 --> 00:00:10.000
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:11.876 --> 00:00:14.788
Welcome to another exciting
episode here at ITProTV.

3
00:00:14.788 --> 00:00:17.429
I'm your host Wes Bryan,
and in today's episode,

4
00:00:17.429 --> 00:00:20.430
we're continuing through our
OS X Server Essentials, and

5
00:00:20.430 --> 00:00:24.591
over the last couple of episodes we've
been looking at Collaborative Services.

6
00:00:24.591 --> 00:00:26.720
Well, we're gonna keep
on that train here and

7
00:00:26.720 --> 00:00:29.130
joining us in the studios is
none other than Mr. Don Pezet.

8
00:00:29.130 --> 00:00:30.250
Don, how you doing today, sir?

9
00:00:30.250 --> 00:00:31.190
>> I'm doing great, Wes.

10
00:00:31.190 --> 00:00:33.030
Ready to collaborate and listen.

11
00:00:33.030 --> 00:00:34.630
So, in this episodes,

12
00:00:34.630 --> 00:00:37.830
we're gonna be tackling the Calendar
service inside of the Server app.

13
00:00:37.830 --> 00:00:40.750
If you're watching these episodes in
order, our the last episode was the Mail

14
00:00:40.750 --> 00:00:45.280
server, which is arguably the most
useful collaboration service.

15
00:00:45.280 --> 00:00:46.820
You email people, they can read it, and

16
00:00:46.820 --> 00:00:49.530
you just talk to somebody,
it's great, it's exciting.

17
00:00:49.530 --> 00:00:52.140
With a calendar,
we don't really talk to people, right?

18
00:00:52.140 --> 00:00:55.720
But you do coordinate
events with a calendar.

19
00:00:55.720 --> 00:00:56.390
So for example,

20
00:00:56.390 --> 00:00:59.550
I might want to schedule a meeting, and
I want to invite Wes to the meeting.

21
00:00:59.550 --> 00:01:01.280
So I need to let him know
that there's a meeting,

22
00:01:01.280 --> 00:01:04.270
I need to get it put it on my calendar,
I need to put it on his calendar.

23
00:01:04.270 --> 00:01:08.060
Those are all things that go into
setting up and scheduling a meeting.

24
00:01:08.060 --> 00:01:10.630
Well, the Calendar service
can facilitate that.

25
00:01:10.630 --> 00:01:13.030
Now, you don't actually
need the Calendar service.

26
00:01:13.030 --> 00:01:17.360
Everybody has the calendar app on their
Mac already, so you can just fire up your

27
00:01:17.360 --> 00:01:20.130
calendar and start creating
events to your heart's content.

28
00:01:21.270 --> 00:01:24.320
The problem is,
those are decentralized calendars.

29
00:01:24.320 --> 00:01:27.160
In other words, if I launch
the calendar app on my laptop, and

30
00:01:27.160 --> 00:01:32.130
I start creating events, they exist
right here on my laptop and that's it.

31
00:01:32.130 --> 00:01:35.470
If I get a new laptop,
those calendar events aren't there.

32
00:01:35.470 --> 00:01:38.170
If I invite Wes to a meeting,
and I put it on my calendar,

33
00:01:38.170 --> 00:01:40.730
that's great, it's not on his calendar.

34
00:01:40.730 --> 00:01:43.840
A centralized calendar,
a shared calendar is what we need.

35
00:01:43.840 --> 00:01:46.490
We need some way to tie
everybody's calendars together,

36
00:01:46.490 --> 00:01:47.920
and there's a few reasons for that, right?

37
00:01:47.920 --> 00:01:50.720
There might be that we want to
have a true central calendar,

38
00:01:50.720 --> 00:01:52.180
like a corporate calendar.

39
00:01:52.180 --> 00:01:54.784
These are the days that we are open,
these are the days that we are closed,

40
00:01:54.784 --> 00:01:56.763
here's special events like
the end of our fiscal year.

41
00:01:56.763 --> 00:02:00.417
Those are corporate calendar type items so
we might have that one big shared

42
00:02:00.417 --> 00:02:05.020
calendar, but then we want everyone else
to have their own individual calendars.

43
00:02:05.020 --> 00:02:07.660
But we still want them stored centrally.

44
00:02:07.660 --> 00:02:09.180
And there's a big reason for that.

45
00:02:09.180 --> 00:02:12.270
There's the backup reason right that we
don't want if someone's laptop fails we

46
00:02:12.270 --> 00:02:13.290
don't want them to lose their calendar.

47
00:02:13.290 --> 00:02:15.380
If we have it centralized It
can be stored on a server.

48
00:02:15.380 --> 00:02:16.870
It can be backed up there.

49
00:02:16.870 --> 00:02:20.640
But the other thing is if I want to
schedule a meeting, and I want to schedule

50
00:02:20.640 --> 00:02:24.390
it for tomorrow I might say when is
Wes going to be available tomorrow.

51
00:02:24.390 --> 00:02:27.360
Well, in a decentralized environment,
I just have to pick a time.

52
00:02:27.360 --> 00:02:31.820
I'm gonna say, hey, I'm gonna
schedule a meeting for 2 PM tomorrow.

53
00:02:31.820 --> 00:02:33.250
And let me just invite Wes.

54
00:02:33.250 --> 00:02:35.220
And then Wes can accept or decline.

55
00:02:35.220 --> 00:02:37.480
If he's busy at 2 PM tomorrow,
he'll decline it.

56
00:02:37.480 --> 00:02:39.180
And now I gotta go and
find another time, and

57
00:02:39.180 --> 00:02:43.000
we keep guessing like that until we find
a good time that lines up for everybody.

58
00:02:43.000 --> 00:02:45.930
The more people in the meeting,
the harder that becomes.

59
00:02:45.930 --> 00:02:51.710
If we have centralized calendars,
I can actually view Wes' free busy data.

60
00:02:51.710 --> 00:02:55.670
I can look and, not necessarily see
what he's doing, at any given time, but

61
00:02:55.670 --> 00:02:57.600
I can see whether he's busy or not.

62
00:02:57.600 --> 00:03:02.390
And so, when I look at Wes' calendar for
tomorrow, I might see that he's busy.

63
00:03:02.390 --> 00:03:07.150
From noon to 2 PM and
busy from 3 PM to 5 PM, but

64
00:03:07.150 --> 00:03:10.280
from 2 to 3, he's available, and
so if I schedule a meeting and

65
00:03:10.280 --> 00:03:14.020
I put it in that slot, he's more likely
to accept and attend the meeting.

66
00:03:14.020 --> 00:03:17.710
Now, we're better able to manage
when people are available, and

67
00:03:17.710 --> 00:03:21.670
a centralized calendar server
is what facilitates that.

68
00:03:21.670 --> 00:03:25.100
Now that sounds complex, its a lot of
moving pieces and believe me it is.

69
00:03:25.100 --> 00:03:28.292
Its a hard thing to set up
unless we have the Server app.

70
00:03:28.292 --> 00:03:32.718
Right, the Server app, Apple takes open
source source Caliber Technologies, and

71
00:03:32.718 --> 00:03:35.597
they package it in a super-easy
to implement manner.

72
00:03:35.597 --> 00:03:39.855
We can turn this on, get it set up and
have people connected in short order.

73
00:03:39.855 --> 00:03:42.235
>> Don, how about compatibility
with other clients?

74
00:03:42.235 --> 00:03:43.597
Is that something we get here as well?

75
00:03:43.597 --> 00:03:47.220
>> Yeah, so it is based on
OpenSource technologies, and

76
00:03:47.220 --> 00:03:50.250
what it's really based off of
is something called CalDAV.

77
00:03:50.250 --> 00:03:56.480
Cal is C-A-L for Calendar and DAV is D-A-V
for Distributed, Authoring and Versioning.

78
00:03:56.480 --> 00:03:58.200
That might sound familiar to you,

79
00:03:58.200 --> 00:04:00.720
in another episode we
talked about WebDAV Right?

80
00:04:00.720 --> 00:04:03.940
Web Distributed Authoring and Versioning.

81
00:04:03.940 --> 00:04:08.279
And what WebDAV did is, it allows people
to edit a website via some standards,

82
00:04:08.279 --> 00:04:09.360
protocols.

83
00:04:09.360 --> 00:04:12.310
Well, CalDAV lets you do the same
thing but for a calendar.

84
00:04:12.310 --> 00:04:14.570
It's the same protocol converted over, and

85
00:04:14.570 --> 00:04:19.000
because it's an open standard protocol,
pretty much everybody supports it.

86
00:04:19.000 --> 00:04:23.500
You can connect to a CalDAV calendar
from the calendar app inside of a mac,

87
00:04:23.500 --> 00:04:25.050
which is what will be on the exam.

88
00:04:25.050 --> 00:04:28.110
But in real life you can connect from
Thunderbird or Microsoft Outlook.

89
00:04:28.110 --> 00:04:31.930
You can connect from any third party
calendar service that supports the CalDAV

90
00:04:31.930 --> 00:04:33.670
protocol, which most of them do.

91
00:04:33.670 --> 00:04:36.070
So, it's pretty cool that you can
connect with however you want,

92
00:04:36.070 --> 00:04:39.150
and then the counter store
the same way on the server.

93
00:04:39.150 --> 00:04:41.990
>> Now Don, in some of the other services,
the network services and

94
00:04:41.990 --> 00:04:43.450
here on the Collaborative Services,

95
00:04:43.450 --> 00:04:47.360
you've shown us how we fire up
the server up and we turn it on.

96
00:04:47.360 --> 00:04:50.310
Now, is that what we're gonna be doing
here or is it gonna be a little bit more

97
00:04:50.310 --> 00:04:53.170
configuration as to go on before we
can get this set up and running?

98
00:04:53.170 --> 00:04:55.190
This is pretty much
a flip-the-switch type thing.

99
00:04:55.190 --> 00:04:57.810
Let me show you here, so
I'm on my server, and,

100
00:04:57.810 --> 00:05:01.470
this is the same server I used in the Mail
episode, so when we set up a Mail server.

101
00:05:01.470 --> 00:05:04.960
So, the only thing really special about it
is, I do have an Open Directory, right?

102
00:05:04.960 --> 00:05:08.550
You don't have to have an open
directory to make all this stuff work.

103
00:05:08.550 --> 00:05:11.840
But, the Collaboration Services are really
designed to work with an Open Directory.

104
00:05:11.840 --> 00:05:14.440
And have it with the user accounts
exist here on the server.

105
00:05:14.440 --> 00:05:16.790
If you do it without it,
discovery becomes a real challenge.

106
00:05:16.790 --> 00:05:19.960
So this is normally going to
be coupled open directory.

107
00:05:19.960 --> 00:05:22.910
So, if you don't know about open
directory check out our episode on that,

108
00:05:22.910 --> 00:05:25.160
we show how to set it up and
get all that fired up.

109
00:05:25.160 --> 00:05:26.710
But the calendar itself is right up here.

110
00:05:26.710 --> 00:05:28.060
The Calendar service.
