00:27:12.530 --> 00:27:15.940
It's really cool when you do it for
people, whoops or

562
00:27:15.940 --> 00:27:17.190
you kill the whole event like I just did.

563
00:27:17.190 --> 00:27:21.940
So let me recreate that,
and I'll put that back from

564
00:27:21.940 --> 00:27:27.600
noon to 2 with people, so if he goes
to add an invitee, and he adds me.

565
00:27:27.600 --> 00:27:30.090
So here's me,
he's gonna add me to the meeting.

566
00:27:30.090 --> 00:27:31.370
Now, I'm busy also.

567
00:27:31.370 --> 00:27:33.580
So see how I get the little x by my name?

568
00:27:33.580 --> 00:27:37.030
So he can't invite me to the meeting
cuz I'm busy during that time.

569
00:27:37.030 --> 00:27:41.500
If he hits Check Availability,
that'll open up the scheduling planner.

570
00:27:41.500 --> 00:27:43.760
And when the scheduling planner comes up,

571
00:27:43.760 --> 00:27:48.900
what he's gonna see is his schedule and
my schedule and

572
00:27:48.900 --> 00:27:52.710
the conference room schedules and anybody
else that's been invited to the thing.

573
00:27:52.710 --> 00:27:56.490
And he's gonna see when they're available,
all right.

574
00:27:56.490 --> 00:27:59.740
So he can look at this and say,
all right, I want to invite Don And

575
00:27:59.740 --> 00:28:04.460
looking at Don, well he's open in
the morning but it's already passed.

576
00:28:04.460 --> 00:28:08.080
That's why it's this kind of light pink
area, and we don't want to schedule there.

577
00:28:08.080 --> 00:28:11.310
Then we hit noon to two, and
that's what I'm trying to schedule.

578
00:28:11.310 --> 00:28:13.170
And see these gray bars?

579
00:28:13.170 --> 00:28:17.990
That's when we're busy, so
we're busy during this time.

580
00:28:17.990 --> 00:28:20.040
I'm overlapping with that and
that's a problem.

581
00:28:20.040 --> 00:28:21.290
So what do I do?

582
00:28:21.290 --> 00:28:23.350
Well I can take the meeting.

583
00:28:23.350 --> 00:28:24.710
And I can move it.

584
00:28:24.710 --> 00:28:28.850
I can move it forward in time and
have it start here, and

585
00:28:28.850 --> 00:28:33.680
now I'm not overlapping, or
I can move it back in time to try and

586
00:28:33.680 --> 00:28:37.390
schedule later but
I'm getting passed our Work close hours.

587
00:28:37.390 --> 00:28:39.310
So I'm just gonna move
it forward like that.

588
00:28:39.310 --> 00:28:41.080
And so now, it's available.

589
00:28:41.080 --> 00:28:42.750
Maybe I need to move it to tomorrow.

590
00:28:42.750 --> 00:28:46.790
And so we can just hit tomorrow, and
now we've got plenty of availability.

591
00:28:46.790 --> 00:28:47.290
So all right.

592
00:28:47.290 --> 00:28:48.290
Well, we're too busy today.

593
00:28:48.290 --> 00:28:49.480
Let's put it tomorrow.

594
00:28:49.480 --> 00:28:52.940
And we're both free tomorrow afternoon,
so we can schedule that or

595
00:28:52.940 --> 00:28:54.150
you can just set next available time,

596
00:28:54.150 --> 00:28:58.070
it will find the best time possible for
everybody you've invited.

597
00:28:58.070 --> 00:28:58.930
We're just two people.

598
00:28:58.930 --> 00:29:00.050
It's not a big deal.

599
00:29:00.050 --> 00:29:02.220
But if you try to invite
30 people to a meeting,

600
00:29:02.220 --> 00:29:05.680
it is really difficult to find
a time where everybody's available.

601
00:29:05.680 --> 00:29:07.670
This is it's a great way to find that.

602
00:29:07.670 --> 00:29:12.260
And so now when you hit done, it's gonna
automatically change the meeting date, and

603
00:29:12.260 --> 00:29:13.210
now we can send it.

604
00:29:14.370 --> 00:29:16.130
So this'll be my All Hands Meeting.

605
00:29:17.370 --> 00:29:21.340
And he can send it,
everybody's invited, everybody's happy.

606
00:29:21.340 --> 00:29:23.140
Now people just have to
accept the invitation.

607
00:29:23.140 --> 00:29:26.410
And if I switch back to my account, I
should have an invitation waiting for me.

608
00:29:27.460 --> 00:29:30.210
Because we turned on push
notifications I don't have to wait.

609
00:29:30.210 --> 00:29:31.110
It should already be lit up.

610
00:29:31.110 --> 00:29:33.120
And, yep.
I missed my notification,

611
00:29:33.120 --> 00:29:36.770
because it happened so fast, but I've got
a little number one on my calendar here.

612
00:29:37.950 --> 00:29:38.800
There it is.

613
00:29:38.800 --> 00:29:39.830
Yep.
And I can accept.

614
00:29:39.830 --> 00:29:41.100
And now I'm in that meeting too.

615
00:29:41.100 --> 00:29:41.820
All right.
So

616
00:29:41.820 --> 00:29:44.880
all this being handled by that
centralized calendar service.

617
00:29:44.880 --> 00:29:46.310
Pretty neat stuff.

618
00:29:46.310 --> 00:29:47.890
Was it hard to set up?

619
00:29:47.890 --> 00:29:49.370
Nah, it's really easy.

620
00:29:49.370 --> 00:29:51.910
We just turn the stuff on and
you're in business.

621
00:29:51.910 --> 00:29:54.850
It's one of the cooler
collaboration services.

622
00:29:54.850 --> 00:29:59.220
>> Well, it looks like we're ready to do a
little bit of collaborating here now, Don.

623
00:29:59.220 --> 00:30:00.730
A lot of great information.

624
00:30:00.730 --> 00:30:03.860
Looking at the clock, it does look like
we're about ready to wrap this one up.

625
00:30:03.860 --> 00:30:06.360
But before we do,
do you have any additional words?

626
00:30:06.360 --> 00:30:07.090
That's about it.

627
00:30:07.090 --> 00:30:10.360
I can't stress enough how important
it is to back up the calendar server.

628
00:30:10.360 --> 00:30:13.300
You really need to back it up,
because if you lose the server you've

629
00:30:13.300 --> 00:30:16.220
just lost the centralized calender
that you're telling everyone to use.

630
00:30:16.220 --> 00:30:19.280
Also, make sure you educate your users,
that when they create a calendar item that

631
00:30:19.280 --> 00:30:21.870
they need to create it in that
central calendar, not in their own.

632
00:30:21.870 --> 00:30:24.060
So that it'll actually
reside on the server.

633
00:30:24.060 --> 00:30:28.210
They can still maintain their own private
calendar if they want, for personal stuff.

634
00:30:28.210 --> 00:30:30.570
But all the business stuff needs
to go on that central calendar,

635
00:30:30.570 --> 00:30:32.440
it's all about user education there.

636
00:30:32.440 --> 00:30:33.930
>> Well, we thank you for
that information.

637
00:30:33.930 --> 00:30:35.890
And we do thank you,
the viewer, for watching.

638
00:30:35.890 --> 00:30:37.966
We're gonna go ahead and
sign out of here at ITProTV.

639
00:30:37.966 --> 00:30:39.148
I've been your host Wes Bryan.

640
00:30:39.148 --> 00:30:40.011
>> And I'm Don Pezet.

641
00:30:40.011 --> 00:30:42.052
>> And we'll see you next time.

642
00:30:42.052 --> 00:30:49.680
[MUSIC]

episodes.description: In this episode, Wes and Don demonstrate setting up a centralized contacting through the Contacts Service. They talk about concepts like CardDAV, DNS requirements, configuring Push notifications and the benefits of Contacts. They also show the viewer how to configure the client to connect to the Contacts Service.
episodes.title: Contacts Service
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.000 --> 00:00:10.000
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:11.883 --> 00:00:14.743
Welcome back to another exciting
episode here at ITProTV.

3
00:00:14.743 --> 00:00:16.113
I'm your host, Wes Bryan.

4
00:00:16.113 --> 00:00:19.419
And in today's episode, we're
continuing through our series on OS X s

5
00:00:19.419 --> 00:00:23.071
Server Essentials and we're coming
back with more collaborative services.

6
00:00:23.071 --> 00:00:25.552
In this episode,
we're gonna be talking about contacts and

7
00:00:25.552 --> 00:00:28.192
joining me in the studio today is
none other than Mr. Don Pezet.

8
00:00:28.192 --> 00:00:29.332
Don, how are you doing today, sir?

9
00:00:29.332 --> 00:00:30.194
>> I'm doing great, Wes.

10
00:00:30.194 --> 00:00:32.627
Ready to jump right back into
collaborative services and

11
00:00:32.627 --> 00:00:34.104
much like Jodie Foster found out.

12
00:00:34.104 --> 00:00:36.498
If we want to reach out and talk to
somebody, we've got to make contact.

13
00:00:36.498 --> 00:00:37.462
And in this episode,

14
00:00:37.462 --> 00:00:40.471
we're gonna look at the contact
service as part of the server app.

15
00:00:40.471 --> 00:00:44.047
This one's not one of the glamorous
services that's gonna blow your mind with

16
00:00:44.047 --> 00:00:47.801
amazement, but it is a very functional,
very useful service that is built-in.

17
00:00:47.801 --> 00:00:51.280
Because we talk about collaboration,
we talked about sending email or

18
00:00:51.280 --> 00:00:52.675
chat messages or whatever.

19
00:00:52.675 --> 00:00:55.696
In order to chat with somebody or
in order to send somebody an email,

20
00:00:55.696 --> 00:00:57.711
you have to know their
contact information.

21
00:00:57.711 --> 00:01:00.188
You have to know their email address or
XNP address or

22
00:01:00.188 --> 00:01:03.370
whatever it is that you're
gonna use to talk to them with.

23
00:01:03.370 --> 00:01:05.240
So, how do you find that out?

24
00:01:05.240 --> 00:01:08.175
There's the old fashioned what,
which is you ask them,

25
00:01:08.175 --> 00:01:10.759
which is nice if they're
right there in the room.

26
00:01:10.759 --> 00:01:12.735
So hey, Wes, what's your email address?

27
00:01:12.735 --> 00:01:14.280
I can find out, right, he's right here.

28
00:01:14.280 --> 00:01:18.360
But what if it's somebody, I might
work with a company with 5,000 people,

29
00:01:18.360 --> 00:01:22.560
I haven't met all 5,000 people and some
of them might be in different states or

30
00:01:22.560 --> 00:01:24.016
even different countries.

31
00:01:24.016 --> 00:01:27.618
So I can't just ask them in the hallway,
I can call them on the phone, but

32
00:01:27.618 --> 00:01:29.466
now I gotta know their phone number.

33
00:01:29.466 --> 00:01:33.169
So one way or another, I've gotta be able
to find the people to then communicate

34
00:01:33.169 --> 00:01:35.837
with them and
the contact service is what provides that.

35
00:01:35.837 --> 00:01:39.888
Now, the primary purpose of
the contact service is to create

36
00:01:39.888 --> 00:01:43.793
a centralized directory of
our employees and their data.

37
00:01:43.793 --> 00:01:46.875
And by their data,
I mean their name, email address,

38
00:01:46.875 --> 00:01:49.825
maybe phone number,
other information like that.

39
00:01:49.825 --> 00:01:51.662
The stuff you have on a business card.

40
00:01:51.662 --> 00:01:55.677
Now I know what you might be thinking is
well, doesn't the Open Directory do that?

41
00:01:55.677 --> 00:01:58.481
We can have an Open Directory and we can
have all of our user accounts in there,

42
00:01:58.481 --> 00:02:01.026
and it would have all their name,
and address, and phone number, and

43
00:02:01.026 --> 00:02:02.780
we could pull it right
from the open directory.

44
00:02:02.780 --> 00:02:04.315
And you're absolutely right,
we certainly could.

45
00:02:04.315 --> 00:02:08.841
In fact, if you watched our episode
that we did on the email server and

46
00:02:08.841 --> 00:02:14.006
on the calendar server, we did that
without having the contact server set up.

47
00:02:14.006 --> 00:02:16.942
We were able to create meetings and
send emails, and

48
00:02:16.942 --> 00:02:19.086
we did it all through Open Directory.

49
00:02:19.086 --> 00:02:22.778
So, open Directory can take
the place of the contact server or

50
00:02:22.778 --> 00:02:26.290
contact server can take
the place of open directory.

51
00:02:26.290 --> 00:02:27.957
Open Directory provides authentication.

52
00:02:27.957 --> 00:02:29.353
What if I don't care about authentication?

53
00:02:29.353 --> 00:02:32.560
What if I don't wanna bind people's
machines to my Open Directory?

54
00:02:32.560 --> 00:02:33.775
I don't want that.
Everybody has their own

55
00:02:33.775 --> 00:02:34.663
independent machines.

56
00:02:34.663 --> 00:02:38.242
I can setup a contact server,
have everybody's accounts right there

57
00:02:38.242 --> 00:02:43.140
centralized and people can find that
data without being bound to our network.

58
00:02:43.140 --> 00:02:45.179
But most commonly, you use them both.

59
00:02:45.179 --> 00:02:48.591
You use them both together,
because they are very functional and

60
00:02:48.591 --> 00:02:51.940
it does make a lot of sense, so
you can have the Open Directory and

61
00:02:51.940 --> 00:02:55.288
you can have the contact service
both running at the same time and

62
00:02:55.288 --> 00:02:57.978
now that's much easier to
find people resources.

63
00:02:57.978 --> 00:03:00.233
So, let's take a look at how this works.

64
00:03:00.233 --> 00:03:03.594
The contact service itself
is pretty easy to get setup,

65
00:03:03.594 --> 00:03:06.320
it's one of those that
is not just very hard.

66
00:03:06.320 --> 00:03:10.437
We've already seen calendar and mail in
some of the other episodes and so on.

67
00:03:10.437 --> 00:03:12.079
So on this one,
we're taking a look at contacts.

68
00:03:12.079 --> 00:03:16.308
And if I click on it, you'll see that
there's not a whole lot of options.

69
00:03:16.308 --> 00:03:18.911
We've got the permissions that we
see on pretty much every server.

70
00:03:18.911 --> 00:03:20.470
So, whose allowed to contact?

71
00:03:20.470 --> 00:03:23.334
And then after that,
we've got our push notification and

72
00:03:23.334 --> 00:03:27.494
notice my push notifications are already
enabled and that's cuz we turned them on.

73
00:03:27.494 --> 00:03:32.485
In one of the episodes, either the nail
episode or the calendar episode.

74
00:03:32.485 --> 00:03:34.461
You turn it on for one service,
it turns it on for all of them.

75
00:03:34.461 --> 00:03:37.064
So, that's the push
notifications through Apple.

76
00:03:37.064 --> 00:03:40.294
So really,
the only option I have here is this one.

77
00:03:40.294 --> 00:03:44.311
Allow users to search the directory
using Contacts application.

78
00:03:44.311 --> 00:03:45.612
What's that?

79
00:03:45.612 --> 00:03:49.986
Well, by default,
the contact service has a separate

80
00:03:49.986 --> 00:03:53.800
list of user accounts
than the Open Directory.

81
00:03:53.800 --> 00:03:55.379
They're two separate things,

82
00:03:55.379 --> 00:03:59.182
because the contact service can operate
independent of the Open Directory.

83
00:03:59.182 --> 00:04:00.532
I don't even have to
have an open directory.

84
00:04:00.532 --> 00:04:05.750
I can go shut that service off and
just do contacts, and it ran just fine.

85
00:04:05.750 --> 00:04:08.356
But if I wanna run both
of them simultaneously,

86
00:04:08.356 --> 00:04:11.297
it's a good idea to check
this little box right here.

87
00:04:11.297 --> 00:04:14.962
And what that says is if somebody
connects to the contacts server and

88
00:04:14.962 --> 00:04:18.949
they do a search, it'll search all
the contacts in the contact server and

89
00:04:18.949 --> 00:04:21.613
it'll search everybody
in the open directory.

90
00:04:21.613 --> 00:04:23.566
So now, they are truly merged together.

91
00:04:23.566 --> 00:04:27.188
I get it all right here in one place and
things kind of operate the way we want.

92
00:04:27.188 --> 00:04:29.395
If I don't have an Open Directory,
I don't need to check this.

93
00:04:29.395 --> 00:04:31.070
I can ignore it and everything is fine.

94
00:04:31.070 --> 00:04:32.994
So kinda up to me on how
I wanna go on that, but

95
00:04:32.994 --> 00:04:34.660
usually we're gonna wanna check it.

96
00:04:34.660 --> 00:04:38.675
But that's the only real
option I've got here and

97
00:04:38.675 --> 00:04:43.940
once that's set, I can turn it on and
I've got a contact server.

98
00:04:43.940 --> 00:04:47.118
So, what just happened in the background
since obviously something had to happen

99
00:04:47.118 --> 00:04:48.233
that we couldn't see here?

100
00:04:48.233 --> 00:04:49.211
So, what happened?

101
00:04:49.211 --> 00:04:53.116
Well, the contact service started and
what the contact

102
00:04:53.116 --> 00:04:57.943
service is is it's actually built
off of something called CardDAV.

103
00:04:57.943 --> 00:05:02.347
CardDAV is card distributed authoring and
versioning, that should sound familiar.

104
00:05:02.347 --> 00:05:04.783
When we talked about the web server,
we talked about WebDAV.

105
00:05:04.783 --> 00:05:08.578
Web Distributed Authoring and Versioning
where somebody could connect and

106
00:05:08.578 --> 00:05:10.947
edit files, and
push data up to the server, and

107
00:05:10.947 --> 00:05:14.342
do all that via their web browser,
and we saw that with Wikkis also.

108
00:05:14.342 --> 00:05:17.608
And then when we got the calendars,
there was CalDAV,

109
00:05:17.608 --> 00:05:21.163
which was A modified version
of WebDAV used for calendars.

110
00:05:21.163 --> 00:05:24.598
Well, CardDAV is a modified
version of WebDAV, but

111
00:05:24.598 --> 00:05:29.560
it's designed to be used for
business cards or vCards, really.

112
00:05:29.560 --> 00:05:32.708
The digital business cards we have
that have your name, phone number,

113
00:05:32.708 --> 00:05:35.908
email address, mailing address,
fax number, whatever else it is that

114
00:05:35.908 --> 00:05:39.223
you wanna put in there, even a picture,
it can all be a part of that format.

115
00:05:39.223 --> 00:05:41.961
>> So, Don, it really looks like
WebDAV when it comes down to it,

116
00:05:41.961 --> 00:05:45.234
forms like a basis for a lot of the
services you see inside of the server app.

117
00:05:45.234 --> 00:05:46.374
>> Yeah, absolutely.

118
00:05:46.374 --> 00:05:48.350
It's an open standard,
so it's really flexible.

119
00:05:48.350 --> 00:05:50.675
Apple uses it for all of this stuff,
and plenty of other vendors do too.

120
00:05:50.675 --> 00:05:52.720
This is not just an Apple special thing.

121
00:05:52.720 --> 00:05:57.115
So, when we get this set up, we're gonna
use the contact service here in OS X, but

122
00:05:57.115 --> 00:05:58.983
you can use third party software.

123
00:05:58.983 --> 00:06:02.450
There's tons of different things out
there, like the GTD software and

124
00:06:02.450 --> 00:06:06.381
even Microsoft Outlook that can connect
up and pull contacts through cardDAV and

125
00:06:06.381 --> 00:06:08.600
pull your calendar through CalDAV and
so on.

126
00:06:08.600 --> 00:06:10.550
So, that's what's really
nice about this stuff.

127
00:06:10.550 --> 00:06:13.672
It is technically using
HTTP behind the scenes.

128
00:06:13.672 --> 00:06:16.065
So it's using the hypertext
transfer protocol, but

129
00:06:16.065 --> 00:06:18.311
on a different port number
than what were used to.

130
00:06:18.311 --> 00:06:20.541
So normally when you browse the web,
it's on port 80.

131
00:06:20.541 --> 00:06:24.317
But when you're doing CardDAV, it ends up
on a crazy port, I can never remember,

132
00:06:24.317 --> 00:06:25.649
I wrote it down, 8800.

133
00:06:25.649 --> 00:06:32.409
So, 8800 for the unsecured traffic and
8843 for the secure traffic.

134
00:06:32.409 --> 00:06:36.266
So it's got these different port
numbers it uses, but it's still HTTP.

135
00:06:36.266 --> 00:06:37.360
It's still that standard protocol.

136
00:06:37.360 --> 00:06:39.592
It makes it really easy for
third parties to support it.

137
00:06:39.592 --> 00:06:44.232
So in the Mac world, we see it used
in the mail app, the calendar app,

138
00:06:44.232 --> 00:06:45.513
the contacts app.

139
00:06:45.513 --> 00:06:49.486
They all use these WebDAV variations.

140
00:06:49.486 --> 00:06:52.063
But just in general,
in the third party world,

141
00:06:52.063 --> 00:06:54.650
you see tons of software
that leverages it too.

142
00:06:54.650 --> 00:06:56.464
So, that got turned on in the background.

143
00:06:56.464 --> 00:07:00.740
Kind of a mini web server was turned
on and a database was created.

episodes.description: In this episode, Wes and Don demonstrate setting up a centralized messaging server through the Messages Service. They explain the protocols Jabber and Extensible Messaging and Presence that are used by the Messages Service. They talk about configuring the Messages Service to archive all messages as well as rebuilding the archive when recovery is needed.

28
00:01:23.145 --> 00:01:26.730
So you can have a video message
between you and someone else, and

29
00:01:26.730 --> 00:01:28.360
it's pretty powerful stuff.

30
00:01:28.360 --> 00:01:30.800
Now, Apple didn't create
this from scratch.

31
00:01:30.800 --> 00:01:31.675
It's not like FaceTime.

32
00:01:31.675 --> 00:01:35.180
FaceTime, Apple did create from scratch,
but this, the Messages service as

33
00:01:35.180 --> 00:01:38.495
a part of the Server app,
is actually based on open standards.

34
00:01:38.495 --> 00:01:40.370
It's designed for open communications.

35
00:01:40.370 --> 00:01:43.240
FaceTime, well,
that just works with Apple devices, but

36
00:01:43.240 --> 00:01:48.070
the Messages service in the Server app is
built on top of a protocol called XMPP.

37
00:01:48.070 --> 00:01:52.248
And that's the, I have to cheat on
this one, the Extensible Messaging and

38
00:01:52.248 --> 00:01:53.453
Presence Protocol.

00:01:53.453 --> 00:01:55.270
So what does that mean?

40
00:01:55.270 --> 00:01:56.749
Extensible, it supports add-ons.

41
00:01:56.749 --> 00:01:58.460
It can do a lot more than just text.

42
00:01:58.460 --> 00:02:00.420
You can extend that functionality.

43
00:02:00.420 --> 00:02:03.830
Messaging, when we send messages,
you send text blurbs,

44
00:02:03.830 --> 00:02:06.180
typically is what you send along.

45
00:02:06.180 --> 00:02:11.220
Presence, presence means it'll tell me
if you're active on your computer or

46
00:02:11.220 --> 00:02:13.390
if you've been idling for
15 minutes, right?

47
00:02:13.390 --> 00:02:14.820
Are you away or are you there?

48
00:02:14.820 --> 00:02:16.320
Do you get a green light or red light?

49
00:02:16.320 --> 00:02:18.270
So we get presence information.

50
00:02:18.270 --> 00:02:21.940
And then protocol, it's a language that
two computers can speak to each other.

51
00:02:21.940 --> 00:02:24.660
Now, XMPP doesn't really
roll off the tongue, and so

52
00:02:24.660 --> 00:02:28.030
it has another name that a lot of

53
00:02:28.030 --> 00:02:30.720
Jabber is J-A-B-B-E-R, Jabber.

54
00:02:30.720 --> 00:02:35.760
And the Jabber protocol is XMPP, and
XMPP is Jabber, they're the same thing.

55
00:02:35.760 --> 00:02:38.940
So, when you go out on the Internet,
you're gonna learn about this protocol,

56
00:02:38.940 --> 00:02:41.080
you'll see people call it
the two different names, but

57
00:02:41.080 --> 00:02:42.670
it is actually the same.

58
00:02:42.670 --> 00:02:45.610
Now, with Jabber,
it's nice because it's an open standard.

59
00:02:45.610 --> 00:02:47.060
Anybody can support it.

60
00:02:47.060 --> 00:02:49.850

00:02:49.850 --> 00:02:51.970
So, for example, Google Talk.

00:02:51.970 --> 00:02:56.370
Google was using XMPP, and you could tap

00:02:56.370 --> 00:02:58.870

00:02:58.870 --> 00:03:01.400

00:03:01.400 --> 00:03:03.520

00:03:03.520 --> 00:03:06.140

00:03:06.140 --> 00:03:07.580

00:03:07.580 --> 00:03:10.490

00:03:10.490 --> 00:03:14.430

00:03:14.430 --> 00:03:18.770

00:03:18.770 --> 00:03:22.390

00:03:33.190 --> 00:03:35.780

00:03:35.780 --> 00:03:39.870

00:03:39.870 --> 00:03:41.800

00:03:41.800 --> 00:03:43.060

00:03:51.550 --> 00:03:56.472

00:03:56.472 --> 00:03:58.050

00:03:58.050 --> 00:04:01.040

84
00:04:01.040 --> 00:04:05.320

00:04:05.320 --> 00:04:09.450

00:04:09.450 --> 00:04:12.280

00:04:12.280 --> 00:04:15.660

88
00:04:15.660 --> 00:04:18.240
So I've gotta make sure to

89
00:04:18.240 --> 00:04:20.350

moving to another machine.

90
00:04:20.350 --> 00:04:22.130
That's always a bit of a challenge.

91
00:04:22.130 --> 00:04:28.360
The other thing is, as a company, we

92
00:04:28.360 --> 00:04:29.970
So, for example,

00:04:29.970 --> 00:04:33.877

00:04:33.877 --> 00:04:37.190
Well, if everybody's chatting just

00:04:37.190 --> 00:04:39.286
its really hard for

00:04:39.286 --> 00:04:43.220

00:04:43.220 --> 00:04:46.052

00:04:46.052 --> 00:04:47.540
And thats really the main reason for

99
00:04:47.540 --> 00:04:50.318

00:04:50.318 --> 00:04:53.010
Now, if somebodys computer gets lost or

101
00:04:53.010 --> 00:04:55.437

00:04:55.437 --> 00:04:58.760
And end users never really

00:04:58.760 --> 00:05:00.322

00:05:00.322 --> 00:05:01.440
[LAUGH] It's gonna come around and

00:05:01.440 --> 00:05:04.800

00:05:04.800 --> 00:05:08.340
Well, you can pull up the phone log and

00:05:08.340 --> 00:05:09.670

00:05:09.670 --> 00:05:11.059
So you'd have all of that in one place.

00:05:12.138 --> 00:05:13.780

So, if you're just gonna turn it on and

00:06:49.576 --> 00:06:52.485

00:07:01.500 --> 00:07:03.540
It's whatever you want it to be really,

00:07:03.540 --> 00:07:08.040
